description: The Network+ certification was introduced by CompTIA in 1999 and was designed to do for Network Technicians what the A+ certification did for Computer Technicians. Obtaining Network+ certification shows that the holder possess the same knowledge and skills of someone who has worked for nine months as a Network Technician. The Network+ exam covers topics ranging from theory (terminology, topology and design) to hardware (routers, switches and cabling) and provides users with a broad, vendor neutral perspective on the topics required to work in the field of Network Administration.

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.947
Welcome to ITVProTV,

2

3

>> You're watching ITProTV.

4

>> All right, greetings, everyone, welcome

5
00:00:16.800 --> 00:00:18.110
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

6
00:00:18.110 --> 00:00:22.110
And in today's episode, we are back with

7
00:00:22.110 --> 00:00:23.600
And of course, joining us in the studio,

00:00:23.600 --> 00:00:26.520
our resident expert on that very topic,
Mr. Wes Bryan.

9
00:00:26.520 --> 00:00:27.500

10
00:00:27.500 --> 00:00:29.090
How's it going?
>> Man, it's going great, thanks for

11
00:00:29.090 --> 00:00:29.860
having me here.

12
00:00:29.860 --> 00:00:32.070
As always, it's definitely a pleasure.

13
00:00:32.070 --> 00:00:35.310
We're gonna be diving in today
like Dan says with more Net+.

14
00:00:35.310 --> 00:00:38.420
And we're gonna be coming at you
with some networking devices.

15
00:00:38.420 --> 00:00:40.420
And we're gonna kinda introduce these and

16
00:00:40.420 --> 00:00:45.020
tell you a little bit about what you
can probably expect to see on the exam.

17
00:00:45.020 --> 00:00:47.060
Again we can't tell you everything.

18
00:00:47.060 --> 00:00:49.410
But we'll try to give you some
of the characteristics and

19
00:00:49.410 --> 00:00:51.750
the attributes of these
different network devices.

20
00:00:51.750 --> 00:00:55.780
And just kind of introduce them to you so
that you'll be familiar with them.

21
00:00:55.780 --> 00:00:58.060
And we're just gonna take
our objective list, guys.

22
00:00:58.060 --> 00:01:00.350
And we're gonna go one
by one through the list.

23
00:01:00.350 --> 00:01:03.140
And we'll explain them as we get to them.

24
00:01:03.140 --> 00:01:05.910
In fact, one of the very first things,
I'll tell you what, before we even get

25
00:01:05.910 --> 00:01:08.725
into that let's just talk about
networking devices in general, right.

26
00:01:08.725 --> 00:01:12.055
It really boils down to two different
types of networking devices.

27
00:01:12.055 --> 00:01:14.595
You have what are known as endpoints, and

28
00:01:14.595 --> 00:01:16.355
you have what are known
as redistribution points.

29
00:01:16.355 --> 00:01:20.845
Those are two really really the typical
two types of network devices you have

30
00:01:20.845 --> 00:01:21.850
out there, right?

31
00:01:21.850 --> 00:01:26.370
If I have a redistribution point, it's
usually some form of network connectivity

32
00:01:26.370 --> 00:01:30.480
device that takes the signal that
it receives and it passes it.

33
00:01:30.480 --> 00:01:32.480
It might even amplify it or reboost it,

34
00:01:32.480 --> 00:01:36.220
send it on its way with a little
bit stronger of a signal.

35
00:01:36.220 --> 00:01:39.710
So, we don't have to worry about
things like signal attenuation.

36
00:01:39.710 --> 00:01:42.980
But then you have your endpoints,
and your endpoints, or end systems,

37
00:01:42.980 --> 00:01:46.840
as you might hear them called, this is
where we actually have our source and

38
00:01:46.840 --> 00:01:48.510
our destination addressing.

39
00:01:48.510 --> 00:01:52.460
Source of the communication,
that's one endpoint or end system.

40
00:01:52.460 --> 00:01:55.600
And then we send it to another
end system or endpoint and

41
00:01:55.600 --> 00:01:58.420
that becomes the destination or
recipient of the data.

42
00:01:58.420 --> 00:02:01.120
In fact, you can even see this in some
of the names of like some of the older

43
00:02:01.120 --> 00:02:04.970
routing protocol like ISIS is one and
they called that, Intermediate System to

44
00:02:04.970 --> 00:02:07.990
Intermediate System,
because their naming convention for

45
00:02:07.990 --> 00:02:11.270
the people that wrote that or
built that protocol.

46
00:02:11.270 --> 00:02:14.820
Was to call them intermediate systems and
end systems.

47
00:02:14.820 --> 00:02:18.720
So again, an intermediate system would
be a redistribution point, right,

48
00:02:18.720 --> 00:02:21.290
it's intermediate between the source and
destination.

49
00:02:21.290 --> 00:02:27.170
So, we're gonna be looking at pretty
much the redistribution systems, right.

50
00:02:27.170 --> 00:02:28.840
And then some of the technologies as well.

51
00:02:28.840 --> 00:02:32.180
So let's go ahead and
let's dive into the very first one here.

52
00:02:32.180 --> 00:02:35.120
We're gonna talk about
what are known as routers.

53
00:02:35.120 --> 00:02:40.180
Now if you're not familiar with
a router and what it does, a router is,

54
00:02:40.180 --> 00:02:45.400
it's a device that really what it does
is it allows us to basically connect

55
00:02:45.400 --> 00:02:49.260
to other networks that we're not aware of,
that we're not directly connected to.

56
00:02:49.260 --> 00:02:53.930
It's one of the most important networking
devices really we have on the backbone

57
00:02:53.930 --> 00:02:54.480
of the Internet.

58
00:02:54.480 --> 00:02:58.490
It's what allows us to communicate
across mass distances.

59
00:02:58.490 --> 00:03:00.990
In fact, I got a little diagram here,
we can kinda look at it.

60
00:03:00.990 --> 00:03:04.400
A router, what it does,
is it works and it routes traffic.

61
00:03:04.400 --> 00:03:08.769
It passes traffic between
endpoints based on an IP address,

62
00:03:08.769 --> 00:03:12.630
a logical address that's set in software.

63
00:03:12.630 --> 00:03:15.130
It also makes complex
routing decisions and

64
00:03:15.130 --> 00:03:19.160
what we mean by complex routing decisions
is it usually has a database that it

65
00:03:19.160 --> 00:03:23.820
stores inside of it that when it needs
to determine which way to send, for

66
00:03:23.820 --> 00:03:27.450
instance which network
to send the data to.

67
00:03:27.450 --> 00:03:32.430
Or if it's not directly connected to,
which interface do I send it out

68
00:03:32.430 --> 00:03:34.860
in order to get that information
where it needs to go.

69
00:03:34.860 --> 00:03:36.762
It can make a decision
based on a routing table.

70
00:03:36.762 --> 00:03:39.582
It can look at that database and say okay,

71
00:03:39.582 --> 00:03:45.620
I see that I've got a route that leads
out to let's say network a or network b.

72
00:03:45.620 --> 00:03:47.410
How do I get it there?

73
00:03:47.410 --> 00:03:48.800
Well I send it out this interface.

74
00:03:48.800 --> 00:03:53.210
Now what happens if the route
that's in that table

75
00:03:53.210 --> 00:03:56.320
ends up becomes a problem or
it's congested?

76
00:03:56.320 --> 00:03:57.630
Well this is the beauty of routers.

77
00:03:57.630 --> 00:03:59.680
Routers can communicate
amongst other routers.

78
00:03:59.680 --> 00:04:04.593
In fact they can form this very complex
topologies essentially by talking to each

79
00:04:04.593 --> 00:04:08.783
other and learning of networks that
they weren't aware of before and

80
00:04:08.783 --> 00:04:12.100
that's one of the great
things about a router.

81
00:04:12.100 --> 00:04:15.160
Now, some of the additional, Things that
I'd like to mention about a router so that

82
00:04:15.160 --> 00:04:20.920
you'll be prepared for it on the exam, is
where this sits in the overall OSI model.

83
00:04:20.920 --> 00:04:23.550
In another episode,
we talked about the OSI model and

84
00:04:23.550 --> 00:04:27.460
we've even talked about
a model known as TCP/IP.

85
00:04:27.460 --> 00:04:29.290
So where do routers sit.

86
00:04:29.290 --> 00:04:32.600
A router sits at layer
three of the OSI model.

87
00:04:32.600 --> 00:04:33.740
This is where routing happens.

88
00:04:33.740 --> 00:04:37.650
This is where IP addresses
are applied to our data.

89
00:04:37.650 --> 00:04:39.640
It's what routers deal with.

90
00:04:39.640 --> 00:04:43.550
Now if we're talking
about the TCIP/IP model.

91
00:04:43.550 --> 00:04:45.960
We're talking about layer two,
that's the Internet layer.

92
00:04:45.960 --> 00:04:49.610
So, OSI model, layer three, network layer.

93
00:04:49.610 --> 00:04:54.190
If you're talking about TCP/IP, it's layer
two, it's called the Internet layer.

94
00:04:54.190 --> 00:04:57.605
Again, the functionalities between the two
different models are doing the same thing.

95
00:04:57.605 --> 00:05:01.505
So, know that for
the exam just in case they ask you.

96
00:05:01.505 --> 00:05:06.125
>> Wes, typically will they ask you
questions when it comes to the models that

97
00:05:06.125 --> 00:05:09.445
you might use, are they typically gonna
ask us about the TCP/IP layer, what

98
00:05:09.445 --> 00:05:13.690
layer routers reside on, or is it gonna be
OSI or is it gonna be a jumble of both?

99
00:05:13.690 --> 00:05:15.020
>> It very well could be both.

100
00:05:15.020 --> 00:05:16.740
And let me tell you a little bit more.

101
00:05:16.740 --> 00:05:18.160
Let me elaborate a little
bit more on that.

102
00:05:18.160 --> 00:05:19.200
If you look at the objectives,

103
00:05:19.200 --> 00:05:22.220
cuz we don't really know
exactly what's on the exam.

104
00:05:22.220 --> 00:05:27.700
But they do tell you, given a scenario,
apply such and such model, right?

105
00:05:27.700 --> 00:05:31.360
So whether it's OSI, or whether it's
TCP/IP so I would say that there

106
00:05:31.360 --> 00:05:36.830
is a very high probability of
a question being like that on the exam.

107
00:05:36.830 --> 00:05:38.070
And you have to pay attention.

108
00:05:38.070 --> 00:05:40.870
Is it the OSI model, or
is it the TCP/IP model?

109
00:05:40.870 --> 00:05:44.380
And that's why it's good to know both,
and also know the relationship between

110
00:05:44.380 --> 00:05:47.520
those two models when we talk about
comparisons and the functionality.

111
00:05:47.520 --> 00:05:53.080
So if this doesn't make sense, it would
be time to check out the OSI model and

112
00:05:53.080 --> 00:05:58.420
the TCP/IP model episodes that we do have
so that you guys will be aware of that.

113
00:05:58.420 --> 00:06:00.200
All right, let's see here.

114
00:06:00.200 --> 00:06:04.090
The next thing we have are, well, this is
another device that is commonly on our

115
00:06:04.090 --> 00:06:06.600
networks and these are known as switches.

116
00:06:06.600 --> 00:06:07.580
All right, now a switch.

117
00:06:07.580 --> 00:06:09.710
What is it and what is a switch doing?

118
00:06:09.710 --> 00:06:12.780
Well, routers can route traffic

119
00:06:12.780 --> 00:06:15.855
across networks that they're
not directly connected to.

120
00:06:15.855 --> 00:06:18.480
A switch on the other hand,
it doesn't work like that.

121
00:06:18.480 --> 00:06:22.270
That's not what it does with one exception
that I'll get back to coming up.

122
00:06:22.270 --> 00:06:24.670
What it does, switching technologies,

123
00:06:24.670 --> 00:06:27.730
they work inside of your
local area networks, right?

124
00:06:27.730 --> 00:06:33.720
Routers can connect and pass traffic
between local area networks, right?

125
00:06:33.720 --> 00:06:37.348
They don't have to be directly connected
to a local area network to get that

126
00:06:37.348 --> 00:06:38.338
information to it.

127
00:06:38.338 --> 00:06:40.008
Switches on the other hand,

128
00:06:40.008 --> 00:06:44.610
they're only aware of the devices that
are directly connected to their port.

129
00:06:44.610 --> 00:06:50.220
So, the switch can communicate inside of
your local area network but the basic

130
00:06:50.220 --> 00:06:54.160
switching functionality doesn't allow you
to connect to other networks that you're

131
00:06:54.160 --> 00:06:58.579
not aware of or that are not directly
connected to your connectivity device.

132
00:06:59.680 --> 00:07:01.760
So what is it that
a switch is operating on?

133

00:21:07.832 --> 00:21:12.393

00:21:12.393 --> 00:21:16.164

00:21:16.164 --> 00:21:19.041

00:21:19.041 --> 00:21:21.730

00:21:21.730 --> 00:21:22.934

00:21:22.934 --> 00:21:28.510
is that code behaving the way it should

00:21:28.510 --> 00:21:32.430

00:21:35.890 --> 00:21:39.260

00:22:26.851 --> 00:22:29.158

00:22:29.158 --> 00:22:34.142
Because when you look at an IDS,

00:22:39.740 --> 00:22:44.687
Alert you to signs of an intrusion, so

00:22:44.687 --> 00:22:45.911

Doesn't matter if it's host based,
a process or

00:22:49.009 --> 00:22:52.272
an application that is

441
00:22:52.272 --> 00:22:55.512
Or if it's a network
intrusion detection system.

442
00:22:55.512 --> 00:22:59.550
All right,
the difference here is that the intrusion

prevention system can

The IDS is just for monitoring and

00:23:08.020 --> 00:23:10.750

00:23:10.750 --> 00:23:11.860
That's just detection.

00:23:13.000 --> 00:23:15.216
The IPS on the other hand says, yeah,

00:23:18.790 --> 00:23:24.492

00:23:29.028 --> 00:23:30.650

00:23:34.450 --> 00:23:36.880
Notice that all traffic in the IDS,

That's the big difference,
the IPS, this could be on for

00:23:55.292 --> 00:23:59.198

00:24:04.733 --> 00:24:11.250

Yeah you got an APIPA address,
yeah you got an APIPA address.

427
00:22:44.740 --> 00:22:47.870
Hey DHCP, and the DHCP server responds.

428
00:22:47.870 --> 00:22:50.990
It says, discard the APIPA and
let's go through the DORA process,

429
00:22:50.990 --> 00:22:54.490
cuz I need your IP address to
actually do some communication.

430
00:22:54.490 --> 00:22:56.440
So know what the APIPA is.

431
00:22:56.440 --> 00:22:59.490
That brings us to the end of DHCP.

432
00:22:59.490 --> 00:23:00.520
There's a lot more.

433
00:23:00.520 --> 00:23:03.560
In fact, Cherokee was mentioning
before we even started.

434
00:23:03.560 --> 00:23:04.320
She can ramble on and

435
00:23:04.320 --> 00:23:09.330
teach a week on just this topic alone and
maybe still have more concepts to go.

436
00:23:09.330 --> 00:23:12.950
Understand some of the basic concepts
that we're showing you here.

437
00:23:12.950 --> 00:23:16.770
Now the next thing that we have to talk
about is we have to talk about a concept

438
00:23:16.770 --> 00:23:21.260
known as DNS.

439
00:23:21.260 --> 00:23:25.180
DNS is a very important concept,
and what this service provides,

440
00:23:25.180 --> 00:23:26.670
let's start with the acronym.

441
00:23:26.670 --> 00:23:31.530
The acronym starts with something
known as the Domain Name System.

442
00:23:31.530 --> 00:23:33.300
All right, the Domain Name System.

443
00:23:33.300 --> 00:23:34.720
It's been around for a long time.

444
00:23:34.720 --> 00:23:36.720
I wanna say it goes back to,
I wanna say like 83,

445
00:23:36.720 --> 00:23:38.500
84 is when it first came into play.

446
00:23:39.700 --> 00:23:45.060
Now think about this, if you wanna visit
a website, you know its IP address?

447
00:23:45.060 --> 00:23:49.575
Right, that four octet dotted
decimal address, 192.168.1.10?

448
00:23:51.549 --> 00:23:52.547
Do you know it or not?

449
00:23:52.547 --> 00:23:55.870
Well if you don't know it,
you can't communicate with the website.

450
00:23:55.870 --> 00:23:57.870
>> I don't go around
memorizing IP addresses.

451
00:23:57.870 --> 00:23:58.460
>> You don't, do you?

452
00:23:58.460 --> 00:23:58.990
That's right.

453
00:23:58.990 --> 00:24:00.480
So what are we doing here?

454
00:24:00.480 --> 00:24:02.374
That's crazy talk, right?

455
00:24:02.374 --> 00:24:07.128
I'm gonna memorize every single IP address
to every website and every computer I need

456
00:24:07.128 --> 00:24:11.435
to talk to out there across the network
and the web That's where DNS comes in.

457
00:24:11.435 --> 00:24:12.927
The domain name system.

458
00:24:12.927 --> 00:24:17.376
All right, the domain name system we
have to kind of understand works on what

459
00:24:17.376 --> 00:24:21.550
are known as fully qualified domain names,
all right.

460
00:24:21.550 --> 00:24:26.420
Essentially DNS takes an FQDN a fully
qualified domain name, a name,

461
00:24:26.420 --> 00:24:32.032
something we can recognize like
www.google.com, www.comptia.org,

462
00:24:32.032 --> 00:24:36.979
www.microsoft.com maps them to
their individual IP addresses.

463
00:24:38.180 --> 00:24:41.670
Now why is that such an important
service on our network?

464
00:24:41.670 --> 00:24:46.150
Because then I don't have to
remember hundreds of IP addresses.

465
00:24:46.150 --> 00:24:48.485
I have a hard time
memorizing my anniversary.

466
00:24:48.485 --> 00:24:51.810
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let alone 10, 20, 30, 50 IP addresses,

467
00:24:51.810 --> 00:24:52.778
however many.

468
00:24:52.778 --> 00:24:53.637
>> I won't tell your wife.

469
00:24:53.637 --> 00:24:55.797
>> Yeah, yeah, shh, don't tell my wife.

470
00:24:55.797 --> 00:24:58.020
That'll just be between me,
you, and the Internet.

471
00:24:58.020 --> 00:24:59.145
>> That's right.

472
00:24:59.145 --> 00:25:02.560
>> [LAUGH] So
we need a service there that can help us,

473
00:25:02.560 --> 00:25:06.400
that can make that a little bit easier and
that's where DNS comes into play.

474
00:25:06.400 --> 00:25:08.440
It means,
when I type a name into a search engine,

475
00:25:08.440 --> 00:25:13.380
I type a name into an address field in
a web browser, that in the background,

476
00:25:13.380 --> 00:25:16.940
it goes through the process that
we'll look at here coming up.

477
00:25:16.940 --> 00:25:21.520
And probably in the next episode,
to resolve that name.

478
00:25:21.520 --> 00:25:24.810
>> And connect the two,
to map that name to the IP address so

479
00:25:24.810 --> 00:25:26.790
that the web browser
displays your web site.

480
00:25:26.790 --> 00:25:30.560
And you're none the wiser,
you didn't have to know the IP address.

481
00:25:30.560 --> 00:25:33.980
But before we go ahead and go into
a part three here, let me go ahead,

482
00:25:33.980 --> 00:25:36.650
I tell you what, one last thing
that we'll put in this episode.

483
00:25:36.650 --> 00:25:39.730
Let me show you what a FQDN is, so
you can kind of see what I mean.

484
00:25:39.730 --> 00:25:42.060
Cuz I'm throwing an an acronym
out here at you and

485
00:25:42.060 --> 00:25:43.850
I'm certainly not assuming
that you know what it is.

486
00:25:43.850 --> 00:25:46.150
But let's make some sense out
of the alphabet soup here.

487
00:25:46.150 --> 00:25:47.260
If we look at my machine here,

488
00:25:47.260 --> 00:25:50.940
I've got what's known as a fully
qualified domain name, all right.

489
00:25:50.940 --> 00:25:54.390
What is a fully qualified domain name,
FQDN?

490
00:25:54.390 --> 00:25:56.440
Well we have a host name right.

491
00:25:56.440 --> 00:26:00.080
And in fact, if I switch over to my
machine and I bring up my, well I don't

492
00:26:00.080 --> 00:26:03.648
wanna do a snapshot here, that's what

493
00:26:03.648 --> 00:26:11.180
All right, and I say, I, for
instance, I type host name, right.

494
00:26:11.180 --> 00:26:13.790
I can see that the name is Client01.

495
00:26:14.980 --> 00:26:16.460
All right, but this is a single name.

496
00:26:17.830 --> 00:26:20.410
How many computers out there
across the world do you think

497
00:26:20.410 --> 00:26:21.830
maybe have a name Client01?

498
00:26:23.030 --> 00:26:25.440
There might be a lot, might be hundreds,
might be thousands, I don't know,

499
00:26:25.440 --> 00:26:26.650
could be one for all I know.

500
00:26:26.650 --> 00:26:27.780
This one right here.

501
00:26:27.780 --> 00:26:29.250
But we don't know.

502
00:26:29.250 --> 00:26:32.710
So I can't use this type of name,
this single name.

503
00:26:32.710 --> 00:26:37.165
It's called flat naming space, out there
on the Internet, cuz it's gotta be unique.

504
00:26:37.165 --> 00:26:41.975
So, the hostname alone doesn't represent
a fully qualified domain name, right,

505
00:26:41.975 --> 00:26:43.765
cuz it's not specific enough, right.

506
00:26:43.765 --> 00:26:45.005
It's too vague.

507
00:26:45.005 --> 00:26:51.025
So, hostnames by themselves do us, really
no justice in finding those locations.

508
00:26:51.025 --> 00:26:54.075
It's a combination of that and
the domain name.

509
00:26:54.075 --> 00:26:57.575
In this case, we've seen in Microsoft
it was a connection-specific suffix,

510
00:26:57.575 --> 00:26:59.470
DNS suffix, right.

511
00:26:59.470 --> 00:27:01.360
That's the domain name.

512
00:27:01.360 --> 00:27:06.790
So when we put this two together,
right, we put hostname and

513
00:27:06.790 --> 00:27:11.179
we put the domain name together,
we get what's known as an FQDN.

514
00:27:12.330 --> 00:27:15.640
With the FQDN, that's what DNS is doing.

515
00:27:15.640 --> 00:27:20.680
DNS is saying let's go ahead and
let's take that FQDN, that host name and

516
00:27:20.680 --> 00:27:24.340
domain name, and
we'll map it directly to an IP address.

517
00:27:24.340 --> 00:27:28.245
So now when I type in the web browser,
I type in,

518
00:27:28.245 --> 00:27:33.329
in this case I'm not gonna
type srv01.demo.itpro.tv,

519
00:27:33.329 --> 00:27:36.963
but if I was it would
map into its IP address.

520
00:27:36.963 --> 00:27:39.201
We have other things that
we're gonna talk about,

521
00:27:39.201 --> 00:27:42.427
other kinds of records when it comes
to DNS that makes it a little bit more,

522
00:27:42.427 --> 00:27:46.150
not so hard to remember, because then
that does get complicated as well.

523
00:27:46.150 --> 00:27:48.120
But judging by the time here,

524
00:27:48.120 --> 00:27:52.290
I know Cherokee's off to the side here

So Cherokee, that does look

00:27:55.810 --> 00:27:58.140
we'll probably have to

Yes Wes, thank you for taking the time

00:28:01.820 --> 00:28:03.770

00:28:03.770 --> 00:28:07.480
I do know there's a lot more to

00:28:07.480 --> 00:28:10.370
We're gonna go ahead and

00:28:10.370 --> 00:28:12.310

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes continue with installing and configuring network services DNS, Domain Name System.  Wes explains the purpose and shows the DNS process using a DNS Server and understanding the DNS Hierarchy found on the backbone of the internet.  He demonstrates creating A records and CNAME records to show us how the DNS database stores the records and uses the records for resolution.

WEBVTT

1

and

there are more services out there that

15
00:00:44.250 --> 00:00:46.510

16

If you're just joining us,

17
00:00:47.540 --> 00:00:52.430
go back and watch that episode on DHCP,

18
00:00:52.430 --> 00:00:55.210
And remember,
our IP addresses are important

19
00:00:55.210 --> 00:00:59.045
because it's essentially what we need

20
00:00:59.045 --> 00:01:01.965

21
00:01:01.965 --> 00:01:05.495
when it comes to an IP address,
that we're really talking about, right?

22
00:01:05.495 --> 00:01:09.592
We're talking about into the billions
of possible IP addresses.

23
00:01:09.592 --> 00:01:11.082
And I want you to think.

24
00:01:11.082 --> 00:01:13.812
How do I talk to or find computers,
like, for instance,

25
00:01:13.812 --> 00:01:18.397
websites out there across the Internet,
if I want to visit them, right?

26
00:01:18.397 --> 00:01:20.232
Do I visit them by their IP address?

27
00:01:20.232 --> 00:01:21.002
I want you to think about it.

28
00:01:21.002 --> 00:01:25.437
When's the last time you've typed
into your web browser something like

29
00:01:25.437 --> 00:01:29.342
70.something.something.something just
to get to Google, right?

30
00:01:29.342 --> 00:01:31.142
You don't, what do we use?

31
00:01:31.142 --> 00:01:35.260
Well, we use another very important
service inside of the TCP/IP

32
00:01:35.260 --> 00:01:39.440
protocol stack called DNS,
Domain Name System.

33
00:01:39.440 --> 00:01:43.310
And its sole function, its main goal,

34
00:01:43.310 --> 00:01:47.720
is to take a user-friendly name, something
that we can remember a little bit easier.

35
00:01:47.720 --> 00:01:50.610
And map it to something, well,
that we can't remember, right?

36
00:01:50.610 --> 00:01:52.150
I would say, like my anniversary,

37
00:01:52.150 --> 00:01:55.020
but if my wife's watching that might
get me into trouble there, Ronnie.

38
00:01:55.020 --> 00:01:58.710
But what we're talking about is
mapping to those IP addresses.

39
00:01:58.710 --> 00:02:02.340
Now when we say names, and
we say name resolution, I say mapping.

40
00:02:02.340 --> 00:02:05.910
Keep in mind that term is used
interchangeably, name, resolving the name,

41
00:02:05.910 --> 00:02:09.540
name resolution if you will,
mapping a name to an IP address.

42
00:02:09.540 --> 00:02:12.210
So is it gonna be just any old name?

43
00:02:12.210 --> 00:02:12.960
Well, no.

44
00:02:12.960 --> 00:02:16.866
One of the things that we have to do is we
have to make sure that the name that we

45
00:02:16.866 --> 00:02:19.170
use is unique across the Internet, right?

46
00:02:19.170 --> 00:02:22.000
That's one of the things that we have
these international standards bodies,

47
00:02:22.000 --> 00:02:23.460
rights, things like ICANN, right.

48
00:02:23.460 --> 00:02:26.960
Making sure that IP addresses
are unique across the world,

49
00:02:26.960 --> 00:02:30.630
making things like domain names,
they have to be unique across the world.

50
00:02:30.630 --> 00:02:33.160
So we do have to do that.

51
00:02:33.160 --> 00:02:37.570
So let's talk a little bit about
the name itself, all right.

52
00:02:37.570 --> 00:02:42.190
I actually got a little diagram
here on my computer here.

53
00:02:42.190 --> 00:02:44.450
If we look at what makes up a domain name,

54
00:02:44.450 --> 00:02:47.980
it is something known as a hostname,
all right.

55
00:02:47.980 --> 00:02:50.720
And then the domain name or, excuse me,

56
00:02:50.720 --> 00:02:54.190
the Fully Qualified Domain Name,
let me correct myself, the FQDN.

57
00:02:54.190 --> 00:02:59.280
That's what we use in order to resolve
those names to IP addresses with DNS.

58
00:02:59.280 --> 00:03:01.130
Now it comes with two parts.

59
00:03:01.130 --> 00:03:03.280
It comes with what's known as a hostname,
and

60
00:03:03.280 --> 00:03:05.530
it comes with what's
known as a domain name.

61
00:03:05.530 --> 00:03:09.720
Now the hostname we have to be careful
cuz the hostname by itself isn't

62
00:03:09.720 --> 00:03:10.530
really unique.

63
00:03:10.530 --> 00:03:13.430
You look at the one that I
have as an example here.

64
00:03:13.430 --> 00:03:15.065
And you could see, yes,
it's part of my FQDN.

65
00:03:15.065 --> 00:03:20.160
But by itself, srv01,
that isn't too unique.

66
00:03:20.160 --> 00:03:24.283
If you look at the possibilities of
millions of computers out there over

67
00:03:24.283 --> 00:03:29.522
the Internet, probably somebody else has
thought about naming their computer srv01.

68
00:03:29.522 --> 00:03:34.195
So if I'm in my local network,
my LAN, can I use a hostname?

69
00:03:34.195 --> 00:03:36.750
Well, yeah,
I can use a hostname because for

70
00:03:36.750 --> 00:03:40.780
the most part my hostnames are gonna
be unique within my network.

71
00:03:40.780 --> 00:03:42.380
But they're unique to my network.

72
00:03:42.380 --> 00:03:45.714
If Ronnie's got a network that
he's supporting, let's say,

73
00:03:45.714 --> 00:03:49.804
in Georgia somewhere, right, are my
names gonna be unique to their network?

74
00:03:49.804 --> 00:03:51.700
Maybe, maybe not.

75
00:03:51.700 --> 00:03:54.680
Most likely they won't, especially if you
have a naming convention that's close to

76
00:03:54.680 --> 00:03:56.416
the one I have,
you're gonna have some overlap.

77
00:03:56.416 --> 00:04:01.350
So while the hostname is good for
resolving IP addresses,

78
00:04:01.350 --> 00:04:05.380
finding machines on our local network,
it's not a scalable solution for

79
00:04:05.380 --> 00:04:07.500
the backbone of the World Wide Internet.

80
00:04:07.500 --> 00:04:13.234
So that's why DNS, we use a hierarchical
name system, not just a single name,

81
00:04:13.234 --> 00:04:17.956
but multiple pieces of a name that
collectively make up the FQDN.

82
00:04:17.956 --> 00:04:22.700
And again, that is not only the hostname,
but you can see it is the domain name.

83
00:04:22.700 --> 00:04:24.900
Now, I want you to look
at this structure here.

84
00:04:24.900 --> 00:04:27.590
Because one of the interesting
things is here,

85
00:04:27.590 --> 00:04:29.610
there's something that's
kinda missing in this.

86
00:04:29.610 --> 00:04:38.730
If I was to write this down,
let's say srv01.demo.itpro.tv., all right.

87
00:04:38.730 --> 00:04:40.970
Is that a fully qualified domain name?

88
00:04:40.970 --> 00:04:43.910
You might say, well,
right up looking at it, Wes,

89
00:04:43.910 --> 00:04:48.270
I don't put dots at the end of any time
I type in something like www.google.com.

90
00:04:48.270 --> 00:04:51.740
I don't put a dot after it so
what is that?

91
00:04:51.740 --> 00:04:54.310
Well, that's actually a portion of
the hierarchy that we don't see.

92
00:04:54.310 --> 00:04:56.058
It's kind of transparent
sometimes to the end user and

93
00:04:56.058 --> 00:04:57.388
the end user never gets involved with it.

94
00:04:57.388 --> 00:04:59.557
But the browsers, your operating system,

95
00:04:59.557 --> 00:05:03.830
in fact some systems actually will
put it in there and you'll see it.

96
00:05:03.830 --> 00:05:04.770
They use that.

97
00:05:04.770 --> 00:05:05.300
Why?

98
00:05:05.300 --> 00:05:08.770
Because that's the starting point for
name resolution, right.

99
00:05:08.770 --> 00:05:11.110
Remember we said a hierarchical system?

100
00:05:11.110 --> 00:05:14.590
Well, that dot represents
a part of that hierarchy.

101
00:05:14.590 --> 00:05:17.960
Let's go ahead and
look a little bit about the hierarchy.

102
00:05:17.960 --> 00:05:20.390
So here's the starting point when
it comes to name resolution.

103
00:05:20.390 --> 00:05:23.970
As we look at the hierarchy, I went ahead
and I put the dot up there at the top.

104
00:05:23.970 --> 00:05:25.350
Well, again what is that dot?

105
00:05:25.350 --> 00:05:29.990
That dot represents what's
known as a route hint server.

106
00:05:29.990 --> 00:05:33.680
When we talk about route hint servers,
they represent the top

107
00:05:33.680 --> 00:05:37.640
portion of this hierarchical tree system,
if you will, that we call DNS.

108
00:05:37.640 --> 00:05:42.400
Now what do the route hint servers do for
us, all right?

109
00:05:42.400 --> 00:05:46.420
Well, when I ask a question,
I was gonna say make a query, but

110
00:05:46.420 --> 00:05:49.100
understand that's asking a DNS
server a question, right.

111
00:05:49.100 --> 00:05:52.240
I don't have an IP address,
so what do I do?

112
00:05:52.240 --> 00:05:59.325
Well I ask the DNS server, I say,

Now, that's a simplification, understand.

259
00:13:15.900 --> 00:13:19.180
That's a simplification of what
Network Address Translation is doing.

260
00:13:19.180 --> 00:13:25.190
But it's allowing me to take those private
IP addresses on the internal network and

261
00:13:25.190 --> 00:13:28.520
use them well, and
not maybe that IP address.

262
00:13:28.520 --> 00:13:31.393
But still allow me to communicate
across a public network,

263
00:13:31.393 --> 00:13:33.469
which otherwise I wouldn't be able to do.

264
00:13:33.469 --> 00:13:36.700
Now there are a couple of
different types of NAT, right?

265
00:13:38.120 --> 00:13:41.820
We have what is known as Static NAT,
Network Address Translation.

266
00:13:41.820 --> 00:13:45.540
We also have what's known as
Dynamic Network Address Translation.

267
00:13:45.540 --> 00:13:49.080
Let's go ahead and we'll start out with, I
guess we'll start out with the Static NAT.

268
00:13:49.080 --> 00:13:52.995
It's a little bit easier for
me to explain at least.

269
00:13:52.995 --> 00:13:55.830
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Static NAT is when I have,

270
00:13:55.830 --> 00:14:00.970
I am a company, and I've got a series
of public IP addresses, right?

271
00:14:00.970 --> 00:14:03.290
I have private IP addresses
that I'm still using on my LAN.

272
00:14:03.290 --> 00:14:06.500
Just because I got more than one public
IP address didn't change the fact that

273
00:14:06.500 --> 00:14:10.110
I've still got internal computers
that are using private IP addresses.

274
00:14:10.110 --> 00:14:15.753
But if I've got a series of computers that
I want to have access to the network and

275
00:14:15.753 --> 00:14:20.585
want them to keep the same public
IP address, that's where we use and

276
00:14:20.585 --> 00:14:23.735
implement something known as
Static Network Address Translation.

277
00:14:23.735 --> 00:14:27.125
Now the process is still kind of
going on the same here, right?

278
00:14:27.125 --> 00:14:31.190
We still have that crafting of the packet,
the removing of a private IP address,

279
00:14:31.190 --> 00:14:34.670
and replacing it with a public IP address.

280
00:14:34.670 --> 00:14:38.970
But the thing here is, with Static NAT,
is it's a one-to-one mapping.

281
00:14:38.970 --> 00:14:42.970
We have a single private IP address,
that is mapped,

282
00:14:42.970 --> 00:14:46.390
or NATed, to a single public IP address.

283
00:14:46.390 --> 00:14:48.100
And they don't change.

284
00:14:48.100 --> 00:14:49.500
Well, that's okay.

285
00:14:49.500 --> 00:14:53.050
In this case, for my example,
you only have three IP addresses and

286
00:14:53.050 --> 00:14:56.100
three public addresses
that you need to use.

287
00:14:56.100 --> 00:14:57.690
That's just fine.

288
00:14:57.690 --> 00:14:59.600
But what happens if you have ten?

289
00:14:59.600 --> 00:15:04.100
Ten computers on the internal network and
you only have three public IP addresses?

290
00:15:04.100 --> 00:15:07.590
You still need all those ten to connect,
maybe periodically, well,

291
00:15:07.590 --> 00:15:08.930
you can't use Static NAT.

292
00:15:08.930 --> 00:15:10.710
And that's where another term comes in and

293
00:15:10.710 --> 00:15:13.480
that's called
Dynamic Network Address Translation.

294
00:15:13.480 --> 00:15:17.260
Now I've used the same exact IP
address as internal and external, but

295
00:15:17.260 --> 00:15:19.300
there's a couple of
situations that can happen.

296
00:15:19.300 --> 00:15:21.690
It's almost like a first come,
first serve type basis.

297
00:15:21.690 --> 00:15:25.300
Notice that we've got one that's mapping
to this IP address at this point.

298
00:15:25.300 --> 00:15:28.350
This one's mapping to this IP address and
then we could switch that up, right?

299
00:15:28.350 --> 00:15:32.120
And they're constantly changing
the public IP address, right?

300
00:15:32.120 --> 00:15:36.640
What public IP address is open at this
time, that's gonna be the one that I use.

301
00:15:36.640 --> 00:15:40.530
Well, that does lend itself to
kind of a problem, it could be.

302
00:15:40.530 --> 00:15:44.257
Because what happens if
this last computer or

303
00:15:44.257 --> 00:15:50.251
device is needing to connect to that or
have that IP address translated.

304
00:15:50.251 --> 00:15:55.089
And what ends up happening is that all of
a sudden another machine comes in here and

305
00:15:55.089 --> 00:15:56.452
beats it to the punch.

306
00:15:56.452 --> 00:16:00.024
Well, what happens to our other device?

307
00:16:00.024 --> 00:16:02.556
Well sorry, you don't connect.

308
00:16:02.556 --> 00:16:07.156
I don't have any more and
it's dynamic and it changed and,

309
00:16:07.156 --> 00:16:10.930
what is it,
first come first served type basis.

310
00:16:10.930 --> 00:16:12.387
That's dynamic NATs, all right?

311
00:16:12.387 --> 00:16:14.551
So static, one to one mapping.

312
00:16:14.551 --> 00:16:18.207
Dynamic map just says that
the private IP addresses that

313
00:16:18.207 --> 00:16:21.410
are using the public IP
addresses could change.

314
00:16:21.410 --> 00:16:22.150
They could rotate,

315
00:16:22.150 --> 00:16:26.789
you could have more than just what
public IP addresses you have.

316
00:16:27.970 --> 00:16:31.194
Now, this is typically what we'll see
inside of the business environment.

317
00:16:31.194 --> 00:16:34.435
What we see in our home environment,
I can almost guarantee you.

318
00:16:34.435 --> 00:16:37.440
That if you guys are watching this,
we know you're connected to the internet.

319
00:16:37.440 --> 00:16:39.520
Or [LAUGH] how else are you watching this?

320
00:16:39.520 --> 00:16:43.910
That if you have one of these home router,
or these home gateway devices,

321
00:16:43.910 --> 00:16:45.430
if you will, home routers.

322
00:16:45.430 --> 00:16:48.720
They're not going to use this static map.

323
00:16:48.720 --> 00:16:49.864
What they're gonna use is,

324
00:16:49.864 --> 00:16:53.230
they're gonna use something known
as port address translation.

325
00:16:53.230 --> 00:16:57.430
And a port address translation's the way
if I only have a single public IP address

326
00:16:57.430 --> 00:16:59.930
how do I let multiple devices use that?

327
00:16:59.930 --> 00:17:04.540
Right, well you could say dynamic net but
I only have a single public IP address.

328
00:17:04.540 --> 00:17:06.401
So one of the ways that they do this.

329
00:17:06.401 --> 00:17:10.079
And again,
this is not really going to be safe for

330
00:17:10.079 --> 00:17:15.590
your corporate environment,
is to do port address translation.

331
00:17:15.590 --> 00:17:18.727
So with port address translation what
we're doing is something slightly

332
00:17:18.727 --> 00:17:19.290
different.

333
00:17:19.290 --> 00:17:23.659
Now I know I said we don't
use this in business.

334
00:17:23.659 --> 00:17:27.596
But it's more so you're using this where
you have more than one IP address.

335
00:17:27.596 --> 00:17:32.820
And you need to do address translation
to one single public IP address.

336
00:17:32.820 --> 00:17:33.892
And that's what this is really doing.

337
00:17:33.892 --> 00:17:36.462
Notice that we still have
those private IP addresses.

338
00:17:36.462 --> 00:17:40.679
Now guys, I chose 192.168.1.anything.

339
00:17:40.679 --> 00:17:43.482
It could be a ten dot,
it could be a 172.16 network,

340
00:17:43.482 --> 00:17:47.230
depends on what your company is using or
what you're using at home.

341
00:17:47.230 --> 00:17:52.303
But what it's looking at, it's keeping
track of now, are ports, the TCP/IP ports.

342
00:17:52.303 --> 00:17:56.212
So when I send information in and
out of my network, right.

343
00:17:56.212 --> 00:17:58.353
It's still mapping the addresses or

344
00:17:58.353 --> 00:18:01.469
address translation when
it comes to the addresses.

345
00:18:01.469 --> 00:18:05.352
But now what it’s doing to keep track
of the information that’s coming in and

346
00:18:05.352 --> 00:18:06.317
out of my network.

347
00:18:06.317 --> 00:18:08.772
Is it's keeping track of these ports here.

348
00:18:08.772 --> 00:18:10.229
That's port address translation.

349
00:18:10.229 --> 00:18:15.088
And again the concept here is when you
have multiple private IP addresses.

350
00:18:15.088 --> 00:18:19.840
And you need to do network address
translation to a single public IP address.

351
00:18:19.840 --> 00:18:22.470
Port Address Translation is
the way that you can do that.

352
00:18:23.480 --> 00:18:27.380
Now, looking at my notes, we got one
more that they call out right here.

353
00:18:27.380 --> 00:18:31.220
And that is something known as, while we
are talking about ports, port forwarding.

354
00:18:31.220 --> 00:18:36.240
Now port forwarding is a technique that
as you [LAUGH] might guess by the name

355
00:18:36.240 --> 00:18:39.040
does rely on looking at those ports.

356
00:18:39.040 --> 00:18:42.710
And making sure that it gets to
a specific location within your network.

357
00:18:42.710 --> 00:18:46.190
So, one of the things that I
use port forwarding for and

358
00:18:46.190 --> 00:18:50.816
maybe you guys do here, maybe you guys
do that are watching us out there.

359
00:18:50.816 --> 00:18:54.924
Is I use port forwarding for instance
when I need to get back into my network.

360
00:18:54.924 --> 00:18:57.336
And I need to use something
like remote desktop.

361
00:18:57.336 --> 00:19:00.089
Well, remote desktop uses port 3389.

362
00:19:00.089 --> 00:19:03.914
And if I wasn't doing port forwarding,
when that traffic went to my home router

363
00:19:03.914 --> 00:19:06.211
across the internet and
went to my home router.

364
00:19:06.211 --> 00:19:09.546
My router would say,
I don't know what you're talking about,

365
00:19:09.546 --> 00:19:11.412
I don't know what you want me to do.

366
00:19:11.412 --> 00:19:15.923
However, if I put a port forwarding
rule in there that says,

367
00:19:15.923 --> 00:19:18.409
take port 3389 in this case.

368
00:19:18.409 --> 00:19:22.964
And I want you to make sure that every
time you see port 3389 come in to this

369
00:19:22.964 --> 00:19:24.613
router from the internet.

370
00:19:24.613 --> 00:19:29.058
I want you to forward all of that traffic,
in this case 3389's RDP traffic.

371
00:19:29.058 --> 00:19:31.977
I want you to forward that
over to a specific computer,

372
00:19:31.977 --> 00:19:34.495
a specific device on your network.

373
00:19:34.495 --> 00:19:37.785
That allows us that when you do
connect with a certain service, and

374
00:19:37.785 --> 00:19:40.310
that's usually what these
ports are related to.

375
00:19:40.310 --> 00:19:41.620
It's a service that they're providing.

376
00:19:41.620 --> 00:19:45.670
In this case, this port is related to
the service remote desktop protocol.

377
00:19:45.670 --> 00:19:47.520
And what it's doing is
the router receives that.

378
00:19:47.520 --> 00:19:48.120
it says, okay.

379
00:19:48.120 --> 00:19:49.520
I see that port there.

380
00:19:49.520 --> 00:19:52.570
Let me look at this rule that I have here,
okay.

381
00:19:52.570 --> 00:19:53.154
I see right there.

382
00:19:53.154 --> 00:19:56.099
It says, take that port 3389.

383
00:19:56.099 --> 00:20:02.100
And I'm gonna go ahead and I'm gonna
send it right on over to 192.168.1.15.

384
00:20:02.100 --> 00:20:04.370
All right, so that's port forwarding.

385
00:20:04.370 --> 00:20:09.650
And again, it's a way to take a specific
type of traffic, based on its TCP/IP port.

386
00:20:09.650 --> 00:20:15.536
And then forward over to a single
endpoint on the inside of your network.

387
00:20:15.536 --> 00:20:19.689
>> All right Wes, well the idea of
actually using all of these different

388
00:20:19.689 --> 00:20:22.777
types of services as well
as the application here.

389
00:20:22.777 --> 00:20:27.560
Is really important to all of networking
today as networks continue to grow, right?

390
00:20:27.560 --> 00:20:29.623
The idea of the way that
the Internet worked,

391
00:20:29.623 --> 00:20:32.128
by shrinking the number of
IP addresses you could get.

392
00:20:32.128 --> 00:20:36.828
Well, NAT was actually a perfect
response to that ability, then.

393
00:20:36.828 --> 00:20:41.973
To allow you to address as many
internal IP addresses as you wanted to.

394
00:20:41.973 --> 00:20:47.200
And attach them to a single or just
a small number of public IP addresses.

395
00:20:47.200 --> 00:20:52.787
We also of course talked about the use
of proxies as well as port-forwarding.

396
00:20:52.787 --> 00:20:56.325
You may see all these concepts in
different networks at different times.

397
00:20:56.325 --> 00:20:59.831
Depending on what you really need and
what you have available to you.

398
00:20:59.831 --> 00:21:02.138
If you only have a single
public IP address to you and

399
00:21:02.138 --> 00:21:04.891
you still need to access
individual machines on the inside.

400
00:21:04.891 --> 00:21:08.380
Remember port-forwarding is probably
gonna be your friend to do so.

401
00:21:08.380 --> 00:21:10.220
But if you do have
multiple machines though,

402
00:21:10.220 --> 00:21:14.170
on the inside [INAUDIBLE] NAT is
probably going to be the way to go.

403
00:21:14.170 --> 00:21:15.660
And without NAT, of course,

404
00:21:15.660 --> 00:21:19.670
you can't translate those private IP
addresses to get out on the Internet.

405
00:21:19.670 --> 00:21:22.586
So that may actually be kind of
an exam-like question that you may end up

406
00:21:22.586 --> 00:21:23.179
finding out.

407
00:21:23.179 --> 00:21:26.098
Which is, which of the following
technologies is necessary for

408
00:21:26.098 --> 00:21:28.158
you to trans, or
to allow for this computer.

409
00:21:28.158 --> 00:21:31.654
Which has a private IP address to
communicate to a computer outside on

410
00:21:31.654 --> 00:21:32.689
the Internet wall.

411
00:21:32.689 --> 00:21:35.468
NAT is probably one of
those technologies as well.

412
00:21:35.468 --> 00:21:38.590
Well that's a great place for us to also
think about ending this episode, and

413
00:21:38.590 --> 00:21:40.530
that's exactly what we are going to do.

414
00:21:40.530 --> 00:21:43.720
So, as we sign-off here,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

415
00:21:43.720 --> 00:21:44.790
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

416
00:21:44.790 --> 00:21:49.107
>> Stay tuned right here for
more CompTIA Network+.

417
00:21:49.107 --> 00:21:54.938
[MUSIC]

418
00:21:54.938 --> 00:22:00.380
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

They describe Frame Relay, Satellite Networking and ISDN.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.593
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.593 --> 00:00:07.326
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.326 --> 00:00:08.429
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.429 --> 00:00:12.169
>> You are watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.169 --> 00:00:15.256
>> Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:15.256 --> 00:00:16.945
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:16.945 --> 00:00:20.530
And today,
you're watching the CompTIA Network+ show.

8
00:00:20.530 --> 00:00:24.460
We're, specifically, gonna be diving in to
the realm of different WAN technologies.

9
00:00:24.460 --> 00:00:28.390
And here to help us to understand that
a bit better is gonna be Mr. Wes Bryan.

10
00:00:28.390 --> 00:00:29.660
Wes, welcome back to the studios.

11
00:00:29.660 --> 00:00:30.970
>> Thanks Ronnie for having me here.

12
00:00:30.970 --> 00:00:31.640
Great to be here.

13
00:00:31.640 --> 00:00:35.180
That's right, we're gonna dive in
to the side of networks that, well,

14
00:00:35.180 --> 00:00:38.620
a lot of times we don't see and
the technologies that we don't see.

15
00:00:38.620 --> 00:00:41.740
It's all in the cloud and
it's all magic, right?

16
00:00:41.740 --> 00:00:44.681
Well no, there are some technologies
there that we have to be aware of and

17
00:00:44.681 --> 00:00:46.430
that's kind of what we're gonna look at.

18
00:00:46.430 --> 00:00:50.318
We've got quite a few different
technologies to discuss, so

19
00:00:50.318 --> 00:00:53.847
what do you say that we go ahead and
we will dive right in?

20
00:00:53.847 --> 00:00:56.640
Now, when we talk about WAN
connectivities, I want you to understand

21
00:00:56.640 --> 00:01:00.440
it's really about our Internet Service
Providers that were talking about here.

22
00:01:00.440 --> 00:01:04.346
What are the technologies that they
implement in order to connect you between

23
00:01:04.346 --> 00:01:05.920
large geographical regions?

24
00:01:05.920 --> 00:01:08.700
And it can be something
as simple as a city,

25
00:01:08.700 --> 00:01:12.270
it could be something as much
as a worldwide Internet.

26
00:01:12.270 --> 00:01:15.220
So we're gonna definitely be looking
at those, and one of the first

27
00:01:15.220 --> 00:01:19.810
technologies they call out is, well,
a fiber optic technology known as SONET.

28
00:01:19.810 --> 00:01:23.490
So let's go ahead and
describe what SONET is, and

29
00:01:23.490 --> 00:01:27.570
even what that acronym means, that's the
Synchronous Optical Networking standard.

30
00:01:27.570 --> 00:01:30.160
Again, it is a fiber optic standard.

31
00:01:30.160 --> 00:01:35.592
It is a synchronized data communication
technology and it has a lot of bandwidth.

32
00:01:35.592 --> 00:01:37.060
That's a potential to
have a lot of bandwidth.

33
00:01:37.060 --> 00:01:40.936
Let's go ahead and look at my screen,
I got a little diagram here, and

34
00:01:40.936 --> 00:01:43.290
you'll see a couple of different terms.

35
00:01:43.290 --> 00:01:48.590
You'll see SONET and you'll also see SDH,
that's the Synchronous Digital Hierarchy.

36
00:01:48.590 --> 00:01:50.040
It really depends on where you are.

37
00:01:50.040 --> 00:01:53.050
If you're here in the states, our American
National Standards Institute, ANSI,

38
00:01:53.050 --> 00:01:56.300
calls it SONET,
Synchronous Optical Network.

39
00:01:56.300 --> 00:02:00.754
If you are in other countries the,
what is it, the ITU-T, the International,

40
00:02:00.754 --> 00:02:06.850
Telecommunications Union and this is their
Telecommunications Standardization Sector.

41
00:02:06.850 --> 00:02:10.210
Thank goodness,
they just abbreviate that with a -T and

42
00:02:10.210 --> 00:02:14.780
they're the ones that call it SDH or
Synchronous Digital Hierarchy.

43
00:02:14.780 --> 00:02:19.300
This is a fiber optic ring technology and
it is a very fast technology.

44
00:02:19.300 --> 00:02:22.695
Couple other pieces that you
wanna be aware of for the exam.

45
00:02:22.695 --> 00:02:27.550
They'd not really gonna ask you to set
this up though is the way we actually

46
00:02:27.550 --> 00:02:32.490
send data onto the ring and
the different types of rings that we have.

47
00:02:32.490 --> 00:02:36.475
Again, this is a hierarchical standard,
it starts more local and

48
00:02:36.475 --> 00:02:38.965
then it works its way to backbone.

49
00:02:38.965 --> 00:02:42.575
SONET rings, the closest to you or
what are known as local rings,

50
00:02:42.575 --> 00:02:44.825
sometimes local collector rings.

51
00:02:44.825 --> 00:02:48.290
And then local collector rings
are aggregated together and

52
00:02:48.290 --> 00:02:51.470
their data is placed on what's
known as a regional collector ring.

53
00:02:51.470 --> 00:02:54.350
And then finally,
what we do is we get back to the highest

54
00:02:54.350 --> 00:02:59.270
portion of the hierarchy, and
those are those backbone collector rings.

55
00:02:59.270 --> 00:03:00.944
And as you can imagine,

56
00:03:00.944 --> 00:03:05.058
they will aggregate multiple
regional collector rings.

57
00:03:05.058 --> 00:03:11.856
Now essentially, these components
that we have here, you'll see an ADM.

58
00:03:11.856 --> 00:03:12.690
Well, what is that?

59
00:03:12.690 --> 00:03:15.060
That's the add-drop multiplexer.

60
00:03:15.060 --> 00:03:19.552
And essentially, what it does is it
multiplexes several lower bandwidth

61
00:03:19.552 --> 00:03:24.530
frequencies into a single signal and
places it onto the collector ring.

62
00:03:24.530 --> 00:03:27.040
They also call out other things too here,

the ballpark cuz you, just like Mike said,

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike discuss installing and terminating various cable types and connectors. They demonstrate terminating UTP with an RJ-45 connector. They describe various copper and fiber connectors. They also look at different copper and fiber cable types.
episodes.title: Cable Types, Connectors and Tools

And then we,

30

32

33

I've already got one of the cables here

34
00:01:34.712 --> 00:01:36.290
So if we can actually take a look here, so

35

a twisted-pair cabling.

36

And we'll talk about the copper

37
00:01:41.260 --> 00:01:45.175

38

39
00:01:48.624 --> 00:01:51.810

40
00:01:51.810 --> 00:01:56.668
And this type of connector is one of

00:01:56.668 --> 00:02:00.117

RJ45 jack.

42
00:02:00.117 --> 00:02:05.334

43
00:02:05.334 --> 00:02:09.950

44
00:02:09.950 --> 00:02:14.170

45
00:02:14.170 --> 00:02:17.120

46

61

And what you do is,

62

And what you end up having is eight

00:03:09.328 --> 00:03:10.899

65
00:03:10.899 --> 00:03:15.480
And then the RJ45 is just
really the square box here.

66
00:03:15.480 --> 00:03:19.860
It really doesn't define what
the wiring is behind it.

67
00:03:19.860 --> 00:03:26.000
It is just really a specification for
this kind of a rectangular box here.

68
00:03:26.000 --> 00:03:27.184
Now that's the RJ45 jack.

69
00:03:27.184 --> 00:03:31.020
Again, it's one of the most
common LAN-based connectors.

70
00:03:31.020 --> 00:03:36.730
It's typically used with something known

71
00:03:36.730 --> 00:03:39.860
Unshielded, in the fact that
when we talk about twisted pair,

72

In fact, you know what,

98
00:04:55.320 --> 00:04:59.860
Now that being said,

00:05:13.436 --> 00:05:18.660
In fact, if I was, let's see if

00:06:03.480 --> 00:06:07.750

00:06:20.080 --> 00:06:22.560

00:06:22.560 --> 00:06:23.946

00:06:23.946 --> 00:06:26.132

00:06:26.132 --> 00:06:32.010

00:06:32.928 --> 00:06:36.700

00:06:38.870 --> 00:06:40.320

00:06:44.283 --> 00:06:46.729

00:06:46.729 --> 00:06:49.295
>> [LAUGH]
>> So technically,

137
00:06:49.295 --> 00:06:54.460

00:06:54.460 --> 00:06:57.450

it's got ten pins here.

139
00:06:57.450 --> 00:07:00.360
But when it comes down to it,
it's the wiring standard

140
00:07:00.360 --> 00:07:03.500

the communication's gonna happen.

141
00:07:03.500 --> 00:07:06.130

00:07:06.130 --> 00:07:07.870

00:07:07.870 --> 00:07:13.170

00:07:13.170 --> 00:07:17.530

145
00:07:17.530 --> 00:07:20.580
As you go up higher speeds in Ethernet,

146
00:07:20.580 --> 00:07:22.940
But basically,
that's what we're dealing with.

00:07:22.940 --> 00:07:27.550
Here in the RJ48C,
it could be wired a little bit different.

148
00:07:27.550 --> 00:07:29.650
You could have one, two, four, five.

149
00:07:29.650 --> 00:07:32.380
Or you could have one, two, seven, eight.

150
00:07:32.380 --> 00:07:37.380
So you can see essentially the standard
is just a little bit different.

151
00:07:37.380 --> 00:07:41.890
However, the little receptacle though

152
00:07:43.360 --> 00:07:45.530

00:08:16.140 --> 00:08:20.760

DB9 connector,

00:08:25.605 --> 00:08:27.910

00:08:37.580 --> 00:08:38.740
In fact you can see one right here.

00:08:38.740 --> 00:08:40.240
Here's a console cable.

would stimulate direct point to point

connections between two computers

00:09:24.920 --> 00:09:27.100
Today, when we're using a DB9,

00:09:27.100 --> 00:09:30.610

181
00:09:30.610 --> 00:09:32.226
We're still using them as console cables,

182
00:09:32.226 --> 00:09:35.560
but a lot of times what they have is
they have an adapter on them too, so

183
00:09:35.560 --> 00:09:39.580

ethernet based ports on your machines.

184
00:09:39.580 --> 00:09:46.480
So that's a little bit about
the DB-9 RS-232 null modem cable.

185
00:09:46.480 --> 00:09:50.340
Let's go ahead and make sure what we
have here, that we mention everything.

186
00:09:50.340 --> 00:09:55.050
Again, remember it's used for
the serial point-to-point connections.

187
00:09:55.050 --> 00:09:56.680
It's a little dated.

00:09:56.680 --> 00:10:01.420

00:10:01.420 --> 00:10:05.990

26

27
00:01:03.948 --> 00:01:07.110

28
00:01:07.110 --> 00:01:10.630
common network topologies
here in this episode.

29
00:01:10.630 --> 00:01:15.020
All right, so let's just start with
a network topology and in general,

30
00:01:15.020 --> 00:01:20.520
regardless of what one you choose or
which one you maybe are working with.

31
00:01:20.520 --> 00:01:25.992
Keep in mind that a network topology, what
it does is, it describes the arrangements

32
00:01:25.992 --> 00:01:30.937
of the nodes on the network and their
relationship if you will to one another.

33
00:01:30.937 --> 00:01:34.136
And we've got a few different types,
in fact, we'll go ahead and

34
00:01:34.136 --> 00:01:37.680
we'll just jump right in and one of
the very first ones that they call out is

35
00:01:37.680 --> 00:01:40.160
something known as the mesh topology.

36
00:01:40.160 --> 00:01:44.630
Now, the mesh topology really is for
redundancy.

37
00:01:44.630 --> 00:01:48.771
When it comes down to it, it's a very
expensive type of network to implement.

38
00:01:48.771 --> 00:01:50.950
And you do see them in
different environments.

39
00:01:50.950 --> 00:01:54.250
In fact, I got a little diagram here
to understand what a mesh network is,

40
00:01:54.250 --> 00:01:55.120
just keep in mind,

41
00:01:55.120 --> 00:02:00.020
that one device has connectivity to
all other devices within the network.

42
00:02:00.020 --> 00:02:04.730
So for instance, in things like routing
topologies, in the WAN links outside

43
00:02:04.730 --> 00:02:09.068
of your network, your ISPs,
they try to implement redundancy, right?

44
00:02:09.068 --> 00:02:13.668
So that if one router goes down and
we still have access to another router.

45
00:02:13.668 --> 00:02:18.551
Keep in mind that with a mesh network and
those redundant connections, every device

46
00:02:18.551 --> 00:02:24.080
being connected to every other device,
it's a very expensive implementation.

47
00:02:24.080 --> 00:02:29.270
The other thing to keep in mind is that,
as you add a single device,

48
00:02:29.270 --> 00:02:34.600
your connection start to get very,
very exponentially larger.

49
00:02:34.600 --> 00:02:39.120
Hence, why this is a very
expensive implementation.

50
00:02:39.120 --> 00:02:41.300
It does give you the benefit
of redundancy though.

51
00:02:41.300 --> 00:02:46.530
Multiple paths to send the information
in case one device does go offline.

52
00:02:46.530 --> 00:02:49.920
Now you also have a form of wireless
mesh-type networks as well like for

53
00:02:49.920 --> 00:02:51.429
instance an Ad-hoc.

54
00:02:51.429 --> 00:02:56.770
Ad-hoc mode, this basically means you got
like an independent basic service set.

55
00:02:56.770 --> 00:03:01.910
There's no access point, and each network
adapter can communicate with every

56
00:03:01.910 --> 00:03:06.739
other node within this
wireless mesh network.

57
00:03:08.120 --> 00:03:11.200
They also call out additional
things too like the partial mesh.

58
00:03:11.200 --> 00:03:14.130
And, this also happens,
especially for instance,

59
00:03:14.130 --> 00:03:19.140
when you talk about things like your
core backbone routers where it's almost

60
00:03:19.140 --> 00:03:21.650
a full mesh, maybe just not quite, right?

61
00:03:21.650 --> 00:03:25.750
We still do have some limited redundancy,
a certain amount of redundancy, but

62
00:03:25.750 --> 00:03:27.350
it's not fully redundant.

63
00:03:27.350 --> 00:03:31.930
Meaning the fact that, each device, you're
gonna come to one device that doesn't have

64
00:03:31.930 --> 00:03:34.569
connections to every other
device in the network.

65
00:03:34.569 --> 00:03:39.028
You can see this in stub based network
where it's really just one route in

66
00:03:39.028 --> 00:03:42.316
the network and
one route out of the network and then,

67
00:03:42.316 --> 00:03:47.380
connects back to the rest of the mesh,
hence, the name partial mesh, all right.

68
00:03:47.380 --> 00:03:50.070
So, we've got another one here,
and this is one that,

69
00:03:50.070 --> 00:03:54.040
the next one here is an oldie but goodie,
and that's called the bus that networks.

70
00:03:54.040 --> 00:03:57.160
Now, as far as networking communications,

71
00:03:57.160 --> 00:04:02.220
you don't really see these bus-based
networks much anymore if at all.

72
00:04:02.220 --> 00:04:04.510
And that's because they're
not very scalable, right?

73
00:04:04.510 --> 00:04:08.463
These are the ones that we talked about
in an earlier episode that are using

74
00:04:08.463 --> 00:04:10.393
contention-based media access.

75
00:04:10.393 --> 00:04:14.888
And with the contention-based media access
that means everybody's striving for

76
00:04:14.888 --> 00:04:17.120
the communication on the wire.

77
00:04:17.120 --> 00:04:19.700
That means,
if one device sends communication

78
00:04:19.700 --> 00:04:22.490
everybody else will receive it.

79
00:04:22.490 --> 00:04:23.910
Everybody else will hear it.

80
00:04:23.910 --> 00:04:26.120
It just means that,
whatever the destination is,

81
00:04:26.120 --> 00:04:28.510
is the only one that actually
processes the information.

82
00:04:28.510 --> 00:04:33.740
So, bus networks, not very expandable or
scalable, if you will.

83
00:04:33.740 --> 00:04:38.040
Cuz keep in mind,
that if I add a couple of devices

84
00:04:38.040 --> 00:04:41.910
to this centralized backbone cable,
well, what am I doing?

85
00:04:41.910 --> 00:04:43.480
I'm increasing the contention, right?

86
00:04:43.480 --> 00:04:46.670
If every device hears every
other device and I add more,

87
00:04:46.670 --> 00:04:49.750
it's like adding more people
to the conference line.

88
00:04:49.750 --> 00:04:54.040
Eventually, you have a mess of
communication, if you will.

89
00:04:54.040 --> 00:04:57.148
The other thing, too,
about this type of network is,

90
00:04:57.148 --> 00:05:01.270
when we talk about things like
the redundancy, if one of these devices,

91
00:05:01.270 --> 00:05:04.194
let's say, I don't know,
let's pick one here.

92
00:05:04.194 --> 00:05:07.430
Maybe one of these devices goes offline,
right?

93
00:05:07.430 --> 00:05:12.150
Well, if this device goes offline,
what happens to the rest of the network?

94
00:05:12.150 --> 00:05:14.486
Well, it's a bust communication.

95
00:05:14.486 --> 00:05:18.558
And unfortunately, what ends up happening
is that, even though it's only one

96
00:05:18.558 --> 00:05:22.451
computer that's going offline,
we essentially lose communication on all

97
00:05:22.451 --> 00:05:27.160
the other devices, so, you could kind
of see the limitation to it, right?

98
00:05:27.160 --> 00:05:33.360
It's not scalable, one device fails and
we lose all communication.

99
00:05:33.360 --> 00:05:36.160
So bus networks really
are a thing of the past.

100
00:05:36.160 --> 00:05:39.470
Now buses in general,
I want you to be careful because we still

101
00:05:39.470 --> 00:05:42.690
use bus-based technology but today,
it's a little bit different.

102
00:05:42.690 --> 00:05:45.050
Like for instance,
we use serial bus interfaces.

103
00:05:45.050 --> 00:05:48.360
USB is a classic example of
a serial bus that we use.

104
00:05:48.360 --> 00:05:53.410
One host device controlling up
to 127 other devices, right?

105
00:05:53.410 --> 00:05:54.932
That's a bus type network.

106
00:05:54.932 --> 00:05:57.990
FireWire, FireWire has been around for
a long time.

107
00:05:57.990 --> 00:05:59.460
That's a serial bus interface.

108
00:05:59.460 --> 00:06:03.320
So, even though we're not using it
as a network communication per se,

109
00:06:03.320 --> 00:06:06.060
where we hook our network
adapters up to it,

110
00:06:06.060 --> 00:06:10.620
you see still bus technologies
inside of your communications today,

111
00:06:10.620 --> 00:06:13.250
just a little bit different than
what they were in the old days.

112
00:06:14.560 --> 00:06:15.860
All right, what else do we have?

113
00:06:15.860 --> 00:06:17.570
Well, we've got some of
the other ones here.

114
00:06:17.570 --> 00:06:19.360
Ring networks, right?

115
00:06:19.360 --> 00:06:22.950
Ring networks, these are well it depends,

116
00:06:22.950 --> 00:06:27.470
some of them we don't use anymore, some
of them are still used fairly heavily.

117
00:06:27.470 --> 00:06:29.781
So let's go ahead and
let's talk about a ring network, right?

118
00:06:29.781 --> 00:06:34.220
With a ring network, you typically have
upstream and downstream neighbors.

119
00:06:34.220 --> 00:06:37.080
So for instance if we're
focus on this computer here,

120
00:06:37.080 --> 00:06:40.078
we have a downstream neighbor and
an upstream neighbor.

121
00:06:40.078 --> 00:06:42.850
And what does that really mean,
we say downstream and upstream.

122
00:06:42.850 --> 00:06:48.185
Well, in the early ring-based networks,
these are unlike our bus networks.

123
00:06:48.185 --> 00:06:51.075
These are what are known
as deterministic media.

124
00:06:51.075 --> 00:06:55.177
In deterministic media, unlike the
contention based media that we mentioned,

00:28:23.460 --> 00:28:27.030

00:28:36.180 --> 00:28:40.930

00:28:40.930 --> 00:28:42.440

00:28:42.440 --> 00:28:46.850

00:28:46.850 --> 00:28:51.120

00:28:53.570 --> 00:28:56.570

00:28:56.570 --> 00:29:04.100

00:29:04.100 --> 00:29:06.220

00:29:06.220 --> 00:29:10.820

00:29:10.820 --> 00:29:14.620

00:29:14.620 --> 00:29:19.620

00:29:19.620 --> 00:29:20.460

00:29:20.460 --> 00:29:24.610

524
00:29:24.610 --> 00:29:26.000

525
00:29:26.000 --> 00:29:27.650
So since everybody hears it,

00:29:27.650 --> 00:29:33.710

528
00:29:36.350 --> 00:29:38.820

00:29:45.750 --> 00:29:48.190

531
00:29:48.190 --> 00:29:51.660

I don't have to call out,

00:30:04.290 --> 00:30:07.380
In fact, we all have multicast addresses.

537
00:30:07.380 --> 00:30:09.360

538

around and we could send the information

540
00:30:18.310 --> 00:30:23.290
So keep in mind, you have what

541
00:30:23.290 --> 00:30:27.580

00:30:27.580 --> 00:30:31.020

543
00:30:31.020 --> 00:30:34.600
What we have that's akin to a private IP

00:30:34.600 --> 00:30:38.080
These are called unique local addresses,
ULAs.

00:30:38.080 --> 00:30:40.930

These are akin, if you will,

547
00:30:44.650 --> 00:30:49.020
The link-local address however,

In IPv4, we have one address that we

And that's that one reserved

553

554
00:31:13.840 --> 00:31:19.783
Rather than not have any IP address,

00:31:19.783 --> 00:31:23.100
anything.anything, the last two

556
00:31:23.100 --> 00:31:26.030
And I can at least maintain
a communication with

00:31:26.030 --> 00:31:27.616

All right guess what here inside of

00:31:35.020 --> 00:31:36.700
We use a link local.

I don't have to talk to a DHCP server

00:31:41.060 --> 00:31:43.903
making it ideal for local communications.

562

00:31:49.411 --> 00:31:52.491
Well, yeah, but for

00:31:52.491 --> 00:31:54.702

your network.

00:31:58.092 --> 00:31:59.640
That wouldn't be fun.

569

>> [LAUGH]
>> And that's what brings us into

stateless configuration.

See, one of the great things about
IPv6 is that your network adapters,

572
00:32:11.290 --> 00:32:14.460

they can generate,

well the operating system's

In fact,
I've got a little diagram here and

Well wouldn't it be nice since we know

Well guess what?

If we can take that address and

00:32:55.920 --> 00:32:58.450
interface portion of

We now have unique
network interfaces across

OSPF says, let's go ahead and

511
00:26:18.830 --> 00:26:21.580
let's talk to every router on
the entirety of the network.

512
00:26:21.580 --> 00:26:24.480
And instead of telling them
the entire routing table,

513
00:26:24.480 --> 00:26:27.500
which they don't need to know,
I'll just tell you that one link.

514
00:26:27.500 --> 00:26:31.970
So the convergence, Cherokee was
mentioning happens a lot quicker.

515
00:26:31.970 --> 00:26:34.730
And that's one of the things
that's beneficial about OSPF.

516
00:26:34.730 --> 00:26:39.960
Not only the ability to make
decisions not just based on distance,

517
00:26:39.960 --> 00:26:43.210
but a lot of other characteristics and
quality of the link.

518
00:26:43.210 --> 00:26:46.080
I do wanna mention one other one there.

519
00:26:46.080 --> 00:26:48.960
Let say, I don't believe
it's used quite as much, and

520
00:26:48.960 --> 00:26:52.680
that's intermediate system
to intermediate system, IS.

521
00:26:52.680 --> 00:26:57.410
It's another link state routing protocol
as well know it for the exam however,

522
00:26:57.410 --> 00:27:00.170
OSPF is gonna be one
that's more important.

523
00:27:00.170 --> 00:27:02.506
Now Cherokee, that's really just
[LAUGH] kinda scratching the surface,

524
00:27:02.506 --> 00:27:03.456
I'm looking on a list I know.

525
00:27:03.456 --> 00:27:05.543
>> We've got a lot more to go but
judging by the time,

526
00:27:05.543 --> 00:27:07.304
I think we might have to say that, right.

527
00:27:07.304 --> 00:27:09.327
>> That's all right.
We'll go ahead and save it for

528
00:27:09.327 --> 00:27:13.236
he next episode because in this show
we were able to look at the differences

529
00:27:13.236 --> 00:27:15.900
between you showed us static and
dynamic routes.

530
00:27:15.900 --> 00:27:19.330
And then we also looked at the differences
between writing protocols and

531
00:27:19.330 --> 00:27:22.580
learned the difference
between a distance vector

532
00:27:22.580 --> 00:27:25.890
versus a link state routing protocol,
so thank you for that.

533
00:27:25.890 --> 00:27:28.870
But stay tuned, there's a lot more
associated with routing in these

534
00:27:28.870 --> 00:27:30.750
protocols that you need to take a look at.

535
00:27:30.750 --> 00:27:33.110
So we're gonna go ahead and
wrap up for this show.

536
00:27:33.110 --> 00:27:35.200
Remember, I'm your show
host Cherokee Boose.

537
00:27:35.200 --> 00:27:36.140
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

538

>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

539

WEBVTT

1

6

This show is actually a continuation where
we were looking at routing protocols and

7

routing concepts and protocol basics.

8
00:00:24.789 --> 00:00:27.611
We were able to get through some but

And with us today, in studio is
Mister Wes Bryan, thank you for

>> Absolutely, Cherokee,
thank you for having me here.

13
00:00:35.440 --> 00:00:37.960
That's right, we're gonna go back into

14
00:00:37.960 --> 00:00:39.730
like Cherokee said.

15
00:00:39.730 --> 00:00:43.290
We're really looking at some of these
routing concepts we want you to know and

00:00:43.290 --> 00:00:44.850
be prepared for the Net Plus Exam.

17
00:00:44.850 --> 00:00:48.790
However, keep in mind that as you go
on to more advanced certifications, as

18
00:00:48.790 --> 00:00:52.991
you go into the Cisco world, you can get
