19
00:00:52.991 --> 00:00:56.530
So, let's go ahead, and
let's dive right in.

20
00:00:56.530 --> 00:00:59.450
One of the first things that we've
gotta kind of talk about is something

21
00:00:59.450 --> 00:01:01.640
known as the loop back interface.

22
00:01:01.640 --> 00:01:05.440
We didn't really talk about that in the
first part, so we're gonna start there.

23
00:01:05.440 --> 00:01:09.740
With the loop back interface,
we actually have in IPv4 and

24
00:01:09.740 --> 00:01:14.670
IPv6, we've got a couple of networks
that are actually reserved by IANA,

25
00:01:14.670 --> 00:01:17.460
and they're reserved for testing software.

26
00:01:17.460 --> 00:01:21.590
One of the things that we can
do is use our ping utility.

27
00:01:21.590 --> 00:01:24.610
The packet internet groper
I think is what that,

28
00:01:24.610 --> 00:01:26.630
I don't know why the hell they
come up with these names.

29
00:01:26.630 --> 00:01:32.270
But ping utility, we can use in order to
test whether the software in our system,

30
00:01:32.270 --> 00:01:37.300
understands the TCP/IP protocol stack, and
more importantly, that we can communicate.

31
00:01:37.300 --> 00:01:41.140
So, in fact,
let me show you on my computer here.

32
00:01:41.140 --> 00:01:44.000
We can go ahead and pull up on terminal,
I'm on a Mac here too, so

33
00:01:44.000 --> 00:01:46.530
it's just BSD under the hood.

34
00:01:46.530 --> 00:01:51.737
And if I decide that I wanna test
whether my operating system understand

35
00:01:51.737 --> 00:01:56.248
the protocol stack,
well then we use the loop back address and

36
00:01:56.248 --> 00:01:59.133
usually we ping 127.0.0.1.

37
00:01:59.133 --> 00:02:02.521
Now, I got to tell you, if I turn around,
I can ping other numbers here,

38
00:02:02.521 --> 00:02:05.980
because really the whole network is
reserved for a loopback processing.

39
00:02:05.980 --> 00:02:09.244
But traditionally, we use the very
first address within that network and

40
00:02:09.244 --> 00:02:10.673
it starts with the one, right.

41
00:02:10.673 --> 00:02:14.874
Remember, as we go into showing
you how networks are structured,

42
00:02:14.874 --> 00:02:18.936
the very first address in any
network is usually the network ID.

43
00:02:18.936 --> 00:02:23.681
So, we can't use 127.0.0.0 right,
that's the network ID so

44
00:02:23.681 --> 00:02:26.440
the very first addressable.

45
00:02:26.440 --> 00:02:30.289
Address, if you will,
within that range will be 127.0.0.1.

46
00:02:30.289 --> 00:02:34.456
So, if I run this, one of the things that
you're gonna notice here is that I'm

47
00:02:34.456 --> 00:02:38.640
sending out a little bit of information,
and I'm getting some replies back.

48
00:02:38.640 --> 00:02:40.150
That's what we typically see in ping.

49
00:02:40.150 --> 00:02:43.550
And, we'll talk about this utility
coming up in a later episode.

50
00:02:43.550 --> 00:02:47.810
But, what's interesting here is this ping
utility when I'm pinging the loop back

51
00:02:47.810 --> 00:02:52.810
address, it isn't sending any electrical
communications out my network adapter on

52
00:02:52.810 --> 00:02:56.420
to the network, and then out to somebody
that has an IP Address of 127.0.0.1.

53
00:02:56.420 --> 00:03:00.904
See, the reason they call it the loop
back address is because as we'll

54
00:03:00.904 --> 00:03:05.014
talk about in other episodes we
have that seven layer OSI model.

55
00:03:05.014 --> 00:03:09.277
And what's happening here is it is working
its way down to the network layer, and

56
00:03:09.277 --> 00:03:12.550
it's looping itself right back
up to the application layer.

57
00:03:12.550 --> 00:03:15.800
So, it doesn't make it
down to the link layer,

58
00:03:15.800 --> 00:03:18.570
whereas that's typically where the link
and the physical layer where we

59
00:03:18.570 --> 00:03:21.130
start to see those electrical
impulses placed on the media.

60
00:03:21.130 --> 00:03:24.260
So, that's why they call
it the loop back address,

61
00:03:24.260 --> 00:03:27.780
because if I wanna just test my operating
system can't my operating system

62
00:03:27.780 --> 00:03:31.460
speak the protocols that we need in
order to communicate on the network,

63
00:03:31.460 --> 00:03:35.280
the very first thing I can do
is test the loop back interface.

64
00:03:35.280 --> 00:03:39.930
So, again loop back interface is great for
testing your software.

65
00:03:39.930 --> 00:03:42.383
Let me see if I can show you this guys.

66
00:03:42.383 --> 00:03:44.410
And what it's interesting here,

67
00:03:44.410 --> 00:03:49.290
it does kind of yeah I guess in BSD, it
doesn't allow you to ping anything else.

68
00:03:49.290 --> 00:03:53.053
In Windows though it will let you ping
just about any address within that range.

69
00:03:53.053 --> 00:03:56.617
>> And it's kinda nice because you can
really isolate network problems by trying

70
00:03:56.617 --> 00:04:00.181
to make sure there's something wrong
with your local machine before you start

71
00:04:00.181 --> 00:04:03.450
checking out other pieces of
equipment further down that route.

72
00:04:03.450 --> 00:04:04.330
>> That's exactly right,

73
00:04:04.330 --> 00:04:07.610
in fact when I wanna test, if I don't have
communications, let's say on this machine,

74
00:04:07.610 --> 00:04:09.830
the first thing I do is test the software.

75
00:04:09.830 --> 00:04:11.430
I need to know does the operating system,

76
00:04:11.430 --> 00:04:14.560
does it know how to speak the language
of the network, before I go any further.

77
00:04:14.560 --> 00:04:18.880
So absolutely, and you'll see that as
we get into some of our troubleshooting

78
00:04:18.880 --> 00:04:21.560
sections where we're gonna use ping,
and we'll show you,

79
00:04:21.560 --> 00:04:24.680
just like Cherokee mentioned how you
ping as local as you can get, and

80
00:04:24.680 --> 00:04:26.440
then you start working your
way out to your network.

81
00:04:26.440 --> 00:04:29.440
Edge of your network, to figure out
where's the communication breakdown.

82
00:04:29.440 --> 00:04:32.492
Now, speaking of communication breakdown
[LAUGH] that actually takes us right

83
00:04:32.492 --> 00:04:33.564
into our next topic there.

84
00:04:33.564 --> 00:04:36.250
And that's something
known as routing loops.

85
00:04:36.250 --> 00:04:38.150
Now, when they talk about
routing loops here,

86
00:04:38.150 --> 00:04:40.900
we're actually talking
about a layer-three loop.

87
00:04:40.900 --> 00:04:43.179
And what I mean by that is, remember,

88
00:04:43.179 --> 00:04:47.190
we talked about routers operating
at the OSI layer three, right.

89
00:04:47.190 --> 00:04:50.370
That's where routing happens that's
where our IP address happened.

90
00:04:50.370 --> 00:04:54.110
I do wanna just briefly mention that
routing loops don't just happen

91
00:04:54.110 --> 00:04:56.680
at the layer three and in routers.

92
00:04:56.680 --> 00:05:00.360
You also have switching loops too,
and then switching loops are where we

93
00:05:00.360 --> 00:05:04.470
implement things like the spanning
tree algorithm in order to break them.

94
00:05:04.470 --> 00:05:10.310
But, essentially what a loop is, is when
you have incorrect information in one,

95
00:05:10.310 --> 00:05:12.278
two, or more of your routers.

96
00:05:12.278 --> 00:05:16.350
And they kinda get, they can't really
agree on where to send the information.

97
00:05:16.350 --> 00:05:17.910
So, let me show you what I mean here.

98
00:05:17.910 --> 00:05:21.110
If we talk very basically that
this machine right here, for

99
00:05:21.110 --> 00:05:22.900
instance router one, right.

100
00:05:22.900 --> 00:05:27.040
Notice that it is connected
to router three, okay.

101
00:05:27.040 --> 00:05:29.390
So, router three is gonna be our
bag guy here in a second, but

102
00:05:29.390 --> 00:05:31.760
let's see what the routing
table looks like.

103
00:05:31.760 --> 00:05:35.600
Now, router one knows that it has
a direct link to router three.

104
00:05:35.600 --> 00:05:39.670
So, if it needs to get information into a
network that router three is attached to,

105
00:05:39.670 --> 00:05:42.510
you could send that information
right to router three.

106
00:05:42.510 --> 00:05:46.370
But it also knows, through talking
to router two, router two said,

107
00:05:46.370 --> 00:05:47.900
hey router one, guess what?

108
00:05:47.900 --> 00:05:49.890
I know where router three is, and

109
00:05:49.890 --> 00:05:54.520
if you ever need to get to router three,
just send that information to me.

110
00:05:54.520 --> 00:05:55.900
Now, I wanna show you something here too.

111
00:05:55.900 --> 00:05:57.070
Router two, and

112
00:05:57.070 --> 00:06:01.490
remember, keep in mind what router three's
gonna be our bad guy here in a second.

113
00:06:01.490 --> 00:06:03.665
Notice that router two also says,

114
00:06:03.665 --> 00:06:06.385
I got a direct connection down
here to router three as well.

115
00:06:06.385 --> 00:06:10.794
And I've also talked over to RTR-1,
and RTR-1 let me know, hey,

116
00:06:10.794 --> 00:06:16.080
if need RTR-2 needs to get to RTR-3,
just send that information my way.

117
00:06:16.080 --> 00:06:21.150
Alright, so here we're gonna do,
we're gonna make RTR-3 our bad guy here.

118
00:06:21.150 --> 00:06:25.126
So, when we do this what's going to happen
is we're just going to simulate a failure,

119
00:06:25.126 --> 00:06:27.010
alright, it goes offline.

120
00:06:27.010 --> 00:06:29.553
Now, I want you to think about
the routing table, all right.

121
00:06:29.553 --> 00:06:33.199
These guys know Let's say for
instance RTR-1 here it

122
00:06:33.199 --> 00:06:38.121
knows that hey I just tried to send
information to RTR-3, and I can't.

123
00:06:38.121 --> 00:06:40.920
I can't send information, RTR-3's offline.

124
00:06:40.920 --> 00:06:42.170
So, what does it do?

125
00:06:42.170 --> 00:06:44.925
It says let me go ahead and
check my routing table here.

126
00:06:44.925 --> 00:06:46.785
And I know I've got this entry.

127
00:06:46.785 --> 00:06:49.745
Since this direct route doesn't work,

128
00:06:49.745 --> 00:06:52.885
I know I got a route that
I can send this router to.

129
00:06:52.885 --> 00:06:54.415
>> An alternative.
>> That's right.

130
00:06:54.415 --> 00:06:57.045
I've got an alternative option here.

131
00:06:57.045 --> 00:06:59.360
So, we send that traffic to RTR-2,
all right.

132
00:06:59.360 --> 00:07:01.970
Well RTR-2 says, let me go ahead.

133
00:07:01.970 --> 00:07:05.460
I know that I can send
this directly to RTR-3.

134
00:07:05.460 --> 00:07:07.570
But, RTR-3 is offline.

135
00:07:07.570 --> 00:07:09.062
So, now what are gonna do?

136
00:07:09.062 --> 00:07:13.830
Well, RTR-2 is gonna look at its routing
table and say, okay I know what to here.

137
00:07:13.830 --> 00:07:16.648
I got an entry in my routing table
that say, hey if you need to send.

138
00:07:16.648 --> 00:07:21.440
It to RTR-3, and I can't get there
directly, I'll just send it to RTR-1.

139
00:07:21.440 --> 00:07:22.200
So, what happens?

140
00:07:23.410 --> 00:07:24.693
It sends it back to RTR-1.

141
00:07:24.693 --> 00:07:27.050
And then RTR-1 says, okay,

142
00:07:27.050 --> 00:07:31.400
well, I know I have a direct link that's
fails, let me check my routing table.

143
00:07:31.400 --> 00:07:36.808
Okay I see, I send it to RTR-2 and now you
can start to see what's happening here.

144
00:07:36.808 --> 00:07:42.070
Notice that RTR-2 is receiving the packet
and the process just keeps going and

145
00:07:42.070 --> 00:07:45.910
going and eventually the packet times out.

146
00:07:45.910 --> 00:07:48.180
The time to live expires and it discards.

147
00:07:48.180 --> 00:07:52.399
So, keep in mind that a routing loop,
there's a couple of different technologies

148
00:07:52.399 --> 00:07:54.827
that we use to implement,
or not to implement.

149
00:07:54.827 --> 00:07:56.197
You never want to
implement a routing loop.

150
00:07:56.197 --> 00:07:58.303
You need to check your routing
infrastructure if that's what you're

151
00:07:58.303 --> 00:07:58.915
gonna set out to do.

152
00:07:58.915 --> 00:08:00.160
But, if you want to.

153
00:08:00.160 --> 00:08:01.561
Stop routing loops.

154
00:08:01.561 --> 00:08:03.950
There's a couple of different
technologies you can do.

155
00:08:03.950 --> 00:08:08.410
And these will,
the goal is to stop this in its tracks.

156
00:08:08.410 --> 00:08:10.280
One is called Split Horizons.

157
00:08:10.280 --> 00:08:12.040
The other one is called Poison Reverse.

158
00:08:12.040 --> 00:08:15.400
So for instance, if I send that
information to router two, and

159
00:08:15.400 --> 00:08:19.880
router two knows, hey, I can't get to
router three, it's gonna tell router one,

160
00:08:19.880 --> 00:08:23.610
don't send me anymore information,
cuz I can't get to router three.

161
00:08:23.610 --> 00:08:27.740
And that essentially is going to
eliminate some of these bogus or

162
00:08:27.740 --> 00:08:29.520
invalid entries in the routing table.

163
00:08:29.520 --> 00:08:33.930
Now they'd be valid, right,
if router 3 was online.

164
00:08:33.930 --> 00:08:38.061
And then if you're using something like
OSPF, eventually if this router comes back

165
00:08:38.061 --> 00:08:40.852
online then what we end up
getting is our links restored,

166
00:08:40.852 --> 00:08:44.060
routing tables are rebuilt and
then we're good again.

167
00:08:44.060 --> 00:08:45.090
That doesn't always happen and

168
00:08:45.090 --> 00:08:48.099
that's why you wanna know those
couple different technologies.

169
00:08:49.800 --> 00:08:53.780
All right, so that takes us to,
that gets our routing loops.

170
00:08:53.780 --> 00:08:57.646
Now the other thing I wanna talk about
is something known as a default route,

171
00:08:57.646 --> 00:08:58.498
all right?

172
00:08:58.498 --> 00:09:01.202
Sometimes you might hear this address,

173
00:09:01.202 --> 00:09:04.468
it's reserved in our IP Address range,
right?

174
00:09:04.468 --> 00:09:09.416
It's 0.0.0.0, or four blocks of zeroes,
or no, eight blocks of zeroes

175
00:09:09.416 --> 00:09:14.980
separated by colons, if you happen to
be talking about IPv6 versus IPv4.

176
00:09:14.980 --> 00:09:19.790
Now if I want, let's say,
a series of routers

177
00:09:19.790 --> 00:09:24.850
I don't want them knowing about all the
different routes right behind router one.

178
00:09:24.850 --> 00:09:29.030
I don't need to over saturate
their routing tables, right?

179
00:09:29.030 --> 00:09:33.840
I just need these routers within this
network to just talk to each other, right?

180
00:09:33.840 --> 00:09:38.420
And if they don't know where to send
the information, I want them to send it to

181
00:09:38.420 --> 00:09:42.630
router 1 and then router 1 can get it
to the infrastructure that it needs to.

182
00:09:42.630 --> 00:09:46.820
So what we do is we implement
what's known as a Default Route.

183
00:09:46.820 --> 00:09:51.290
And the Default Route basically tells
these routers, if you can't find it within

184
00:09:51.290 --> 00:09:55.566
your routing table, which typically
are gonna be all the routes between these

185
00:09:55.566 --> 00:09:58.998
routers confined to this area,
just send it to this address and

186
00:09:58.998 --> 00:10:02.155
what's gonna happen is they'll
send that to router 1.

187
00:10:02.155 --> 00:10:04.765
Now what we have back here,
you can't tell,

188
00:10:04.765 --> 00:10:07.930
is the fact that we've got
a major topology back here.

189
00:10:07.930 --> 00:10:10.079
Yeah, router 1 can get
to all these routes.

190

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes dive into the exciting world of network monitoring tools. They start by looking at the function and purpose of Packet Analyzers aka Packet Sniffers. Then they move onto exploring Interface Monitoring tools like Solar Winds and Netstat. Well, at that point,

338
00:19:07.160 --> 00:19:09.920
that means that you have to understand
a little bit about routing.

339
00:19:09.920 --> 00:19:14.296
For every device that is going to try and
connect in from another network.

340
00:19:14.296 --> 00:19:18.673
That means it can connect in to this
switch and needs to know the IP address.

341
00:19:18.673 --> 00:19:20.824
Which means it's going to be
on a different network from

342
00:19:20.824 --> 00:19:22.340

343
00:19:22.340 --> 00:19:25.661
And then, when it actually gets the
information over here, that connection.

344
00:19:25.661 --> 00:19:30.710
What we also have to have is a pathway
to get it back to where I'm going.

345
00:19:30.710 --> 00:19:34.050
So how do I do that,
how do I make the switch do that?

346
00:19:34.050 --> 00:19:37.355
Where it says hey,
I need to reply to this other computer.

347
00:19:37.355 --> 00:19:41.060
Which is on, let's say, 172.16.10.120.

348
00:19:41.060 --> 00:19:45.392
Well, If any other device on

349
00:19:45.392 --> 00:19:47.932

is take a look at the computer and

00:19:47.932 --> 00:19:49.920
go, it doesn't belong to this network.

351
00:19:49.920 --> 00:19:51.200
It sends it out where, Wes?

352
00:19:51.200 --> 00:19:52.480
>> I was thinking the default gateway?

353
00:19:52.480 --> 00:19:53.800
>> It sends it out the default gateway.

354
00:19:53.800 --> 00:19:56.670
And so that's the same thing here is
that we need to set a default gateway

00:19:56.670 --> 00:19:57.960
on this switch.

356
00:19:57.960 --> 00:20:00.870
So we can do that,
let's go and take a look here.

357
00:20:00.870 --> 00:20:04.260
So on the switch that needs to be
controlled by another network,

358
00:20:04.260 --> 00:20:07.120
from another network,
not by another network, I should say.

359
00:20:07.120 --> 00:20:09.220
Then that's all we have to do.

360
00:20:09.220 --> 00:20:14.161
Now, remember that means you have
an IP address on this switch on

361
00:20:14.161 --> 00:20:17.465
the interface VLAN 1 for the management.

362
00:20:17.465 --> 00:20:21.393
And then all you have to do is get out to
this global configuration prompt here.

363
00:20:21.393 --> 00:20:25.546
And do IP default-gateway, and

364
00:20:25.546 --> 00:20:33.010
then you simply type in the IP
address of your gateway.

365
00:20:33.010 --> 00:20:37.500
So, now as a Telnet or
an SSH connection comes in to the switch

366
00:20:37.500 --> 00:20:40.310
through whatever router
it actually came through.

367
00:20:40.310 --> 00:20:44.090
It lands at that connection on that
switch and then it says, hey, for

368
00:20:44.090 --> 00:20:45.570
me to return this reply.

369
00:20:45.570 --> 00:20:47.150
I don't have a route to get there.

370
00:20:47.150 --> 00:20:48.440
It goes through what?

371
00:20:48.440 --> 00:20:50.390
Its default gateway, and

372
00:20:50.390 --> 00:20:54.540
on your router, it should be able to get
back to whoever sent the initial command.

373
00:20:54.540 --> 00:20:58.780
So that default gateway on a switch
is actually very important for

374
00:20:58.780 --> 00:21:02.500
us if we're going to do some
type of management with this.

375
00:21:02.500 --> 00:21:05.920
So just kind of remember that there's
a lot of pieces involved here.

376
00:21:05.920 --> 00:21:08.450
But for
us it's checking the simple things, right?

377
00:21:08.450 --> 00:21:11.860
So those types of scenarios
are always gonna happen.

378
00:21:11.860 --> 00:21:15.720
You can't get access to the switch from
another network, default gateway, okay?

379
00:21:15.720 --> 00:21:17.980
You can't manage the switch
on your same network,

380
00:21:17.980 --> 00:21:20.660
you're trying to do it from
your desktop computer.

381
00:21:20.660 --> 00:21:24.320
Well you need to make sure that you set
up the access for it by giving it an IP

382
00:21:24.320 --> 00:21:28.420
address and setting up, of course,
those virtual lines or terminals.

383
00:21:28.420 --> 00:21:30.100

384
00:21:30.100 --> 00:21:31.690
So that's where it begins.

385
00:21:31.690 --> 00:21:34.860
>> Yeah Ronnie, in the first part of this

00:21:34.860 --> 00:21:37.880

a managed switch.

00:21:37.880 --> 00:21:40.636
And one of the things I noticed

00:21:40.636 --> 00:21:42.465
a little marker on the side that said POE.

389
00:21:42.465 --> 00:21:46.650
I've seen that before as far as
advertised on the devices themselves.

390
00:21:46.650 --> 00:21:48.670
What is that doing for
us when it comes to the switch?

391
00:21:48.670 --> 00:21:50.730
What is this POE they speak of.?

392
00:21:50.730 --> 00:21:53.980
>> POE is what they call
power over Ethernet.

393
00:21:53.980 --> 00:21:57.030
Now, if you've had any small device.

394
00:21:57.030 --> 00:22:00.670
A good one that you'll end up seeing
in a corporate environment or

395
00:22:00.670 --> 00:22:04.210
business environment is
what we call VOIP phones.

396
00:22:04.210 --> 00:22:06.840
They normally come, of course,
you plug it in and it will work and

397
00:22:06.840 --> 00:22:08.400
just about ready to go.

398
00:22:08.400 --> 00:22:13.470
But they also normally come with the power
adapter, or what people call wall warts.

399
00:22:13.470 --> 00:22:15.930
First time I heard that I was like,
what the heck is the wall wart?

400
00:22:15.930 --> 00:22:19.410
I don't know, but everybody knew
what they were talking about.

401
00:22:19.410 --> 00:22:21.020
I didn't know what it was.

402
00:22:21.020 --> 00:22:26.260
But that's supplying what extra power to
that phone to get it up and working, okay?

403
00:22:26.260 --> 00:22:29.360
Well, if your switch doesn't
supply any power to the phone,

404
00:22:29.360 --> 00:22:32.450
the only way to supply power to
the phone is by that wall wart.

405
00:22:32.450 --> 00:22:35.577
POE, power over Ethernet
means that instead,

406
00:22:35.577 --> 00:22:38.632
we can just plug the wire
into that VOIP phone.

407
00:22:38.632 --> 00:22:43.384
And it supplies, not only the network and
the telephone connections that we need to,

408
00:22:43.384 --> 00:22:48.700
but it also supplies the additional power
needed for that phone to operate and work.

409
00:22:48.700 --> 00:22:50.548
So that's what you actually
end up talking about.

410
00:22:50.548 --> 00:22:52.340
>> I think, Ronnie,
you just solved a mystery for me,

411
00:22:52.340 --> 00:22:53.370
and help me out on this one.

412
00:22:53.370 --> 00:22:56.268
I've seen wireless access points
that are in the middle of nowhere.

413
00:22:56.268 --> 00:22:58.850
There isn't an outlet anywhere,
but I've also seen

414
00:22:58.850 --> 00:23:02.580
IP cams that are on the side of a brick
wall and there isn't a outlet anywhere.

415
00:23:02.580 --> 00:23:04.640
Is that what they most
likely might be doing?

416
00:23:04.640 --> 00:23:07.370
Are they supplying power to these
devices over the Ethernet cables that

417
00:23:07.370 --> 00:23:08.130
are plugged into them?

418
00:23:08.130 --> 00:23:10.560
>> That's exactly right,
they're pretty much doing that.

419
00:23:10.560 --> 00:23:13.590
Now the key to making that work
are a couple of elements, right?

420
00:23:13.590 --> 00:23:16.670
The switch has to have power going to it.

421
00:23:16.670 --> 00:23:20.000
If it doesn't,
there are ways to kind of get around it.

422
00:23:20.000 --> 00:23:21.830
I know that that sounds weird.

423
00:23:21.830 --> 00:23:23.650
But there are ways,
to kind of get around it.

424
00:23:23.650 --> 00:23:28.520
Those devices, have also come up with
what they call, power injectors, too.

425
00:23:28.520 --> 00:23:32.460
Now you might go,
what the heck is a power injector?.

426
00:23:32.460 --> 00:23:36.224
Well it's the device that can plug into
a wall outlet, it's got a wall wart.

427
00:23:36.224 --> 00:23:40.390
But then you actually plug that
inline to the network cable.

428
00:23:40.390 --> 00:23:43.040
So you now actually have two cables
running to whatever device it is.

429
00:23:43.040 --> 00:23:48.403
Whether it's a wireless access point,
or an IP camera, or a VOIP phone.

430
00:23:48.403 --> 00:23:50.208
It just gives you one wire to worry about.

431
00:23:50.208 --> 00:23:52.568
And then you generally plug that
injector in somewhere else.

432
00:23:52.568 --> 00:23:55.279
But overall though, the switch itself,

433
00:23:55.279 --> 00:24:00.398
if it supplies POE It will actually end
up being able to power those devices up.

434
00:24:00.398 --> 00:24:01.768
And we should be good with it.

435
00:24:01.768 --> 00:24:03.882
>> Ronnie,
as far as the physical media goes,

436
00:24:03.882 --> 00:24:05.780
is that just your standard Cat cables?

437
00:24:05.780 --> 00:24:08.360
Are there nothing really
special about those Cat cables?

438
00:24:08.360 --> 00:24:12.810
>> Well, you normally need at least
Cat5E if you're going to do this.

439
00:24:12.810 --> 00:24:17.003
Or it just pretty much is
one of those requirements.

440
00:24:17.003 --> 00:24:19.732
Now, and that's kind of one that hopefully

441
00:24:19.732 --> 00:24:23.217
just about everybody today
is running at least Cat5e.

442
00:24:23.217 --> 00:24:27.030
Now I'm not gonna say that you are or
aren't, but hopefully you are.

443
00:24:27.030 --> 00:24:32.027
But it does require that, and
the great thing is this particular type of

444
00:24:32.027 --> 00:24:37.038
POE has kinda really stabilized into
two standards that are out there.

445
00:24:37.038 --> 00:24:46.424
The ieee802.3af and .at.

446
00:24:46.424 --> 00:24:49.590
So remember those
particular standards there.

447
00:24:49.590 --> 00:24:54.740
The first one, the .af, is a very popular
one and it's kind of the standard now.

448
00:24:54.740 --> 00:24:57.040
It can supply up to about 15 volts.

449
00:24:57.040 --> 00:25:00.930
I think,15.4 watts, not volts, watts.

450
00:25:00.930 --> 00:25:03.436
Let me make sure I make that
clear distinction there.

451
00:25:03.436 --> 00:25:08.266
So most of the devices that you
have that only need up to 15 watts,

452
00:25:08.266 --> 00:25:10.438
this is one that will do that.

453
00:25:10.438 --> 00:25:13.491
But what about those devices that
need a little bit more power?

454
00:25:13.491 --> 00:25:15.727
And there are plenty of them out there.

455
00:25:15.727 --> 00:25:21.808
Then you have the AT,
which provides all up to 25.5 watts,

456
00:25:21.808 --> 00:25:24.803
so pretty much almost double.

457
00:25:24.803 --> 00:25:27.275
I'm not gonna say it's exactly double but

458
00:25:27.275 --> 00:25:30.770
almost double the amount
of power that you have.

459
00:25:30.770 --> 00:25:37.174
So as long as most devices have kinda
said, look, we're AF or AT standard,

460
00:25:37.174 --> 00:25:42.396
most of the power over ethernet
supply by switches will work.

461
00:25:42.396 --> 00:25:47.781
You will still run into some proprietary
devices that will require their

462
00:25:47.781 --> 00:25:53.443
own way of doing the power over ethernet,
using their own power injectors.

463
00:25:53.443 --> 00:25:57.802

00:25:57.802 --> 00:26:01.666

00:26:01.666 --> 00:26:05.586

00:26:07.688 --> 00:26:09.857

00:26:09.857 --> 00:26:13.481

00:26:13.481 --> 00:26:14.517

00:26:19.726 --> 00:26:20.844
[LAUGH]
>> Ronnie,

00:26:20.844 --> 00:26:24.918

00:26:24.918 --> 00:26:28.965

475
00:26:28.965 --> 00:26:32.873
Is that the total wattage that's
divided between all ports or can you?

476
00:26:32.873 --> 00:26:36.155
Or do you have some type of configuration
if you need more wattage on one port you

00:26:36.155 --> 00:26:38.070
can do that and it lessens it on others?

478
00:26:38.070 --> 00:26:40.760
>> It's kind of a weird way

00:26:40.760 --> 00:26:46.350
Usually the switch is told, this how much
power you have period overall, okay?

00:26:46.350 --> 00:26:48.890

depending on the port density,

00:26:48.890 --> 00:26:51.260
the number of ports on that device.

482
00:26:51.260 --> 00:26:56.024
So that's normally what you end up
seeing where it can do certain amounts.

483
00:26:56.024 --> 00:26:57.637
So they're following those standards.

484
00:26:57.637 --> 00:27:01.739
The max that you should be able to push
out through that one is gonna be that

485
00:27:01.739 --> 00:27:02.759
25.5 watts.

486
00:27:02.759 --> 00:27:06.980
But you might have the ability,
if you also needed to at times,

487
00:27:06.980 --> 00:27:10.019
maybe to be able to push
out a little bit more.

488
00:27:10.019 --> 00:27:13.267
It always ranges a little
bit differently and

00:27:13.267 --> 00:27:17.978

00:27:17.978 --> 00:27:21.204

00:27:21.204 --> 00:27:24.591

00:27:24.591 --> 00:27:29.574

00:27:31.568 --> 00:27:33.557

00:27:33.557 --> 00:27:35.774

496
00:27:35.774 --> 00:27:37.166
>> Well,
that's a lot of great information, Ronnie.

Keep in mind what Ronnie said.

Pay attention to those standards,
pay attention to the configuration, or

00:27:42.561 --> 00:27:46.480

00:22:27.749 --> 00:22:30.590
And then somebody else's
comes online on channel 11?

437
00:22:30.590 --> 00:22:33.021
So, you can use your heat maps, right.

438
00:22:33.021 --> 00:22:34.986
Heat maps show the signal's strength.

439
00:22:34.986 --> 00:22:38.474
But they can also show things
like the channels around you,

440
00:22:38.474 --> 00:22:41.140
what access points
are using what channels.

441
00:22:41.140 --> 00:22:45.312
And you move your channel of your 2.4
gigahertz network to another channel,

442
00:22:45.312 --> 00:22:47.757
off of whatever the auto-configuration is.

443
00:22:47.757 --> 00:22:52.125
So, again, remember 11 channels,
non-overlapping channels for

444
00:22:52.125 --> 00:22:54.900
purposes of performance, 1, 6 and 11.

445
00:22:54.900 --> 00:22:59.540
Now they also call out,
[LAUGH] well, the 5 GHz spectrum.

446
00:22:59.540 --> 00:23:04.240
And you could see, Dan,
my 5 GHz spectrum diagram is fantastic.

447
00:23:04.240 --> 00:23:06.125
>> It's an amazing work of art.

448
00:23:06.125 --> 00:23:08.338
[CROSSTALK]
>> I understand everything about 5 GHz.

449
00:23:08.338 --> 00:23:09.812
>> That's perfect, that's right.

450
00:23:09.812 --> 00:23:11.055
[CROSSTALK] Are you ready for the exam?

451
00:23:11.055 --> 00:23:11.780
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well, here's

452
00:23:11.780 --> 00:23:13.200
what you should be ready for.

453
00:23:13.200 --> 00:23:14.932
There are a lot of channels, right.

454
00:23:14.932 --> 00:23:19.062
And they don't all go in order like we
see in one, two, three, four, five, six,

455
00:23:19.062 --> 00:23:22.488
seven, eight, nine, ten,
eleven in 2.4 gigahertz spectrum.

456
00:23:22.488 --> 00:23:24.289
So I did not write them all out here.

457
00:23:24.289 --> 00:23:27.154
I don't think they're gonna expect
you to know every individual channel.

458
00:23:27.154 --> 00:23:31.238
However, know in the US,
those channels start at 36.

459
00:23:31.238 --> 00:23:36.006
And they work their way up to,
I put 135, I'll have to double check.

460
00:23:36.006 --> 00:23:39.404
Cuz I believe that might be 165,
in fact I'm thinking that's right.

461
00:23:39.404 --> 00:23:41.760
I don't think 135 was right, 165.

462
00:23:41.760 --> 00:23:46.622
And what's interesting about the five
gigahertz spectrum is the fact that at

463
00:23:46.622 --> 00:23:50.885
the time of the recording of this show,
it's relatively [INAUDIBLE]

464
00:23:50.885 --> 00:23:55.822
Becoming more use with things like
your 802.11n, and then certainly,

465
00:23:55.822 --> 00:24:01.240
your 802.11ac devices that are out there,
cuz they run in the 5GHz spectrum.

466
00:24:01.240 --> 00:24:05.346
Now one of the good things in spectrum
as well that built into the 802.11

467
00:24:05.346 --> 00:24:09.768
specification, is that each channel that
we use here in the United States supports

468
00:24:09.768 --> 00:24:11.150
something known as DFS.

469
00:24:11.150 --> 00:24:14.024
That is the Dynamic Frequency
Selection Technology, and

470
00:24:14.024 --> 00:24:15.673
it's built into every channel.

471
00:24:15.673 --> 00:24:19.987
And, if you are going to be
compliant with 5GHz spectrum,

472
00:24:19.987 --> 00:24:24.560
it has to be built in according
to the standard as well.

473
00:24:24.560 --> 00:24:28.480
And DFS, Dynamic Frequency Selection,
this is kind of cool,

474
00:24:28.480 --> 00:24:32.530
is the fact that, when we moved into
the 5 GHz band, a lot of radar systems,

475
00:24:32.530 --> 00:24:36.560
including things like your Doppler radar
systems, are on that 5 GHz spectrum too.

476
00:24:36.560 --> 00:24:42.640
So they wanted a way that devices,
these unrestricted,

477
00:24:42.640 --> 00:24:47.562
unlicensed, if you will, using band,
they're using the unlicensed band,

478
00:24:47.562 --> 00:24:50.760
that they don't interfere
with those radar systems.

479
00:24:50.760 --> 00:24:54.110
So what they do is they use dynamic
frequency selection that says,

480
00:24:54.110 --> 00:24:57.850
if I detect a radar system using this,

481
00:24:57.850 --> 00:25:00.840
dynamically switched to another
frequency or another channel.

482
00:25:00.840 --> 00:25:03.840
So, keep that in mind, and again,
the channels here running from 36 to 165,

483
00:25:03.840 --> 00:25:11.480
I do believe 165 is the top end there
on that, and again the 5 GHz spectrum.

484
00:25:11.480 --> 00:25:13.740
We use larger channel widths.

485
00:25:13.740 --> 00:25:18.440
You'll see that in, for instance,
802.11n, if you're on an A network,

486
00:25:18.440 --> 00:25:21.130
you're using 40 MHz channels.

487
00:25:21.130 --> 00:25:24.580
If you're doing backwards compatibility,
it splits those channels up and

488
00:25:24.580 --> 00:25:30.180
you're using 20 MHz for old legacy
devices, 20 MHz for new legacy devices.

489
00:25:30.180 --> 00:25:33.270
Or, if you're just supporting
all new devices,N devices,

490
00:25:33.270 --> 00:25:35.170
you could aggregate those together, and

491
00:25:35.170 --> 00:25:39.040
you get a 40 MHz bandwidth,
pumping out a lot of information.

492
00:25:39.040 --> 00:25:44.670
But then if you move into AC, the newer
standards, not only do you get the 40 MHz,

493
00:25:44.670 --> 00:25:49.550
but they double that to 80 MHz, and
then they double that to 160 MHz.

494
00:25:49.550 --> 00:25:52.482
So you can see a lot of
information being pumped out,

495
00:25:52.482 --> 00:25:54.690
according to the new standards today.

496
00:25:56.350 --> 00:25:59.370
All right, Dan, so a couple other
things that they call out here too,

497
00:25:59.370 --> 00:26:03.850
that we want to kinda be aware of,
signal strength.

498
00:26:03.850 --> 00:26:09.030
Actually, I tell you what, we're gonna go
and, let's do something known as good put.

499
00:26:09.030 --> 00:26:10.100
This is kinda interesting.

500
00:26:10.100 --> 00:26:11.960
I look [LAUGH] at this technology.

501
00:26:11.960 --> 00:26:16.080
We always think of bandwidth, and
we think of through put, if you will.

502
00:26:16.080 --> 00:26:20.010
Let's go ahead, and let's start
by demystifying what those mean.

503
00:26:20.010 --> 00:26:23.390
I got a little bit of a diagram here.

504
00:26:23.390 --> 00:26:27.350
Let's say I use a wireless
network analyzer or

505
00:26:27.350 --> 00:26:32.310
just a network analyzer in general, and
I learned that my bandwidth, I know that,

506
00:26:32.310 --> 00:26:37.300
according to standards, I've set my
network up for a gigabit standard, right?

507
00:26:37.300 --> 00:26:40.490
That's what I said, I got gigabit nics,
I got gigabit speed cables,

508
00:26:40.490 --> 00:26:41.855
I got gigabit devices.

509
00:26:41.855 --> 00:26:46.849
You gotta understand that, that's just the
theoretical bandwidth, if I could saturate

510
00:26:47.990 --> 00:26:51.460
all the amount of information I could
throw off that network at one time.

511
00:26:51.460 --> 00:26:53.200
But that's not reality.

512
00:26:53.200 --> 00:26:56.420
Reality is what's actually happening,
and that's throughput.

513
00:26:56.420 --> 00:27:00.320
Throughput says, yeah, I know what the
bandwidth is, I've got a gigabit network.

514
00:27:00.320 --> 00:27:04.300
But when I take into consideration other
things, like on that gigabit network,

515
00:27:04.300 --> 00:27:05.889
out there on one of those lines.

516
00:27:05.889 --> 00:27:09.286
I've got a cable that's been
pulled a little bit too far,

517
00:27:09.286 --> 00:27:13.880
undoes some of the twists, reduces
the performance of the cable, all right.

518
00:27:13.880 --> 00:27:14.720
We've got, what else?

519
00:27:14.720 --> 00:27:16.495
That's not only thing we've got, right?

520
00:27:16.495 --> 00:27:20.410
We've got, maybe, some electromagnetic
interference somewhere within those lines.

521
00:27:20.410 --> 00:27:24.090
Doesn't matter that your
theoretical bandwidth is a gig,

522
00:27:24.090 --> 00:27:28.350
those are factors that are stepping down
the overall top speed of your network.

523
00:27:28.350 --> 00:27:34.224
Understand that throughput is what's
actually happening, all right.

524
00:27:34.224 --> 00:27:39.373
Now, that being said, that's interesting,
okay, we'll just leave that there for now.

525
00:27:39.373 --> 00:27:43.160
>> [LAUGH]
>> EMI does cause problems, doesn't it?

526
00:27:43.160 --> 00:27:46.650
So that's throughput,
throughput says in a given second,

527
00:27:46.650 --> 00:27:51.480
how much data do I actually
have on that wire?

528
00:27:51.480 --> 00:27:53.070
Well, where does goodput come in?

529
00:27:53.070 --> 00:27:54.610
Well, goodput's kinda interesting.

530
00:27:56.160 --> 00:28:01.580
Goodput, you'll have to ask the question,
how much of the data was actually useful?

531
00:28:01.580 --> 00:28:02.770
What do you mean by that?

532
00:28:02.770 --> 00:28:03.570
Well, I want you to think,

533
00:28:03.570 --> 00:28:08.930
not every bit of that 700 Mb
throughput is useful data, right?

534
00:28:08.930 --> 00:28:10.930
I have, well, what do we have?

535
00:28:12.290 --> 00:28:15.740
We've got network communications,
we got network control, right?

536
00:28:15.740 --> 00:28:20.560
ARP responses, we got negative
acknowledgements, acknowledgements, right?

537
00:28:20.560 --> 00:28:25.770
My network adapter cares
about the acknowledgements.

538
00:28:25.770 --> 00:28:29.310
But my application, that's up on my
desktop, that's processing the data,

539
00:28:29.310 --> 00:28:31.580
does it care about a retransmit?

540
00:28:31.580 --> 00:28:32.890
That's not good data.

541
00:28:32.890 --> 00:28:36.470
So with goodput,
don't let the term fool you.

542
00:28:36.470 --> 00:28:41.000
What you're actually actually kinda doing,
is looking inside the data.

543
00:28:41.000 --> 00:28:42.330
What is the actual data, right?

544
00:28:42.330 --> 00:28:47.100
I know the bandwidth overall is 700 Mb,
but that doesn't

545
00:28:47.100 --> 00:28:51.940
mean that's what I'm actually processing,
up there at the application layer.

546
00:28:51.940 --> 00:28:57.200
So if I take out retransmits,
if I take out network communication and

547
00:28:57.200 --> 00:29:02.040
control information, and
I'm left with just the application data,

548
00:29:02.040 --> 00:29:05.080
well that's essentially what goodput is.

549
00:29:05.080 --> 00:29:08.670
Goodput says, I don't care
what the throughput is, right?

550
00:29:08.670 --> 00:29:09.820
That's all the data.

551
00:29:10.840 --> 00:29:14.070
All I care about is what is
the application layer data,

552
00:29:14.070 --> 00:29:17.110
that was delivered to
the application itself, right?

553
00:29:17.110 --> 00:29:22.210
And you could see that goodput could be
several megabits lower than what your

554
00:29:22.210 --> 00:29:24.420
throughput is, so they do call that out.

555
00:29:24.420 --> 00:29:28.050
It's not a real good way
to measure goodput, right?

556
00:29:28.050 --> 00:29:31.360
If it's throughput, I could put some
kind of network analyzer on it, right?

557
00:29:31.360 --> 00:29:35.270
I can put a cable certifier on it, and
I could test information like that.

558
00:29:35.270 --> 00:29:38.760
When you use goodput, it's almost
always gonna be some kind of software,

559
00:29:38.760 --> 00:29:44.070
that does trending analysis over time,
and says, okay well, your through

560
00:29:44.070 --> 00:29:48.170
puts in 700 Mb, but we know that web
application server, man, it's crawling.

561
00:29:48.170 --> 00:29:50.690
>> This is definitely one of the things
that would trick me up on an exam,

562
00:29:50.690 --> 00:29:54.110
because I would think, goodput,
if it's anything that was good data,

563
00:29:54.110 --> 00:29:58.230
well, retransmits are good because
without them, I didn't transmit anything.

564
00:29:58.230 --> 00:30:00.460
I get garbled nests at the end
of the thing, right so,

565
00:30:00.460 --> 00:30:00.990
>> That's right.

566
00:30:00.990 --> 00:30:02.190
>> It would totally jack me up.

567
00:30:02.190 --> 00:30:06.070
You have to keep in mind on what
they mean when they say goodput,

568
00:30:06.070 --> 00:30:07.410
not what you might interpret it as.

569
00:30:07.410 --> 00:30:09.040
>> That is a great point Dan.

570
00:30:09.040 --> 00:30:10.020
I had to do the same thing.

571
00:30:10.020 --> 00:30:13.450
Step out and put my blinders on,
if you will,

572
00:30:13.450 --> 00:30:18.150
from the perspective of the application
that's waiting on the data, right?

573
00:30:18.150 --> 00:30:20.610
I need my pizza, that's what I want.

574
00:30:20.610 --> 00:30:25.810
I don't care what road the guy,
he didn't have to tell me,

575
00:30:25.810 --> 00:30:28.310
I went down this road,
I took a right, I passed the guy,

576
00:30:28.310 --> 00:30:30.660
the old guy in the rocking chair
with the dogs sitting next to it,

577
00:30:30.660 --> 00:30:32.240
I don't care about all that-
>> I'm driving a Honda Civic,

578
00:30:32.240 --> 00:30:32.950
it's black, yeah.

579
00:30:32.950 --> 00:30:35.355
>> You're driving a Honda Civic,
it's been tricked out, right?

580
00:30:35.355 --> 00:30:36.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don't care about that,

581
00:30:36.870 --> 00:30:37.961
I want my pizza, right?

582
00:30:37.961 --> 00:30:40.150
[LAUGH] Well,
the application just wants its data,

583
00:30:40.150 --> 00:30:41.560
it doesn't care about all the other stuff.

584
00:30:41.560 --> 00:30:45.230
And that's essentially what goodput is for
us.

585
00:30:45.230 --> 00:30:48.730
All right, Dan, I know we're
running a little bit short on time.

586
00:30:48.730 --> 00:30:53.950
I do have a few more things, but I don't
know that I can put it in this episode,

587
00:30:53.950 --> 00:30:56.120
so we might have to go into a part two.

588
00:30:56.120 --> 00:30:57.260
>> Yeah, that sounds perfect, right?

589
00:30:57.260 --> 00:30:58.670
Because sometimes that happens.

590
00:30:58.670 --> 00:31:00.870
And you know we love our part
twos around here at ITProTV.

591
00:31:00.870 --> 00:31:04.150
Hopefully you do, and
you'll watch that one as well.

592
00:31:04.150 --> 00:31:07.640
Wes, a lot of great information in this
episode though, so we appreciate that.

593
00:31:07.640 --> 00:31:09.310
We do appreciate our viewers for
watching, but

594
00:31:09.310 --> 00:31:12.580
it does look like it's about that time for
us to sign off.

595
00:31:12.580 --> 00:31:16.110
So, signing off, for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

596
00:31:16.110 --> 00:31:16.750
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

597
00:31:16.750 --> 00:31:19.268
>> And we'll see you next time.

598
00:31:19.268 --> 00:31:25.151
[MUSIC]

599
00:31:25.151 --> 00:31:27.235
>> Thank you for watching, ITProTV.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:01.190
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.190 --> 00:00:02.606
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.606 --> 00:00:08.471
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:08.471 --> 00:00:12.175
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.175 --> 00:00:12.964
>> All right.

6
00:00:12.964 --> 00:00:16.670
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.670 --> 00:00:17.845
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

8
00:00:17.845 --> 00:00:21.385
And in today's episode we are continuing
on with more on our Network+ series

9
00:00:21.385 --> 00:00:22.430
from CompTIA.

10
00:00:22.430 --> 00:00:25.560
And of course, joining us back
in the studio yet again for

11
00:00:25.560 --> 00:00:29.960
a part two on Wireless Infrastructure
is our good friend, Mr Wes Bryan.

12
00:00:29.960 --> 00:00:31.630
Wes, welcome back, sir, how's it going?

13
00:00:31.630 --> 00:00:35.010
>> Man, it's going great, what have been
going even better if I would have managed

14
00:00:35.010 --> 00:00:36.695
to not talk so much in the first episode.

15
00:00:36.695 --> 00:00:38.316
[LAUGH]
>> Lot of info there.

16
00:00:38.316 --> 00:00:42.294
>> Yeah, we've got a couple more topics
that we have to discuss when it comes to

17
00:00:42.294 --> 00:00:46.410
configuring and implementing wireless
local area network infrastructure.

18
00:00:46.410 --> 00:00:48.230
And we didn't manage to put
those in the first part,

19
00:00:48.230 --> 00:00:50.830
so that is why we
are back with a part two.

20
00:00:50.830 --> 00:00:54.680
Keep in mind some of the stuff that
we talked about in the first part.

21
00:00:54.680 --> 00:00:58.580
If you're just joining us, definitely
go back and check out the first part.

22
00:00:58.580 --> 00:01:04.030
We talked about wireless access points,
device density, roaming, VLAN pooling.

23
00:01:04.030 --> 00:01:10.128
We even talked about the lightweight
wireless access point protocol.

24
00:01:10.128 --> 00:01:11.027
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's it.

25
00:01:11.027 --> 00:01:14.790
[LAUGH]
>> Protocol, protocol, point protocol

26
00:01:14.790 --> 00:01:19.830
where we can control the configurations
of a multitude of access points

27
00:01:19.830 --> 00:01:23.900
on our network from a single location,
channels and all kinds of good things.

28
00:01:23.900 --> 00:01:26.020
If any of that sounds foreign to you,
go back and

29
00:01:26.020 --> 00:01:29.880
check that episode out, and then come
back and you can round it off here.

30
00:01:29.880 --> 00:01:32.100
Some of the things that
we're going to talk about,

31
00:01:33.100 --> 00:01:36.840
one of the first things that we got
to talk about are topology types.

32
00:01:36.840 --> 00:01:40.620
Probably it would had been a great thing
to start out with the different topologies

33
00:01:40.620 --> 00:01:44.100
that we have in wireless local
area network implementation, but

34
00:01:44.100 --> 00:01:47.330
we can talk about them for sure here.

35
00:01:47.330 --> 00:01:50.530
So let's go ahead, I've got a little
diagram here, and one of the things that

36
00:01:50.530 --> 00:01:56.480
they talk about is a couple
different types of these topologies.

37
00:01:56.480 --> 00:02:00.888
They talk about what's known
as infrastructure mode,

38
00:02:00.888 --> 00:02:02.867
mesh mode, ad hoc mode.

39
00:02:02.867 --> 00:02:06.039
Well, mesh mode, we've kinda talked
about this in other topologies,

40
00:02:06.039 --> 00:02:08.960
where we're talking about
different network implementations.

41
00:02:08.960 --> 00:02:14.980
And a mesh topology is typically where you
have this redundant type of configuration.

42
00:02:14.980 --> 00:02:19.840
Where whatever the device is that's
basically participating in the mesh

43
00:02:19.840 --> 00:02:24.220
network, has redundant connections to
every other device in the network.

44
00:02:24.220 --> 00:02:27.250
In this point what I'm talking
about is the connectivity devices.

45
00:02:27.250 --> 00:02:30.550
Because when we talk about this
type of wireless-based mesh,

46
00:02:30.550 --> 00:02:34.230
what we have are a series of
access points that are configured.

47
00:02:34.230 --> 00:02:37.450
And they have redundant connections
to all other access points that

48
00:02:37.450 --> 00:02:39.050
are in this wireless mesh.

49
00:02:39.050 --> 00:02:39.920
And then finally,

50
00:02:39.920 --> 00:02:45.350
a single end point here that we
communicate off of our local area network.

51
00:02:45.350 --> 00:02:49.330
All right, so
that is a form of wireless mesh network.

52
00:02:49.330 --> 00:02:54.510
Now, another one that falls
under the wireless mesh

53
00:02:54.510 --> 00:02:58.580
type of topology is something
known as an ad hoc network.

54
00:02:58.580 --> 00:03:01.470
Now, be careful with
this one because ad hoc

55
00:03:01.470 --> 00:03:05.630
isn't the only implementation of a mesh
network, it's actually the opposite.

56
00:03:05.630 --> 00:03:09.610
Ad hoc is just a form of
mesh network implementation,

57
00:03:09.610 --> 00:03:10.950
it's one of the forms that you can have.

episodes.description: With the numerous options and features of firewalls choosing one can sometimes prove to be difficult. Wes and Cherokee aim to clarify these different offerings so you can choose the best solution for your needs. They discuss several aspects to consider including but not limited to the logical network placement, host vs network firewalls, stateful vs stateless and how those features correlate with the layers of the OSI model.

again inbound traffic depends on

00:23:15.700 --> 00:23:19.500

00:23:23.460 --> 00:23:24.390
the public network.

446
00:23:25.640 --> 00:23:27.480
Let's see here.

They also talk about, again,

00:23:37.280 --> 00:23:40.480

I don't wanna give everybody

00:23:43.514 --> 00:23:47.832
It's one of the reasons we hit you

episodes.description: In this show Wes and Cherokee look at different ways one can limit and manage access granted to network resources. Wes explains 802.1x, posture assessment, guest networks, quarantine networks, and edge vs access control. Lastly, Wes shows a demonstration of how a network policy server can limit access based on preconfigured parameters.

1

7

It has to be a wireless communication.

00:02:39.281 --> 00:02:43.555

Now that's the wireless implementation.

00:02:51.642 --> 00:02:56.545

00:03:14.214 --> 00:03:15.910

non-persistent is one that is run in RAM,

00:06:55.820 --> 00:06:58.075
Once its done,
it's closed that RAM is freed up and

00:06:58.075 --> 00:06:59.605

Typically installed, like a piece of

00:25:11.280 --> 00:25:15.553
And you might not solve the issue
on the first go around.

514
00:25:15.553 --> 00:25:17.510
So save that person's direct information.

515
00:25:17.510 --> 00:25:19.669
So you're saving time when you have
to get back on the phone with them.

516
00:25:19.669 --> 00:25:21.430
To let them know, look,
this didn't work or whatever.

517
00:25:21.430 --> 00:25:24.518
I don't know what kind of support you
have, depending on your service contract.

518
00:25:24.518 --> 00:25:26.822
So things of that nature, but-

519
00:25:26.822 --> 00:25:27.963
And the other thing, too,

520
00:25:27.963 --> 00:25:31.025
is don't think that you might
just have to escalate it up.

521
00:25:31.025 --> 00:25:32.785
You might have to escalate out.

522
00:25:32.785 --> 00:25:34.185
And what do I mean by that?

00:25:34.185 --> 00:25:35.415

524
00:25:35.415 --> 00:25:36.595
One of the other show hosts and

talk about, I don't know,

527
00:25:45.275 --> 00:25:47.320
the ghost in the darkness or something.

528
00:25:47.320 --> 00:25:50.190
It would join a directory, and
then you'd go to print, and

00:25:50.190 --> 00:25:51.310
you'd lose it of the directory.

530
00:25:51.310 --> 00:25:52.810
And it'd unjoin the directory.

531
00:25:52.810 --> 00:25:54.440
It was the weirdest thing.

532
00:25:54.440 --> 00:25:58.000
But I should know how to
troubleshoot a printer, but

533
00:25:58.000 --> 00:25:59.210
I couldn't find what the problem was.

534
00:25:59.210 --> 00:26:03.100
So we escalate it to the person
sitting next to me, right?

535
00:26:03.100 --> 00:26:05.070
Ended up finding that
it was a driver issue.

536
00:26:05.070 --> 00:26:07.140
And everybody says well,
of course it's a driver issue.

537
00:26:07.140 --> 00:26:09.070
That's what we always say about hardware.

538
00:26:09.070 --> 00:26:12.619
But it was a point in the manufacturing
process that their model numbers,

539
00:26:12.619 --> 00:26:14.005
internally, had changed.

540
00:26:14.005 --> 00:26:16.118
And they were using different drivers for

541
00:26:16.118 --> 00:26:18.963
what appeared on the outside
as the same exact printer.

542
00:26:18.963 --> 00:26:20.278
But we didn't know So again,

543
00:26:20.278 --> 00:26:23.340
don't think that escalating always
has to be to a higher level tier.

544
00:26:23.340 --> 00:26:25.749
It could be to your peers who've
got more experience than you do.

545
00:26:25.749 --> 00:26:30.465
Even though you're sitting at
the same level as them, if you will,

546
00:26:30.465 --> 00:26:32.630
on the food chain of helpdesk.

547
00:26:32.630 --> 00:26:34.783
>> Yes.
>> That's right.

548
00:26:34.783 --> 00:26:36.585
All right, so where are we at next?

549
00:26:36.585 --> 00:26:40.515
So the next thing we've got is establish
a plan to resolve the problem,

550
00:26:40.515 --> 00:26:41.245
and all right.

551
00:26:41.245 --> 00:26:43.277
And then identify possible effects, okay?

552
00:26:43.277 --> 00:26:47.527
Okay and they don't talk about this here.

553
00:26:47.527 --> 00:26:50.405
I'm going to go ahead and
add something here that is not for

554
00:26:50.405 --> 00:26:51.951
the certification purposes.

555
00:26:51.951 --> 00:26:56.952
All right they say,
identify possible side effects, okay.

556
00:26:59.019 --> 00:27:01.310
What happens if something goes wrong?

557
00:27:01.310 --> 00:27:04.870
I want you to put here too in
your minds a rollback plan.

558
00:27:04.870 --> 00:27:05.704
Plan for rollback.

559
00:27:05.704 --> 00:27:08.640
Cuz if you're gonna identify
possible effects, and

560
00:27:08.640 --> 00:27:10.605
you think there might be an effect.

561
00:27:10.605 --> 00:27:12.600
Make sure that you can
undo the changes as well.

562
00:27:13.670 --> 00:27:17.690
I will tell you up until this point, if
you notice, we haven't touched the system.

563
00:27:19.070 --> 00:27:20.686
We haven't made a single change here.

564
00:27:20.686 --> 00:27:22.501
The other thing that I would
tell you at this point.

565
00:27:22.501 --> 00:27:24.821
If you're going to
establish a plan of action,

566
00:27:24.821 --> 00:27:27.870
the very first thing you
do is take back ups.

567
00:27:27.870 --> 00:27:29.890
Notice we haven't changed anything yet.

568
00:27:29.890 --> 00:27:32.030
Up until this point, nothing's changed.

569
00:27:32.030 --> 00:27:34.440
Because if we change it,
we just skip ahead,

570
00:27:34.440 --> 00:27:36.520
then we could be the source
of the problem to begin with.

571
00:27:36.520 --> 00:27:38.660
So, do keep that in mind.

572
00:27:38.660 --> 00:27:44.660
All right, next one we have is
implement a solution or escalate.

573
00:27:44.660 --> 00:27:49.600
Again, there's no problem with saying,
I'm not sure, all right?

574
00:27:50.855 --> 00:27:54.130
Utilize the talents of the people
that you have around there.

575
00:27:54.130 --> 00:27:56.430
Be willing to say, I don't know.

576
00:27:56.430 --> 00:27:58.784
Now implementing the solution,
we know what that is.

577
00:27:58.784 --> 00:28:01.290
But I do want you to understand this.

578
00:28:01.290 --> 00:28:03.800
Cherokee, I don't know if you've done
this, and I'm guilty of this guy.

579
00:28:03.800 --> 00:28:06.480
So do as I say not as I do,
I'm guilty of this.

580
00:28:06.480 --> 00:28:09.080
Have you ever made two or
three changes to something and

one of those changes fixed it?

582
00:28:10.680 --> 00:28:12.076
>> Yeah.
>> But you couldn't figure out which one

583
00:28:12.076 --> 00:28:12.850
of those changes?

584
00:28:12.850 --> 00:28:15.815
>> I don't know why it's broken,
I don't know why it's fixed.

585
00:28:15.815 --> 00:28:17.530
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Exactly,

586
00:28:17.530 --> 00:28:20.060
now as much as we're joking
around it does happen.

587
00:28:20.060 --> 00:28:23.430
So here's one thing that I would say and
take this piece of advice.

588
00:28:23.430 --> 00:28:24.360
I've learned to do it now [LAUGH] but

589
00:28:24.360 --> 00:28:27.039
I wish I would have
learned it a lot earlier.

590
00:28:28.210 --> 00:28:30.690
Make one change, test.

591
00:28:30.690 --> 00:28:31.920
Did that fix it?

592
00:28:31.920 --> 00:28:35.900
If it fixed it, document it right there
that that change is what fixed it.

593
00:28:35.900 --> 00:28:37.390
It didn't fix it?

594
00:28:37.390 --> 00:28:40.130
Undo that change and
move to the next one and

595
00:28:40.130 --> 00:28:42.810
implement that solution if
you think it's a solution.

596
00:28:42.810 --> 00:28:44.210
Did that change fix it?

597
00:28:44.210 --> 00:28:48.010
Well, if it did again document it and
we'll move to the next step.

598
00:28:49.160 --> 00:28:51.206
Make one change and then find out.

599
00:28:51.206 --> 00:28:52.389
Don't make a series of changes.

600
00:28:52.389 --> 00:28:55.308
And then at the end, like Cherokee said,
I don't know what the problem was.

601
00:28:55.308 --> 00:28:57.850
And, even worse,
I don't know what the solution is either.

602
00:28:57.850 --> 00:28:59.571
That's not gonna be
a good day at the office.

603
00:28:59.571 --> 00:29:00.091
All right,

604
00:29:00.091 --> 00:29:03.160
the other thing too is you might have
to reverse that change too again.

605
00:29:03.160 --> 00:29:06.912
If you go through that process and
it doesn't fix it, all right?

606
00:29:06.912 --> 00:29:09.024
>> And
that leads us into our next step here.

607
00:29:09.024 --> 00:29:12.484
What if you experience that same
problem on someone else's computer and

00:29:12.484 --> 00:29:13.683

609
00:29:13.683 --> 00:29:15.387
And you're like, hm,
I don't know what I did.

610
00:29:15.387 --> 00:29:16.715
Now I have to fix that again.

611
00:29:16.715 --> 00:29:19.039
Or worse,
what if your partner has to fix it and

612
00:29:19.039 --> 00:29:21.851
you don't have anything documented for
them, right?

613
00:29:21.851 --> 00:29:24.115
>> Documentation is definitely key.

614
00:29:24.115 --> 00:29:26.408
However we do have one more
that we have to keep in mind.

615
00:29:26.408 --> 00:29:27.728
>> Did I skip one?
>> That's okay.

616
00:29:27.728 --> 00:29:28.641
>> Man.
[LAUGH]

617
00:29:28.641 --> 00:29:29.915
>> It's in the myriad, and

00:29:29.915 --> 00:29:32.710
this is one that I would
say is very important.

619
00:29:32.710 --> 00:29:35.300
And I'm gonna change it
up just a little bit too.

620
00:29:35.300 --> 00:29:40.020
Verify full system functionality, and
if possible, applicable they like to say,

621
00:29:40.020 --> 00:29:41.970
sounds like insurance terms.

622
00:29:41.970 --> 00:29:43.504
And preventative measures, right?

623
00:29:43.504 --> 00:29:46.356
So, if we know that it

00:29:46.356 --> 00:29:50.390
We didn't have enough circulation in our
server closet because somebody closed off

00:29:50.390 --> 00:29:51.878

00:29:51.878 --> 00:29:54.220
Or whatever the case may be.

627
00:29:54.220 --> 00:29:57.120
Can we implement a preventative measure
that says, don't do that again?

628
00:29:57.120 --> 00:29:57.700
Don't do that.

629
00:29:57.700 --> 00:30:00.500
Is it the fact that our climate
control system was failing?

630
00:30:00.500 --> 00:30:01.550
Preventative measures?

631
00:30:01.550 --> 00:30:03.430
Implement one that's not, [LAUGH] right?

632
00:30:03.430 --> 00:30:04.850
So do keep that in mind.

633
00:30:04.850 --> 00:30:07.690
The other thing too, again,

00:30:07.690 --> 00:30:09.849

00:30:11.330 --> 00:30:12.453
A fix is never a fix or

a solution to a problem until

637
00:30:16.100 --> 00:30:17.746
Because you might know that
you fixed the problem.

638
00:30:17.746 --> 00:30:19.999
But until that end user verifies.

639
00:30:19.999 --> 00:30:21.337
And you might not be
dealing with end users.

640
00:30:21.337 --> 00:30:25.520
This might be something that is
just your coworkers next to you.

641
00:30:25.520 --> 00:30:27.980
When you verify the full system
functionality, all right.

642
00:30:27.980 --> 00:30:31.500
>> It's so ironic that I actually skipped
that one because a lot of people tend to

00:30:31.500 --> 00:30:32.680

And like you said,
just interacting with that person,

If you would have asked that end user

00:30:41.324 --> 00:30:43.536
it almost solidifies that process.

648
00:30:43.536 --> 00:30:46.215
Because there, yep,

649
00:30:46.215 --> 00:30:47.686

00:30:47.686 --> 00:30:48.903

00:30:48.903 --> 00:30:52.432

00:30:52.432 --> 00:30:53.586
the customer was happy.

653
00:30:53.586 --> 00:30:55.292
>> [LAUGH]
>> But document everything.

654
00:30:55.292 --> 00:31:00.223
Document steps that you took, your
findings, the information that you gather,

00:31:00.223 --> 00:31:02.600

00:31:02.600 --> 00:31:04.890

Now you might have to, this might be part

00:31:08.509 --> 00:31:11.630
Again a trouble ticketing system,

659

patch management, however it falls under.

00:31:14.108 --> 00:31:16.349
It could all be under some kind of policy.

661
00:31:16.349 --> 00:31:17.964
But if you are doing this for yourself.

00:31:17.964 --> 00:31:21.168
Maybe you're getting a certification
exam because you wanna go out,

00:31:21.168 --> 00:31:22.808
maybe do some of this for yourself.

664
00:31:22.808 --> 00:31:25.147
Still document, document and document.

665
00:31:25.147 --> 00:31:29.462
Because what happens is over time, just
like Cherokee was alluding to earlier.

666
00:31:29.462 --> 00:31:31.259
This happens on somebody else's computer.

667
00:31:31.259 --> 00:31:34.900
Wouldn't it be nice to just say okay,

668
00:31:34.900 --> 00:31:37.870
Okay, I did this, x, y, z, okay, fixed.

669
00:31:37.870 --> 00:31:40.670

the beginning and start all over again?

670
00:31:40.670 --> 00:31:41.586

00:31:41.586 --> 00:31:43.910

00:31:43.910 --> 00:31:47.500
So make sure that you document
your settings as well.

673
00:31:47.500 --> 00:31:50.560

the actions, and the outcomes.

674
00:31:50.560 --> 00:31:55.243
Keep in mind all of the resources
that you've utilized as well.

675
00:31:55.243 --> 00:32:00.826

that whatever the problem might be.

676
00:32:00.826 --> 00:32:04.095

have solved it as well.

00:32:04.095 --> 00:32:05.185

00:32:16.335 --> 00:32:17.930

683
00:32:17.930 --> 00:32:21.100

tuning in, but stay tuned.

684
00:32:21.100 --> 00:32:23.430

685
00:32:23.430 --> 00:32:26.910
