00:19:47.270 --> 00:19:49.140
now you have a communication
error on your network.

353
00:19:50.670 --> 00:19:54.300
All right so I'm gonna lens a couple of
things that we talked about I just wanna

354
00:19:54.300 --> 00:19:56.840
make sure that we do touch base with that.

355
00:19:56.840 --> 00:19:58.780
They talk about things like throughput,

356
00:19:58.780 --> 00:20:01.330
again remember we talked about
the difference between bandwidth and

357
00:20:01.330 --> 00:20:05.290
throughput, bandwidth is the theoretical
capacity of your network, right.

358
00:20:05.290 --> 00:20:08.430
How much information at one
time could you potentially put?

359
00:20:08.430 --> 00:20:11.310
If I've got a gigabit Ethernet network,

360
00:20:11.310 --> 00:20:15.050
it doesn't necessarily mean that I
get gigabit Ethernet speeds, right.

361
00:20:15.050 --> 00:20:18.930
It jut means that theoretically if I
could saturate the entire network,

362
00:20:18.930 --> 00:20:22.070
my bandwidth would give me
that ability to do a gigabit.

363
00:20:22.070 --> 00:20:27.000
When I run a protocol analyzer, when I run
a speed test on it, I see it's a gigabit,

364
00:20:27.000 --> 00:20:29.340
but it's running at 400
megabits per second.

365
00:20:29.340 --> 00:20:31.810
Well, that 400 megabits isn't
the theoretical bandwidth,

366
00:20:31.810 --> 00:20:34.310
that's the throughput,
that's what's actually happening.

367
00:20:34.310 --> 00:20:36.040
Remember, distance,
we've talked about that.

368
00:20:36.040 --> 00:20:38.980
Know your standards so
you know what distances they get.

369
00:20:38.980 --> 00:20:42.350
Keep in mind that just because you
increase the power levels on your access

370
00:20:42.350 --> 00:20:45.500
points, doesn't necessarily mean that
you're gonna get a greater coverage area.

371
00:20:45.500 --> 00:20:52.950
Channels themselves, remember a lot
of times they're auto switching.

372
00:20:52.950 --> 00:20:55.920
To take care of things
like channel congestion,

373
00:20:55.920 --> 00:21:00.860
you might have to manually change
the channels in order to combat that.

374
00:21:00.860 --> 00:21:05.970
And frequencies, again, Most commonly
what we use today 2.4 gigaHertz and

375
00:21:05.970 --> 00:21:09.720
5 gigaHertz, know your standard, so you
know if your device has been connecting,

376
00:21:09.720 --> 00:21:11.820
you might be using the wrong standard.

377
00:21:11.820 --> 00:21:14.710
>> Well we definitely do see
a wider range of problems that

378
00:21:14.710 --> 00:21:17.730
can occur with other wireless
networks versus our wired networks.

379
00:21:17.730 --> 00:21:20.990
So thank you Wes for taking the time to
explain those and of course our standards.

380
00:21:20.990 --> 00:21:22.250
Gotta love those.

381
00:21:22.250 --> 00:21:24.760
And thank you ladies and
gentlemen for joining us today.

382
00:21:24.760 --> 00:21:27.760
But stay tuned,
we do have more Net+ headed your way.

383
00:21:27.760 --> 00:21:30.910
For this show, I'm gonna go ahead and
sign out as your host, I'm Cherokee Boose.

384
00:21:30.910 --> 00:21:31.820
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

385
00:21:31.820 --> 00:21:33.293
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

386
00:21:33.293 --> 00:21:42.562
[MUSIC]

387
00:21:42.562 --> 00:21:44.402
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes help you to troubleshoot and resolve common copper cable issues. Issues covered include shorts in the cable, Opens Impedance Mismatches, Incorrect Termination, Cross-Talk, and Attenuation. They also demonstrate the use of a cable tester to verify cable type and/or integrity.
episodes.title: Common Copper Issues
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.445
Welcome to ITPROTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.445 --> 00:00:08.207
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.207 --> 00:00:11.012
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.400 --> 00:00:13.940
>> All right greetings everyone and

5
00:00:13.940 --> 00:00:16.680
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.680 --> 00:00:18.080
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

7
00:00:18.080 --> 00:00:21.310
in today's episode we are back
with more in our Network+ series.

8
00:00:21.310 --> 00:00:23.975
And of course joining me in
the studio again is our good friend,

9
00:00:23.975 --> 00:00:26.660
our guiding star in this endeavor,
this is Mr. Wesley Bryan.

10
00:00:26.660 --> 00:00:28.100
Wesley, welcome back, how's it going, man?

11
00:00:28.100 --> 00:00:30.440
>> Man it's going great thanks for
having me back down.

12
00:00:30.440 --> 00:00:31.850
It is a pleasure to be here.

13
00:00:31.850 --> 00:00:32.983
And that's right,

14
00:00:32.983 --> 00:00:37.254
we are going to move through our wonderful
Net+ series that we have been in.

15
00:00:37.254 --> 00:00:40.999
And we are gonna be looking at some
things that affect copper cablings.

16
00:00:40.999 --> 00:00:44.989
Since copper cabling is one of
the most prevalent medias today inside

17
00:00:44.989 --> 00:00:46.449
of local area networks.

18
00:00:46.449 --> 00:00:48.283
It is something that you could encounter.

19
00:00:48.283 --> 00:00:51.724
And you might need to know a little
bit about, much more so for

20
00:00:51.724 --> 00:00:53.290
the certifications exam.

21
00:00:53.290 --> 00:00:56.940
So, we're gonna take a look
at specifically copper.

22
00:00:56.940 --> 00:01:00.844
There are some other one that will look
at things like network devices and

23
00:01:00.844 --> 00:01:03.352
logical problems versus physical problems.

24
00:01:03.352 --> 00:01:06.235
Well I guess this is a physical
problem cuz it's the copper media.

25
00:01:06.235 --> 00:01:09.531
But we'll also look at fiber
in other episodes as well so,

26
00:01:09.531 --> 00:01:11.763
that is what we are gonna look at today.

27
00:01:11.763 --> 00:01:14.789
So one of the first things
they call out are shorts.

28
00:01:14.789 --> 00:01:16.932
And when it comes to a short, guys,

29
00:01:16.932 --> 00:01:20.515
really that is just the fact
that the cable could be broken.

30
00:01:20.515 --> 00:01:22.315
And it's not receiving a signal.

31
00:01:22.315 --> 00:01:24.342
It could be something that's intermittent.

32
00:01:24.342 --> 00:01:26.125
And that I probably should go ahead and

33
00:01:26.125 --> 00:01:29.425
set the stage that some of these
issues could be intermittent issues.

34
00:01:29.425 --> 00:01:33.875
And it might be very hard to
troubleshoot if you don't apply

35
00:01:33.875 --> 00:01:37.440
the right troubleshooting
methodology to it.

36
00:01:37.440 --> 00:01:39.750
And we're gonna talk about
troubleshooting as well, and

37
00:01:39.750 --> 00:01:41.380
that methodology in another episode.

38
00:01:41.380 --> 00:01:44.980
But I do wanna kinda bring
it back to the OSI model.

39
00:01:44.980 --> 00:01:47.683
See, we talk a lot about the OSI model,
and

40
00:01:47.683 --> 00:01:50.931
we pretty much just talk
about things like theory.

41
00:01:50.931 --> 00:01:55.286
And everybody thinks that I need
to know this for the Net+ exam.

42
00:01:55.286 --> 00:01:59.291
But then once I know that model and
I've passed the exam.

43
00:01:59.291 --> 00:02:00.258
Can I go ahead and

44
00:02:00.258 --> 00:02:04.640
just not think about that theoretical
seven layer model anymore?

45
00:02:04.640 --> 00:02:08.190
Well, you got to understand that the OSI
model there can also be used for

46
00:02:08.190 --> 00:02:09.780
troubleshooting as well.

47
00:02:09.780 --> 00:02:13.870
I know that one of our other hosts
here that is at ITProTV anytime I say,

48
00:02:13.870 --> 00:02:15.720
hey I'm having an issue with such and
such.

49
00:02:15.720 --> 00:02:19.360
The first thing he tells me is he says,
well, have you checked the physical layer?

50
00:02:19.360 --> 00:02:19.950
And you gotta think.

51
00:02:19.950 --> 00:02:21.180
Well, what is the physical layer?

52
00:02:21.180 --> 00:02:23.540
And that's things like your cables, right?

53
00:02:23.540 --> 00:02:28.440
The copper media, I can look at things
like light status or network adapter.

54
00:02:28.440 --> 00:02:30.970
Is the network adapter
even in the machine?

55
00:02:30.970 --> 00:02:34.419
So this is definitely gonna be
troubleshooting at the physical layer of

56
00:02:34.419 --> 00:02:35.173
the OSI model.

57
00:02:35.173 --> 00:02:36.444
And it's gonna be very important.

58
00:02:36.444 --> 00:02:38.304
Again, keep in mind things like shorts.

59
00:02:38.304 --> 00:02:43.079
Shorts might not manifest
themselves consistently, so

60
00:02:43.079 --> 00:02:46.066
they can be kinda hard to diagnose.

61
00:02:46.066 --> 00:02:49.334
The other thing they also call
out is open impedance mismatches.

62
00:02:49.334 --> 00:02:53.937
This was usually with things like when
you have older networks that would

63
00:02:53.937 --> 00:02:56.282
support things like coaxial cable.

64
00:02:56.282 --> 00:02:59.278
One of the things that could happen is
that you could have these impedance

65
00:02:59.278 --> 00:02:59.877
mismatches.

66
00:02:59.877 --> 00:03:02.935
And a lot of the times it's that
they were improper termination.

67
00:03:02.935 --> 00:03:09.928
And when a signal is sent down a medium
if you will and it's not terminated,

68
00:03:09.928 --> 00:03:14.930
then what you get is that
abrupt change in impedance.

69
00:03:14.930 --> 00:03:19.170
And what happen is the signal reflects
back to its originating source.

70
00:03:19.170 --> 00:03:23.803
And you can imagine in those earlier
networks that were already contention

71
00:03:23.803 --> 00:03:25.063
based, CSMA-CD.

72
00:03:25.063 --> 00:03:28.185
Again, one person talks, everybody hears.

73
00:03:28.185 --> 00:03:31.863
That any kind of signal reflection on
one of those coaxial cables could be

74
00:03:31.863 --> 00:03:32.777
a really bad day.

75
00:03:32.777 --> 00:03:37.619
And it really could bring the whole entire
network down to a crawl if not completely

76
00:03:37.619 --> 00:03:38.920
bring them offline.

77
00:03:38.920 --> 00:03:42.170
Because if a signal bounces off,
right, well then

78
00:03:42.170 --> 00:03:45.740
it's just gonna stay on that wire and
it's gonna stay on that wire indefinitely.

79
00:03:45.740 --> 00:03:47.650
And that's the purpose of termination, and

80
00:03:47.650 --> 00:03:50.060
that's probably something
that we should explain.

81
00:03:50.060 --> 00:03:51.250
Why is this happening?

82
00:03:51.250 --> 00:03:55.280
Well it really starts with
the terminator in itself right.

83
00:03:55.280 --> 00:03:56.340
The terminator what does it do?

84
00:03:56.340 --> 00:04:01.400
Well as that signal, that unprocess signal
comes down the end of that cable and

85
00:04:01.400 --> 00:04:04.590
it hits the resistor essentially,
what does it do?

86
00:04:04.590 --> 00:04:09.230
Well the resistor just absorbs it,
right, it just absorbs that signal so

87
00:04:09.230 --> 00:04:10.830
it doesn't bounce back.

88
00:04:10.830 --> 00:04:12.440
But if there's an impedance mismatch,

89
00:04:12.440 --> 00:04:16.140
the moment it hits that mismatch,
it reflects and goes back to the source.

90
00:04:16.140 --> 00:04:20.550
So these are things that can
manifest themselves in a network

91
00:04:20.550 --> 00:04:23.340
basically operating very, very poorly.

92
00:04:23.340 --> 00:04:26.270
And it's one of those things that you
might have to get some kind of cable

93
00:04:26.270 --> 00:04:28.315
tester put on it to be
able to identify it.

94
00:04:28.315 --> 00:04:29.210
>> Yeah, Wes,

95
00:04:29.210 --> 00:04:34.320
termination of the inside cables can cause
a myriad of different types of problems.

96
00:04:34.320 --> 00:04:36.880
The fact that you've used
maybe a different standard.

97
00:04:36.880 --> 00:04:40.850
Go down the list, actually, Wes, I think
you have an actual list of things that can

98
00:04:40.850 --> 00:04:42.790
go wrong when you terminate incorrectly.

99
00:04:42.790 --> 00:04:45.630
>> Definitely,
here's one that Dan's alluding to.

100
00:04:45.630 --> 00:04:51.678
You see, a lot of the older networking
cables, they relied on 50 ohm resistors.

101
00:04:51.678 --> 00:04:56.387
Most of the cabling that we have today
that's still coaxial are things like the,

102
00:04:56.387 --> 00:04:59.374
even though I know it's kinda dated now,
RG59.

103
00:04:59.374 --> 00:05:03.370
And we use RG6 more commonly today
in things like cable television.

104
00:05:04.775 --> 00:05:10.005
And cable modems,
they rely on 75 ohm resistors.

105
00:05:10.005 --> 00:05:13.335
So there could be an impedance
mismatch improperly terminating,

106
00:05:13.335 --> 00:05:17.700
happen to be put in a 75 ohm
resistor on a 50 ohm cable, right?

107
00:05:17.700 --> 00:05:24.570
So, your resistance has to match the
electrical characteristics of the cable.

108
00:05:24.570 --> 00:05:25.850
Now I say that,

109
00:05:25.850 --> 00:05:30.450
Dan I know that you guys have probably
got a cable modem at your house.

110
00:05:30.450 --> 00:05:32.210
>> Yep.
>> Have you ever seen the resistors?

111
00:05:32.210 --> 00:05:35.130
>> I have never seen the resistors, I
assume they're inside the cable modems and

112
00:05:35.130 --> 00:05:36.080
the end devices.

113
00:05:36.080 --> 00:05:37.630
>> You got it.
Knocked it out of the ball park.

114
00:05:37.630 --> 00:05:40.158
We usually don't have to deal with
them too much anymore because

115
00:05:40.158 --> 00:05:42.960
the devices themselves do
the termination today.

116
00:05:42.960 --> 00:05:47.530
Again, if you have some kind of cabling
that has some kind of bend in it or

117
00:05:47.530 --> 00:05:50.750
has been crimped wrong,
you might see this as well.

118
00:05:50.750 --> 00:05:55.881
So open impedance mismatches again
usually cause signal reflection.

119
00:05:55.881 --> 00:05:58.496
Now, some of the other things
that they talk about, again,

120
00:05:58.496 --> 00:06:00.049
under the incorrect termination.

121
00:06:00.049 --> 00:06:03.270
Is more so like, for instance,
things that we do today.

122
00:06:03.270 --> 00:06:10.765
You remember in another episode, we talked
about the TIA/EIA-568 building standards.

123
00:06:10.765 --> 00:06:14.241
They define a wiring standard for
RJ45 jacks.

124
00:06:14.241 --> 00:06:20.225
Well we have to make sure that those jacks
are wired the right way on both sides.

125
00:06:20.225 --> 00:06:24.624
Improper termination means that
you could have for instance,

126
00:06:24.624 --> 00:06:29.560
568A on one side and
568B wiring scheme on the other side.

127
00:06:29.560 --> 00:06:33.512
Now if you expect it,
we call it a crossover cable, right?

128
00:06:33.512 --> 00:06:34.741
If you are using that,

129
00:06:34.741 --> 00:06:38.968
if you are plugging into a device or
doing a direct point to point connection.

130
00:06:38.968 --> 00:06:41.417
Let's say between your network adapter and
your laptop, and

131
00:06:41.417 --> 00:06:44.130
maybe an IP camera that
you're trying to service.

132
00:06:44.130 --> 00:06:46.881
That's okay,
that's not going to cause a problem.

133
00:06:46.881 --> 00:06:49.478
But, if you wire it wrong like that.

134
00:06:49.478 --> 00:06:52.009
If I just happen to grab
one of these cables here.

135
00:06:52.009 --> 00:06:55.148
And I have no clue and I don't look,
and I don't pay attention.

136
00:06:55.148 --> 00:06:56.687
And I plug it into the patch panel and

137
00:06:56.687 --> 00:06:58.954
maybe obviously this one's
not going to go too far.

138
00:06:58.954 --> 00:06:59.799
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] But

139
00:06:59.799 --> 00:07:01.600
I plug it into the other device, right?

140
00:07:01.600 --> 00:07:04.879
I don't understand why
aren't I getting any signal?

141
00:07:04.879 --> 00:07:08.427
Well that's because one side of
this could be wired up for 568A.

142
00:07:08.427 --> 00:07:11.259
And the other one, if somebody didn't
pay attention to what they're doing.

143
00:07:11.259 --> 00:07:17.075
And probably more often than not it would
be this one would be wired up to 568B.

144
00:07:17.075 --> 00:07:22.050
And somebody just comes along and
wires this side up to 568A.

145
00:07:22.050 --> 00:07:26.010
Now I will tell you something, if you're
buying your cables, right, they're precut,

146
00:07:26.010 --> 00:07:27.690
preterminated for you.

147
00:07:27.690 --> 00:07:29.380
A lot of times you don't
have to worry about it.

148
00:07:29.380 --> 00:07:31.882
All you have to do is look
at the side of the cable and

149
00:07:31.882 --> 00:07:36.004
it usually has some kind of little marking
on it that will tell you how it's wired.

150
00:07:36.004 --> 00:07:39.395
Again a lot of these patch cables and
stuff, okay.

151
00:07:39.395 --> 00:07:45.414
This one is 568B we can see right
on the side of this cable here.

152
00:07:45.414 --> 00:07:48.188
I know what the standard is.

153
00:07:48.188 --> 00:07:51.920
And if I'm familiar with the wiring
standard than I should be able to

154
00:07:51.920 --> 00:07:53.695
terminate the cable right now.

155
00:07:53.695 --> 00:07:57.231
I say sure and I can see Dan over here out
of the corner of my eye kind of laughing.

156
00:07:57.231 --> 00:08:02.571
Because I have this thing where I kinda
made up my own standard, the 568W.

157
00:08:02.571 --> 00:08:05.750
[CROSSTALK] That's right, and
you can hear it in the background there.

158
00:08:05.750 --> 00:08:10.845
And that's because, well, it's very
easy to do a wiring mismatch on it.

159
00:08:10.845 --> 00:08:14.160
And you can't figure out why it is that
your cable isn't working correctly.

160
00:08:14.160 --> 00:08:17.730
>> Yeah, I know a lot of guys that they
just say you know what, I learned 568A,

161
00:08:17.730 --> 00:08:19.000
and that's all I'm ever gonna wire.

162
00:08:19.000 --> 00:08:21.465
If I do a wiring job it's all 568A.

163
00:08:21.465 --> 00:08:23.962
Everybody that works for me uses 568A.

164
00:08:23.962 --> 00:08:26.290
They never deviate for that very reason.

165
00:08:26.290 --> 00:08:29.173
Wes, just a quick question,
maybe you know the answer to this.

166
00:08:29.173 --> 00:08:32.347
If I wire 568A on this wire and
I plug a node in to it and

167
00:08:32.347 --> 00:08:35.943
I wire 568B on this wire and
I plug a different node into it.

168
00:08:35.943 --> 00:08:37.410
Are they going to be able to talk?

169
00:08:37.410 --> 00:08:39.140
>> Well they should be
able to talk just fine.

170
00:08:39.140 --> 00:08:42.025
Really, unless it's a networking device.

171
00:08:42.025 --> 00:08:45.694
Because the networking device is expecting
what's known as a straight through cable.

172
00:08:45.694 --> 00:08:50.291
And it supports a functionality that
actually does the twist inside for

173
00:08:50.291 --> 00:08:53.675
us, doing the forwarding between ports and
stuff.

174
00:08:53.675 --> 00:08:56.992
So if I have one of those 568A and
568B and

175
00:08:56.992 --> 00:09:01.085
they're basically connected
to two network adapters.

176
00:09:01.085 --> 00:09:03.175
You've created a point-to-point
connection, right?

177
00:09:03.175 --> 00:09:05.335
In the earlier days,
prior to having our ethernet,

178
00:09:05.335 --> 00:09:08.795
we would use our RS-232 no
modem cables to do this, right?

179
00:09:08.795 --> 00:09:10.926
And that would be a serial
point-to-point connection.

180
00:09:10.926 --> 00:09:14.285
Now, because we're not using those
serial connectors for the most part,

181
00:09:14.285 --> 00:09:16.055
we still use console cables and stuff.

182
00:09:16.055 --> 00:09:18.104
But they're a little bit
different in how they're wired.

183
00:09:18.104 --> 00:09:20.120
We can make those point
to point connections.

184
00:09:20.120 --> 00:09:23.250
And I'll tell you like I said in
an example that I had to use up.

185
00:09:23.250 --> 00:09:26.509
Again we had,
in a former company that I worked for,

186
00:09:26.509 --> 00:09:28.590
they got a bunch of these IP cams.

187
00:09:28.590 --> 00:09:31.473
And they got them at a discount
cuz the company had gone under or

188
00:09:31.473 --> 00:09:32.536
something like that.

47
00:02:18.400 --> 00:02:20.970

48
00:02:20.970 --> 00:02:24.012

00:02:24.012 --> 00:02:27.370

it calls back it says no no no no no,

51
00:02:30.620 --> 00:02:36.478
And what happens to the computer,
that's the one that's causing the problem.

52
00:02:36.478 --> 00:02:40.800

down and in Windows, for instance,

54

So those are some things that can affect
things like end-to-end connectivity.

55
00:02:51.040 --> 00:02:52.820
Now I did mention in that first episode,

Remember that when we talk about broadcast
storms, what we're talking about is for

61

If a broadcast is sent into
the to the port of a switch,

62
00:03:10.500 --> 00:03:14.440
well, a switch is gonna just

63
00:03:14.440 --> 00:03:17.630
Keep in mind the broadcast traffic kind
of makes a switch act like a hub, right?

64
00:03:17.630 --> 00:03:20.600
Broadcasting communications
out all their ports.

65
00:03:20.600 --> 00:03:23.090
Well, the problem is what if
another switch picks up, right?

66
00:03:23.090 --> 00:03:27.040
Making multiple switches in a network and
the other switch picks up that broadcast.

67
00:03:27.040 --> 00:03:28.380
Well, what is it gonna do?

68
00:03:28.380 --> 00:03:30.810
It knows it needs to go to
that all f MAC address,

69
00:03:30.810 --> 00:03:34.770
which is the broadcast MAC address, and
then it broadcasts out all other ports.

70
00:03:34.770 --> 00:03:36.730
And eventually what you get is
this broadcast storm that can

71
00:03:36.730 --> 00:03:38.390
really cripple your network.

72
00:03:38.390 --> 00:03:42.320
So we implement things like spanning tree
algorithm or spanning tree protocol.

73
00:03:42.320 --> 00:03:44.100
And it goes through this process,

74
00:03:44.100 --> 00:03:46.990
an election process where it
has a root bridge, right?

75
00:03:46.990 --> 00:03:49.790
And the root bridge is the top
of part of the tree hierarchy.

76
00:03:49.790 --> 00:03:53.080
And then it goes through
a process of electing which

77
00:03:53.080 --> 00:03:56.360
ports on the switch can actually
forward traffic and some can't, right?

78
00:03:56.360 --> 00:03:59.670
So that breaks up that broadcast storm.

79
00:03:59.670 --> 00:04:02.010
So we don't have broadcast
continuing on our network,

80
00:04:02.010 --> 00:04:04.490
bringing our network to crippling it.

81

I also mentioned routing loops, too.

And routing loops,
we're talking a little bit more,

83
00:04:08.060 --> 00:04:09.900
a little bit higher than the OSI model,
right.

84
00:04:09.900 --> 00:04:11.280
We're talking about layer three.

85
00:04:11.280 --> 00:04:16.250
So let's go ahead and
take a look at my computer here.

86
00:04:16.250 --> 00:04:19.110
Now, what the goal is look for
a routing, right?

87
00:04:19.110 --> 00:04:22.170
We want all our communications
going across the network and

88
00:04:22.170 --> 00:04:28.250
we don't wanna just cycling around to
infinity, if you will, on our network.

89
00:04:28.250 --> 00:04:29.690
That's the ultimate goal,

90
00:04:29.690 --> 00:04:33.140
but distance vector protocols
are very acceptable to routing loops.

91
00:04:33.140 --> 00:04:36.390
And that's because the way they
communicate is by doing router

92

advertisement messages, right?

93

In a distance vector protocol, what we do
is we're talking to our nearest neighbors.

94
00:04:43.560 --> 00:04:48.160
And it's a little inconvenient in the fact
that we're always broadcasting the entire

95
00:04:48.160 --> 00:04:49.810
routing table every 45 seconds.

96
00:04:49.810 --> 00:04:52.300
So for instance,
router one is gonna talk to router two and

97
00:04:52.300 --> 00:04:54.450

00:19:52.280 --> 00:19:56.090
That will give you signs of errors because
of the fact that the signal's attenuating.

399
00:19:56.090 --> 00:19:58.420
So you also have those as well.

400
00:19:58.420 --> 00:20:00.850
Again, those-
>> It might work but

401
00:20:00.850 --> 00:20:02.040
you're gonna need to fix it.

402
00:20:02.040 --> 00:20:03.942
You gotta love those intermittent issues,
right?

403
00:20:03.942 --> 00:20:08.388
>> Yeah, and that's one of those
things that if it does happen,

404
00:20:08.388 --> 00:20:13.020
you might even be able to see
the interface errors at that point.

405
00:20:13.020 --> 00:20:14.650
So those are some of the things.

406
00:20:14.650 --> 00:20:18.690
Like I said this is really
a repeat of a lot of the stuff

407
00:20:18.690 --> 00:20:23.290
that we've talked about in other issues or
other areas with networking issues.

408
00:20:23.290 --> 00:20:29.302
Just keep in mind that in this episode
we're talking more on the ISP side.

409
00:20:29.302 --> 00:20:32.369
Pay the bill, pay attention to
the service level contracts, and

410
00:20:32.369 --> 00:20:34.283
get ahold of them if it's the local ISP.

411
00:20:34.283 --> 00:20:36.706
If it happens to be more of
the Internet backbone providers,

412
00:20:36.706 --> 00:20:39.853
a lot of times there's nothing you can
do there, you just have to live with it.

413
00:20:39.853 --> 00:20:42.457
They've got the best network
technicians in the world.

414
00:20:42.457 --> 00:20:45.612
And if you're discovering that you're
having a problem chances are they knew

415
00:20:45.612 --> 00:20:47.380
about it before you ever got to it.

416
00:20:47.380 --> 00:20:50.660
>> And usually people kind of,
during your career path you'll choose.

417
00:20:50.660 --> 00:20:52.876
Do I want to be a local
area network administrator,

418
00:20:52.876 --> 00:20:54.431
wide area network administrator?

419
00:20:54.431 --> 00:20:57.503
And that's really because I dunno if
you've heard that saying a jack of all

420
00:20:57.503 --> 00:20:58.643
trades is a master of none.

421
00:20:58.643 --> 00:21:02.071
Because they're really dealing with
a lot of different protocols and

422
00:21:02.071 --> 00:21:03.125
design techniques.

423
00:21:03.125 --> 00:21:07.340
That are well, just really different than
what we see on our local area networks.

424
00:21:07.340 --> 00:21:09.260
So if that's something
that you're interested in,

425
00:21:09.260 --> 00:21:11.720
then definitely spend more
time looking into that.

426
00:21:11.720 --> 00:21:14.030
But I think that's about it for
this episode.

427
00:21:14.030 --> 00:21:14.712
All right, Wes?
>> Absolutely.

428
00:21:14.712 --> 00:21:16.627
>> All right, so
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

429
00:21:16.627 --> 00:21:17.631
Remember, I'm Cherokee Boose.

430
00:21:17.631 --> 00:21:18.479
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

431
00:21:18.479 --> 00:21:21.829
>> See you next time here on ITProTV.

432

433
00:21:27.826 --> 00:21:29.810
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore and explain the venerable Open Systems Interconnect(OSI) model's 7 layers. They take you through each of the layers explaining the purpose and function of each which helps you understand the common communications framework that modern networks utilize.
episodes.title: OSI Model
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.177
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.177 --> 00:00:02.358
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.358 --> 00:00:06.383
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.383 --> 00:00:08.186
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.186 --> 00:00:12.687
>> You're watching ITProTV
>> All right,

6
00:00:12.687 --> 00:00:17.265
greetings, everyone, and welcome to
another exciting episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:17.265 --> 00:00:18.755
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

8
00:00:18.755 --> 00:00:23.555
in today's episode we are moving on with
more on our Network+ series for CompTIA.

9
00:00:23.555 --> 00:00:27.620
And, of course, joining us in the studio,
lending his expertise on that very topic,

10
00:00:27.620 --> 00:00:29.450
our good friend, Mr. Wes Bryan.

11
00:00:29.450 --> 00:00:30.280
Wes, welcome back, sir.

12
00:00:30.280 --> 00:00:31.160
How's it going today?

13
00:00:31.160 --> 00:00:33.050
>> Man, it's going great,
thanks for having me back.

14
00:00:33.050 --> 00:00:34.820
Always a pleasure to be here with ITProTV.

15
00:00:34.820 --> 00:00:36.821
That's right.
We are diving into theory and

16
00:00:36.821 --> 00:00:40.200
that's what our episode is
going to be about today.

17
00:00:40.200 --> 00:00:44.610
It's going to be about a seven,
an abstract seven layer model that

18
00:00:44.610 --> 00:00:47.920
goes all the way back to the 80s,
called the OSI model.

19
00:00:47.920 --> 00:00:52.330
And if you haven't heard of that that is
the Open Systems Interconnection model.

20
00:00:52.330 --> 00:00:56.120
Actually the whole thing is the reference
model for Open System Interconnection.

21
00:00:56.120 --> 00:00:58.140
>> Created by the ISO,
if I'm not mistaken, that's fun.

22
00:00:58.140 --> 00:00:58.952
>> Absolutely, and

23
00:00:58.952 --> 00:01:02.318
you know what's interesting is that's
how I would remember on the exam.

24
00:01:02.318 --> 00:01:03.451
>> It was a mirror-image backwards.

25
00:01:03.451 --> 00:01:05.507
The ISO, OSI.

26
00:01:05.507 --> 00:01:06.694
>> That's it.
>> And what does that mean?

27
00:01:06.694 --> 00:01:10.260
[LAUGH] Well that's the International
Organization for Standardization.

28
00:01:10.260 --> 00:01:12.680
And it's funny,
I always thought about their acronym,

29
00:01:12.680 --> 00:01:15.150
International Organization for
Standardization.

30
00:01:15.150 --> 00:01:16.800
Why isn't it IOS?

31
00:01:16.800 --> 00:01:22.820
Well, it actually gets its acronym
there from a Greek word, isos, I-S-O-S.

32
00:01:22.820 --> 00:01:24.950
I believe it means equality or equal.

33
00:01:24.950 --> 00:01:28.890
So that was their method
to their naming convention.

34
00:01:28.890 --> 00:01:31.510
But why do we have the OSI model?

35
00:01:31.510 --> 00:01:34.070
Why did it come about?

36
00:01:34.070 --> 00:01:37.530
Well, let's go ahead and
let's do the proverbial time machine and

37
00:01:37.530 --> 00:01:39.360
let's go back in time a little bit.

38
00:01:39.360 --> 00:01:42.870
In the earlier days of what we
would later call the Internet,

39
00:01:42.870 --> 00:01:46.170
there were many different
companies out there and

40
00:01:46.170 --> 00:01:51.720
every company had the next latest,
greatest communications technology.

41
00:01:51.720 --> 00:01:54.060
But the problem is none of them
were talking to each other.

42
00:01:54.060 --> 00:01:58.250
So if you did happen to buy a certain
communication technology by a certain

43
00:01:58.250 --> 00:01:59.240
company, well, guess what?

44
00:01:59.240 --> 00:02:02.910
That means everything that you bought
would have to come through them.

45
00:02:02.910 --> 00:02:05.790
And if you needed some kind of
interoperability between another vender,

46
00:02:05.790 --> 00:02:08.370
well, you would hope that those
vendors were talking to each other.

47
00:02:08.370 --> 00:02:11.010
Well, that's not exactly
the way it happened.

48
00:02:11.010 --> 00:02:14.930
So we had a lot of people,
all different components,

49
00:02:14.930 --> 00:02:19.280
on networking with none of them
actually being able to work together.

50
00:02:19.280 --> 00:02:22.400
So they said there were a couple
of committees at the time.

51
00:02:22.400 --> 00:02:25.590
The ISO was one of them.

52
00:02:25.590 --> 00:02:26.840
And I can't remember the other committee.

53
00:02:26.840 --> 00:02:31.830
But they were both working in 1983 on some
reference documentation for standardizing

54
00:02:31.830 --> 00:02:34.680
networks and what they did is they
basically said okay, we're gonna meet.

55
00:02:34.680 --> 00:02:35.620
We'll take both of these.

56
00:02:35.620 --> 00:02:39.630
We're gonna put them together and
ultimately that's what became the OSI.

57
00:02:39.630 --> 00:02:42.970
Now the OSI model it's,
they say interconnections.

58
00:02:42.970 --> 00:02:47.540
It's really a referencing framework,
if you will, to make sure that if you

59
00:02:47.540 --> 00:02:51.110
are following the framework that
you do have an interoperability.

60
00:02:51.110 --> 00:02:52.370
Hence, interconnection.

61
00:02:52.370 --> 00:02:55.360
So that's a little bit
about the history of it.

62
00:02:55.360 --> 00:02:57.480
Let's talk a little bit
more about what it is.

63
00:02:57.480 --> 00:03:03.080
Well, it is a seven layer model,
and in these seven layers, what you

64
00:03:03.080 --> 00:03:08.940
have are essentially services that service
layers below it and then below that.

65
00:03:08.940 --> 00:03:14.300
So if we talk about the highest layer,
the top layer there

66
00:03:14.300 --> 00:03:20.000
is going to be providing basically
handing off its information to a lower

67
00:03:20.000 --> 00:03:24.040
layer that's gonna service that upper
layer and then finally down the stack.

68
00:03:24.040 --> 00:03:26.730
So let's go ahead and
let's look at the OSI model.

69
00:03:26.730 --> 00:03:31.770
I got a little diagram drawn up here and
this is that seven layer model.

70
00:03:31.770 --> 00:03:36.700
You can see that working from Layer
7 all the way down to Layer 1,

71
00:03:36.700 --> 00:03:39.570
we start with something known
as the Application layer.

72
00:03:39.570 --> 00:03:42.740
Now guys, we're going to
cover each individual layer.

73
00:03:42.740 --> 00:03:44.790
I just want you to kinda step back and

74
00:03:44.790 --> 00:03:49.450
get the 10,000 foot overview before we
start dividing each of these layers up.

75
00:03:49.450 --> 00:03:53.150
The next layer, Layer 6,
that's gonna be the Presentation layer.

76
00:03:53.150 --> 00:03:56.260
And you can see Layer 5
is the Session layer.

77
00:03:56.260 --> 00:03:58.500
Layer 4 is the Transport layer.

78
00:03:58.500 --> 00:04:01.476
Down to the Network layer,
Data-Link layer, and the Physical layer.

79
00:04:01.476 --> 00:04:05.185
So when I say that these layers
help to assist each other,

80
00:04:05.185 --> 00:04:09.437
you'll see that Layer 7,
it puts its information in the data and

81
00:04:09.437 --> 00:04:12.711
then it passes it down to
the Presentation layer.

82
00:04:12.711 --> 00:04:17.011
The Presentation layer performs a service
on the data for the Application layer and

83
00:04:17.011 --> 00:04:20.120
then it passes the data
down to the Session layer.

84
00:04:20.120 --> 00:04:22.610
Well, the Session layer helps
the Presentation layer.

85
00:04:22.610 --> 00:04:26.910
So they're all collectively working
together to ensure that you have

86
00:04:26.910 --> 00:04:31.860
communications from source to
destination over your networks.

87
00:04:31.860 --> 00:04:34.190
So let's go ahead and
let's take this a little bit farther and

88
00:04:34.190 --> 00:04:36.300
start breaking down these layers.

89
00:04:36.300 --> 00:04:40.330
See if we can make a little bit more
sense out of the individuality of

90
00:04:40.330 --> 00:04:41.090
each layer here.

91
00:04:42.120 --> 00:04:44.320
All right, so when we start at Layer 7,

92
00:04:44.320 --> 00:04:48.070
here's some of the things that you can
think about when it comes to Layer 7.

93
00:04:48.070 --> 00:04:51.370
Layer 7 is where all, everything starts.

94
00:04:51.370 --> 00:04:53.300
Now when we talk about
where everything starts,

95
00:04:53.300 --> 00:04:57.060
you can see some of the examples that
we used I want you to think of email.

96
00:04:57.060 --> 00:05:01.750
When I send email there's data
within that packet, if you will, or

97
00:05:01.750 --> 00:05:05.910
that information within that
communication that you're gonna send.

98
00:05:05.910 --> 00:05:08.930
Well, in order to gain
access to the network,

99
00:05:08.930 --> 00:05:10.890
we have to go through
the Application layer.

100
00:05:10.890 --> 00:05:13.000
So the Application layer has protocols and

101
00:05:13.000 --> 00:05:17.950
services that allow us access
to the network, right?

102
00:05:17.950 --> 00:05:21.115
Some of the examples you'll see here and,
guys, there are a bunch of them.

103
00:05:21.115 --> 00:05:23.100
I'm just touching base with some of them.

104
00:05:23.100 --> 00:05:25.430
You have things like directory services,
right?

105
00:05:25.430 --> 00:05:28.650
LDAP, light weight directory access
protocol is one of those that

106
00:05:28.650 --> 00:05:31.150
is an application where your protocol,
right?

107
00:05:31.150 --> 00:05:31.760
What it is doing?

108
00:05:31.760 --> 00:05:35.860
Well, it's giving me a structured
rules of communication

109
00:05:35.860 --> 00:05:38.690
from myself to a directory
services database, right,

110
00:05:38.690 --> 00:05:45.200
something like Active Directory,
right, Active Directory open LDAP.

111
00:05:45.200 --> 00:05:47.205
Some different
implementations that you see.

112
00:05:47.205 --> 00:05:51.290
The next thing, for example,
you can see name resolution.

113
00:05:51.290 --> 00:05:53.830
Now with name resolution, we have DNS.

114
00:05:53.830 --> 00:05:59.020
DNS is a form,
an Application layer protocol, right?

115
00:05:59.020 --> 00:06:02.319
It's what allows us to resolve
names to IP addresses.

116
00:06:03.410 --> 00:06:04.910
Other examples, well,
I just went ahead and

117
00:06:04.910 --> 00:06:07.750
lumped the email protocols
all together there.

118
00:06:07.750 --> 00:06:10.710
They're all Application layer protocols,
right.

119
00:06:10.710 --> 00:06:12.650
You have IMAP, POP3, SMTP.

120
00:06:12.650 --> 00:06:16.667
Again, when I send information,
when I send an email,

121
00:06:16.667 --> 00:06:21.624
that program that is formulating
that message, and when I hit Send,

122
00:06:21.624 --> 00:06:25.996
the application is what's giving
me access to the network.

123
00:06:25.996 --> 00:06:29.232
All right, some of the other ones
here real quick that we have,

124
00:06:29.232 --> 00:06:31.530
things like Host Configuration (DHCP).

125
00:06:31.530 --> 00:06:34.371
DHCP is an Application
layer protocol as well.

126
00:06:34.371 --> 00:06:37.400
All right, you also have things
like Web Communications.

127
00:06:37.400 --> 00:06:40.556
One of the most common protocols that
we use out there on the Internet is

128
00:06:40.556 --> 00:06:41.261
HTTP, right?

129
00:06:41.261 --> 00:06:44.880
HTTP is another form of
an Application layer protocol.

130
00:06:44.880 --> 00:06:50.070
So what I want you to take away from the
Application layer, guys, is that it gives

131
00:06:50.070 --> 00:06:54.720
basically applications and different
user processes access to the network.

132
00:06:54.720 --> 00:06:57.880
It is our starting point in order to send

133
00:06:57.880 --> 00:06:59.990
information across
the network to a destination.

134
00:07:01.760 --> 00:07:06.160
All right, next one that we have here,
OSI Layer 6.

135
00:07:06.160 --> 00:07:10.503
All right, what this is kind of
interesting is that Layer 6,

136
00:07:10.503 --> 00:07:15.431
it helps our, it helps the network
by basically formatting our data in

137
00:07:15.431 --> 00:07:19.541
a syntax that the network
doesn't have to understand it.

138
00:07:19.541 --> 00:07:22.300
Right, so when we see like our letters,

139
00:07:22.300 --> 00:07:26.670
our way of different encoding schemes and
stuff like that.

140
00:07:26.670 --> 00:07:29.340
That's what we see and
that's what we recognize, right?

141
00:07:29.340 --> 00:07:32.030
If we were to take some of those encoding
schemes and those characters off, right,

142
00:07:32.030 --> 00:07:34.930
and if we were to change it up, we
wouldn't be able to read anything, right?

143
00:07:34.930 --> 00:07:37.680
Well, the network doesn't wanna
have to worry about that.

144
00:07:37.680 --> 00:07:41.240
The network should only, and
I literally mean the whole network,

145
00:07:41.240 --> 00:07:45.350
all it should have to worry about
is destination address, really.

146
00:07:45.350 --> 00:07:48.701
When we look at TCP IP, that's one of the
big things about TCP IP is we're really

147
00:07:48.701 --> 00:07:49.965
looking at the destination.

148
00:07:49.965 --> 00:07:52.271
How do I get that information
where I need to go?

149
00:07:52.271 --> 00:07:55.809
Well, I don't want the network to have
to figure out what language are they

150
00:07:55.809 --> 00:07:56.436
talking in?

151
00:07:56.436 --> 00:08:00.976
Right the other thing that you can see
here is encryption and decryption happen

152
00:08:00.976 --> 00:08:05.724
at the presentation layer.It's all about
formatting the data basically in a way

153
00:08:05.724 --> 00:08:10.090
that is has become transparent to
the networking portion of the OSI Model.

154
00:08:11.100 --> 00:08:12.550
Compression, decompression.

155
00:08:12.550 --> 00:08:13.440
I didn't put that one up there.

156
00:08:13.440 --> 00:08:14.030
But compression and

157
00:08:14.030 --> 00:08:18.840
decompression are another thing
that happens at the layer six.

158
00:08:18.840 --> 00:08:21.650
And you also have like
I said data conversion.

159
00:08:21.650 --> 00:08:26.950
Sometimes they will call this,
just call it the syntax layer.

160
00:08:26.950 --> 00:08:30.350
Cuz we're just formatting that information
so that we can put it on the network and

161
00:08:30.350 --> 00:08:31.940
again the network doesn't
have to deal with it.

162
00:08:31.940 --> 00:08:36.440
>> Plus, this is also where we would find
things like because we're presenting to

163
00:08:36.440 --> 00:08:41.840
the end user things like Jpegs and
gifs and any type of text, fonts,

164
00:08:41.840 --> 00:08:46.070
things that, anytime it's being presented
to an end user as in a visual format,

165
00:08:46.070 --> 00:08:47.630
that's what we mean by
the presentation layer.

166
00:08:47.630 --> 00:08:51.700
>> That's absolutely correct, Jpeg,
png, all of those tiffs, gifs,

167
00:08:51.700 --> 00:08:53.100
they're all a form of that.

168
00:08:53.100 --> 00:08:54.930
And another thing too when
we talk about encryption.

169
00:08:54.930 --> 00:08:57.980
You know since you mentioned
the format of the data.

170
00:08:57.980 --> 00:08:58.710
SMIME.

171
00:08:58.710 --> 00:09:00.460
>> Yeah.
>> MIME. Multi. What is it?

172
00:09:00.460 --> 00:09:03.040
Multi Internet Mail Extensions
is what the acronym.

173
00:09:03.040 --> 00:09:03.940
Right?

174
00:09:03.940 --> 00:09:05.380
We couple that with encryption.

175
00:09:05.380 --> 00:09:06.150
Right?

176
00:09:06.150 --> 00:09:07.195
SMIME.

177
00:09:07.195 --> 00:09:09.810
Encryption's is happening
up at this layer.

178
00:09:09.810 --> 00:09:12.710
And again formating that data
that male extensions right.

179
00:09:12.710 --> 00:09:14.090
Putting them two together
you got yes mind and

180
00:09:14.090 --> 00:09:19.290
you got secure multi internet male
extensions so yes absolutely.

181
00:09:19.290 --> 00:09:20.710
All right so let's go ahead and

182
00:09:20.710 --> 00:09:24.534
let's look we moving down the stack
here as they say the protocol stack.

183
00:09:24.534 --> 00:09:28.564
All right the next thing we
have is layer five, all right.

184
00:09:28.564 --> 00:09:32.910
Now layer five is interesting because
this is about session control, all right.

185
00:09:32.910 --> 00:09:36.440
Now I know that sounds, well Wes,
it's in the name, Session Control,

186
00:09:36.440 --> 00:09:38.240
well I could have guessed that
just by looking at the tape.

187
00:09:38.240 --> 00:09:39.270
What do you mean by that?

188
00:09:39.270 --> 00:09:43.300
Well when I need to establish
a communication with an endpoint This

189
00:09:43.300 --> 00:09:48.120
layer is what helps me create the session,
define the parameters of the session,

190
00:09:48.120 --> 00:09:51.230
maintaining it if you will, and
then terminating the session.

191
00:09:51.230 --> 00:09:54.960
All right, some of the examples
that you can see of information, or

192
00:09:54.960 --> 00:09:58.310
excuse me, technologies and
examples that happen at this layer.

00:21:29.520 --> 00:21:34.910
Let's just be clear on that,
that it also happens at Layer 4 as well.

425
00:21:34.910 --> 00:21:36.220
All right.

426
00:21:36.220 --> 00:21:37.370
Boy, isn't this confusing?

427
00:21:37.370 --> 00:21:38.690
>> This just got crazy today.

428
00:21:38.690 --> 00:21:40.210
>> What just happened here, right?

429
00:21:40.210 --> 00:21:44.064
No, Dan did not take a knife out and
cut this layer in half before we started.

430
00:21:44.064 --> 00:21:48.422
That was actually a decision that was made
to do a little bit better description of

431
00:21:48.422 --> 00:21:52.630
what was happening in what was
known as Layer 2 of the OSI model.

432
00:21:52.630 --> 00:21:56.051
All right, so Data-Link Layer's
got a couple of things going on.

433
00:21:56.051 --> 00:21:57.178
And really early on,

434
00:21:57.178 --> 00:22:01.260
they learned that it was doing a little
bit more than just a single thing here.

435
00:22:01.260 --> 00:22:04.510
So what they did is they broke it
up into two sub-layers, all right?

436
00:22:04.510 --> 00:22:08.328
These sub-layers that you have, one is
called the Media Access Control Layer,

437
00:22:08.328 --> 00:22:08.898
MAC Layer.

438
00:22:08.898 --> 00:22:13.848
And that's what communicates with
the physical layer, if you will.

439
00:22:13.848 --> 00:22:17.670
Then you have what's known as
the Logical Link Control Layer.

440
00:22:17.670 --> 00:22:22.029
And that's what's actually receiving
information from the networking layer,

441
00:22:22.029 --> 00:22:23.100
if you will.

442
00:22:23.100 --> 00:22:25.030
And then starting to format it, and

443
00:22:25.030 --> 00:22:27.880
handing it to
the Media Access Control Layer, all right?

444
00:22:27.880 --> 00:22:29.870
Now, what does this provide?

445
00:22:29.870 --> 00:22:32.010
Physical addresses, all right?

446
00:22:32.010 --> 00:22:33.670
Those physical addresses
are MAC addresses.

447
00:22:33.670 --> 00:22:35.524
Remember what I told you with Layer 3.

448
00:22:35.524 --> 00:22:39.090
Layer 3, we're talking about
software-defined addresses.

449
00:22:39.090 --> 00:22:40.020
What does that mean?

450
00:22:40.020 --> 00:22:43.380
Well, it means if I grab Dan's laptop,
I can put an IP address on it.

451
00:22:44.740 --> 00:22:46.910
And well,
does that change anything physically?

452
00:22:46.910 --> 00:22:50.926
No, because Dan will look at that IP
address and say, man, Wes is crazy.

453
00:22:50.926 --> 00:22:53.653
[INAUDIBLE] 10 dot,
I use a 192 dot, right?

454
00:22:53.653 --> 00:22:55.331
And he can change it.

455
00:22:55.331 --> 00:22:58.569
With a hardware-level address,
outside of virtualization, so

456
00:22:58.569 --> 00:23:02.207
some of you guys that are watching that
know your OSI model maybe know some of

457
00:23:02.207 --> 00:23:03.890
the software we have out there.

458
00:23:03.890 --> 00:23:07.050
Outside of virtualization,
you can't change these addresses.

459
00:23:07.050 --> 00:23:08.430
>> Well, you can spoof them.

460
00:23:08.430 --> 00:23:09.080
>> That's right.

461
00:23:09.080 --> 00:23:10.450
>> That's splitting hairs.

462
00:23:10.450 --> 00:23:10.992
>> It really is.

463
00:23:10.992 --> 00:23:11.851
And that's in software.

464
00:23:11.851 --> 00:23:15.188
>> Yeah [CROSSTALK]
>> So frames.

465
00:23:15.188 --> 00:23:19.431
Frames happen, you mentioned that too when
we were talking about which layers do we

466
00:23:19.431 --> 00:23:22.730
know what the unit of data
measurement is called.

467
00:23:22.730 --> 00:23:24.050
Here's frames, right?

468
00:23:24.050 --> 00:23:25.070
What else do we got here?

469
00:23:25.070 --> 00:23:25.900
Switches, right?

470
00:23:25.900 --> 00:23:27.580
Switches deal with MAC addresses.

471
00:23:27.580 --> 00:23:28.567
Now-
>> This is where they live.

472
00:23:28.567 --> 00:23:30.850
>> That's right, this is their territory.

473
00:23:30.850 --> 00:23:35.770
Now, in a previous episode, a prior
episode that Dan and I were in, you made

474
00:23:35.770 --> 00:23:39.040
a good mention that we gotta pay attention
to those Layer 3 switches, right?

475
00:23:39.040 --> 00:23:40.010
They'll catch you.

476
00:23:40.010 --> 00:23:41.100
Why is that?

477
00:23:41.100 --> 00:23:43.936
Well, they allow us to do
more than one function,

478
00:23:43.936 --> 00:23:47.257
basically sitting at more than
one layer of the OSI model.

479
00:23:47.257 --> 00:23:51.825
When they say Layer 3 switch, guys,
it means they understand routing, right.

480
00:23:51.825 --> 00:23:53.289
They understand the routing protocols.

481
00:23:53.289 --> 00:23:56.485
We speak that language,
we know what it means.

482
00:23:56.485 --> 00:23:57.965
Right?
>> Not only do they speak but

483
00:23:57.965 --> 00:23:58.632
they can do it.

484
00:23:58.632 --> 00:24:00.260
>> That's right.
They don't just speak it,

485
00:24:00.260 --> 00:24:01.444
they can perform it as well.

486
00:24:01.444 --> 00:24:04.150
So, like I said,
there's an exception to that.

487
00:24:04.150 --> 00:24:06.937
So I want you guys, some of you guys
maybe that are watching to say,

488
00:24:06.937 --> 00:24:08.338
I know switches can do routing too.

489
00:24:08.338 --> 00:24:10.919
We got one in our shop,
that's a layer three switch.

490
00:24:10.919 --> 00:24:14.983
>> And the good news is that on the exam,
they're not gonna try to trick you with,

491
00:24:14.983 --> 00:24:18.630
hey, here's a switch and it's routing,
and try to call it a switch.

492
00:24:18.630 --> 00:24:21.720
They'll most likely label it a multilayer
switch or a layer three switch,

493
00:24:21.720 --> 00:24:22.510
something like that.

494
00:24:22.510 --> 00:24:27.328
Or ask you, if this switch is able
to communicate between VLANs with no

495
00:24:27.328 --> 00:24:29.381
other device, what is that?

496
00:24:29.381 --> 00:24:31.840
And you'll say it's a multi-layer switch,
or a layer three switch.

497
00:24:31.840 --> 00:24:34.620
>> Definitely, and
I would agree with Dan that first of all,

498
00:24:34.620 --> 00:24:35.720
they're not gonna try to trick you.

499
00:24:37.270 --> 00:24:39.807
They might ask you something
about a layer three switch and

500
00:24:39.807 --> 00:24:41.996
say which of these describes
the functionality.

501
00:24:41.996 --> 00:24:46.050
And you should know, like Dan said,
what those functionalities are.

502
00:24:46.050 --> 00:24:47.115
All right, what else do we got here?

503
00:24:47.115 --> 00:24:51.480
Ethernet, ethernet is another
example of a layer two technology.

504
00:24:51.480 --> 00:24:52.957
Frame-relay is an example.

505
00:24:52.957 --> 00:24:55.930
I didn't put it up here but
I can just go ahead and mention it, ATM,

506
00:24:55.930 --> 00:24:57.217
autonomous transfer mode.

507
00:24:57.217 --> 00:25:00.440
Fiber distributed data interface, even
though we really don't use it anymore.

508
00:25:00.440 --> 00:25:01.722
>> Is SONET here?

509
00:25:01.722 --> 00:25:03.230
>> SONET is there thank you very much.

510
00:25:03.230 --> 00:25:05.890
Yes SONET, SDH depending on if
you're here in the country and

511
00:25:05.890 --> 00:25:08.359
you're following ANSI standards
versus ITU in Europe.

512
00:25:08.359 --> 00:25:10.821
Absolutely, Network Adapters.

513
00:25:10.821 --> 00:25:14.972
Now I know [LAUGH] that there's been,
this is always one that's fun, all right?

514
00:25:14.972 --> 00:25:17.690
There is a little bit of a going back and

515
00:25:17.690 --> 00:25:20.500
forth across the Internet that I've
seen when it comes to network adapters.

516
00:25:20.500 --> 00:25:22.453
What do I do with a network adapter?

517
00:25:22.453 --> 00:25:24.890
I plug a physical cable in, right?

518
00:25:24.890 --> 00:25:29.110
So does that mean it's at the physical
layer, and I would say, yeah.

519
00:25:29.110 --> 00:25:31.960
That there are certain functionalities
of a network adapter that are at

520
00:25:31.960 --> 00:25:33.380
the physical layer.

521
00:25:33.380 --> 00:25:35.590
However, it is what defines,

522
00:25:35.590 --> 00:25:39.758
whether you put that information
on that physical layer.

523
00:25:39.758 --> 00:25:42.286
So it's also working at layer two,
so just keep that in mind.

524
00:25:42.286 --> 00:25:44.910
>> Remember that cross-pollination
thing I was talking about here?

525
00:25:44.910 --> 00:25:46.178
We see it yet again.

526
00:25:46.178 --> 00:25:50.475
>> Yeah, and let's give you another
example of that cross-pollination.

527
00:25:50.475 --> 00:25:52.450
I like that analogy.

528
00:25:52.450 --> 00:25:53.770
Layer three, right?

529
00:25:53.770 --> 00:25:56.610
IP knows nothing about MAC addresses,
right?

530
00:25:56.610 --> 00:25:59.530
MAC addresses are a physical
address that we deliver on the LAN.

531
00:25:59.530 --> 00:26:00.520
So what happens?

532
00:26:00.520 --> 00:26:04.630
Well, right in between here, right,
I could probably in here in the middle.

533
00:26:04.630 --> 00:26:05.628
>> The layer 2.5.

534
00:26:05.628 --> 00:26:07.154
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, we could do that.

535
00:26:07.154 --> 00:26:10.037
Well, you know what's kinda funny,
that's what they call MPLS.

536
00:26:10.037 --> 00:26:11.018
>> Yeah.

537
00:26:11.018 --> 00:26:15.960
>> Between the data link layer and
the network layer.

538
00:26:15.960 --> 00:26:18.861
But ARP,
address resolution protocol, right?

539
00:26:18.861 --> 00:26:23.409
When IP a router delivers the IP to
its final destination, to the LAN,

540
00:26:23.409 --> 00:26:26.430
it doesn't know anything
about MAC address.

541
00:26:26.430 --> 00:26:27.535
So what does it do?

542
00:26:27.535 --> 00:26:32.280
It says, well here, ARP, let me just hand
this over to you and can you help me?

543
00:26:32.280 --> 00:26:37.249
And it calls down to the data link
layer and it says, I got an IP address.

544
00:26:37.249 --> 00:26:38.720
Whose MAC address is this?

545
00:26:39.740 --> 00:26:46.870
And Layer 2 responds to ARP and
says, yeah, I know that IP address.

546
00:26:46.870 --> 00:26:49.190
You can find that IP address
at this MAC address.

547
00:26:49.190 --> 00:26:54.130
So you do have, just like he says, a lot
of these layers that are protocols and

548
00:26:54.130 --> 00:26:57.476
servers that might be on both,
more than one layer.

549
00:26:57.476 --> 00:27:00.384
All right, now finally.

550
00:27:00.384 --> 00:27:01.050
>> Finally, last one.

551
00:27:01.050 --> 00:27:01.618
>> Last one.

552
00:27:01.618 --> 00:27:02.180
That's right.

553
00:27:02.180 --> 00:27:04.386
That's the OSI Model Layer 1.

554
00:27:04.386 --> 00:27:10.203
All right, now this is where we start
talking about provides the physical.

555
00:27:10.203 --> 00:27:12.020
You heard what Dan said earlier, right?

556
00:27:12.020 --> 00:27:13.980
The bits, the raw bits.

557
00:27:13.980 --> 00:27:17.602
Now we're talking about things like
electrical impulses or electrical light,

558
00:27:17.602 --> 00:27:19.475
if you're talking about fiber, right?

559
00:27:19.475 --> 00:27:23.190
But you're talking about the raw bits
that are going over the wire, right?

560
00:27:23.190 --> 00:27:24.730
Data encoding happens here.

561
00:27:26.260 --> 00:27:30.466
We talk about things like baseband and
broadband, they happen here.

562
00:27:30.466 --> 00:27:36.040
Some other examples, unshielded
twisted pair, shielded twisted pair,

563
00:27:36.040 --> 00:27:41.400
fiber, T1 your T3 lines,
our physical copper lines, right?

564
00:27:41.400 --> 00:27:43.100
Hubs, hubs are here.

565
00:27:43.100 --> 00:27:44.780
They don't understand logic.

566
00:27:44.780 --> 00:27:48.170
All they do is, they're really more
like a repeater more than anything, and

567
00:27:48.170 --> 00:27:51.540
I probably put repeaters down here and
I didn't, all right?

568
00:27:51.540 --> 00:27:54.760
And then you also have some of these
technologies that we've talked about

569
00:27:54.760 --> 00:27:57.700
like for instance ethernet.

570
00:27:57.700 --> 00:28:00.950
Ethernet describes portions of layer one.

571
00:28:00.950 --> 00:28:01.595
Why?

572
00:28:01.595 --> 00:28:05.699
Because it uses UTP,
STP, and Fiber, right?

573
00:28:05.699 --> 00:28:07.190
Shielded twisted pair if
I didn't say that, guys.

574
00:28:07.190 --> 00:28:10.554
So that is about the physical layer,
all right?

575
00:28:10.554 --> 00:28:14.263
Now we've got more to go because
I wanna show you what's going on

576
00:28:14.263 --> 00:28:16.127
with the processing and stuff.

577
00:28:16.127 --> 00:28:19.700
But I do see that Dan's telling me
it might be time for a part two.

578
00:28:19.700 --> 00:28:22.130
>> Yeah, we've exhausted our time for
this episode.

579
00:28:22.130 --> 00:28:25.381
But Wes, the great thing about this
show is we could just make more.

580
00:28:25.381 --> 00:28:26.462
So, that's what we'll do.

581
00:28:26.462 --> 00:28:28.536
Look forward to seeing
you in that part two.

582
00:28:28.536 --> 00:28:31.194
Thank you guys for watching,
but we are gonna sign off.

583
00:28:31.194 --> 00:28:33.790
For IT PRO TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

584
00:28:33.790 --> 00:28:34.715
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

00:28:34.715 --> 00:28:36.270
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes round out their discussion of the OSI model for network communications. Here they explain the details of the processing order of datagrams on a network as well as the encapsulation/de-encapsulation process.

That's right,

And, of course,
joining us back in the studio,

we're continuing on our
conversation on the OSI model and

the conversations that
are tertiary to that as well.

12

And, of course, joining us in the studio,

13
00:00:37.955 --> 00:00:39.575
Wes, welcome back my man,

14
00:00:39.575 --> 00:00:40.845
>> Man, it's going great, thank you.

15
00:00:40.845 --> 00:00:42.665
As always, great to be here and

16
00:00:42.665 --> 00:00:45.825
great to see you guys out there
in electrical limbo [LAUGH].

17
00:00:45.825 --> 00:00:49.035
That's right,
we are coming back with OSI Mono Part 2.

18
00:00:49.035 --> 00:00:52.875
And there were a couple of things that
we didn't really finish with because

19
00:00:52.875 --> 00:00:56.735
we talked a lot about the theory, and
while most of it's still gonna be theory,

20
00:00:56.735 --> 00:01:00.140
we didn't really discuss,
how is this happening?

21
00:01:00.140 --> 00:01:01.760
We talked about the seven layers.

22
00:01:01.760 --> 00:01:04.770
In fact, let's go ahead,
let's kind of just do a real quick recap.

23
00:01:04.770 --> 00:01:07.060
We're not gonna go into each
individual layer again.

24
00:01:07.060 --> 00:01:10.260
But remember, seven layers,
seven all the way down to one.

25
00:01:10.260 --> 00:01:11.350
The physical being at the bottom.

26
00:01:11.350 --> 00:01:15.260
Remember, application layer, that gives
us our entrance into the network so

27
00:01:15.260 --> 00:01:17.770
we can even send network communications.

28
00:01:17.770 --> 00:01:19.070
Remember the presentation layer,

29
00:01:19.070 --> 00:01:23.670
it's about formatting the data
in a syntax that, basically,

30
00:01:23.670 --> 00:01:27.830
the network can understand or
doesn't have to worry about that.

31
00:01:27.830 --> 00:01:31.144
Session layer, remember that the session
layer is about session establishment.

32
00:01:31.144 --> 00:01:34.209
And this is where we say, okay,
you need a session established,

33
00:01:34.209 --> 00:01:36.780
let me go ahead and
talk to the end point there.

34
00:01:36.780 --> 00:01:39.291
We'll bring up that session,
we'll manage it, we'll maintain it and

35
00:01:39.291 --> 00:01:40.890
we'll terminate it when it's done.

36
00:01:40.890 --> 00:01:43.600
Remember the transport layer's where
we actually start picking which

37
00:01:43.600 --> 00:01:45.535
protocol we're gonna use to move the data.

38
00:01:45.535 --> 00:01:51.070
Largely speaking, we've got two protocols,
two choices, TCP and UDP.

39
00:01:51.070 --> 00:01:56.070
Also remember that at the transport layer
that's where the segmentation happens to,

40
00:01:56.070 --> 00:02:01.090
basically, divide up your information
into more manageable segments and

41
00:02:01.090 --> 00:02:02.530
then sequencing.

42
00:02:02.530 --> 00:02:05.900
And, TCP will make sure that those
are rebuilt in the right order as they

43
00:02:05.900 --> 00:02:08.550
make their way to the destination or
when they do.

44
00:02:08.550 --> 00:02:11.320
Next we have the network layer, keep
in mind this is where routing happens.

45
00:02:11.320 --> 00:02:14.720
This is where your IP address is,
that logical or

46
00:02:14.720 --> 00:02:18.550
software based address
is put onto your data.

47
00:02:18.550 --> 00:02:21.060
Keep in mind, routers,
they communicate at this layer if

48
00:02:21.060 --> 00:02:23.580
it's a layer three switch
also at this layer as well.

49
00:02:23.580 --> 00:02:26.000
As well as things like packet filtering,
remember that.

50
00:02:26.000 --> 00:02:28.046
Next, we have the data link layer.

51
00:02:28.046 --> 00:02:31.649
And the data link layer really is where
LAN communications happen, right?

52
00:02:31.649 --> 00:02:35.028
This is where we have things like
our MAC addresses, our switches,

53
00:02:35.028 --> 00:02:38.710
things like our modems if you will,
network adapters.

54
00:02:38.710 --> 00:02:40.490
And last but not least, the physical bits.

55
00:02:40.490 --> 00:02:44.250
We talked about the physical layer being
about the more about the electrical

56
00:02:44.250 --> 00:02:47.290
mechanics and
characteristics of our network, and

57
00:02:47.290 --> 00:02:52.110
this is where the raw bits end up
being placed on the physical media.

58
00:02:52.110 --> 00:02:53.950
So, with that,
with that little bit of a recap,

59
00:02:53.950 --> 00:02:58.670
let's talk about how the information or
how we're gonna actually use this in

60
00:02:58.670 --> 00:03:02.780
combination with our information
on the networking communications.

61
00:03:03.940 --> 00:03:06.310
So, when you talk about
the processing order,

62
00:03:06.310 --> 00:03:08.580
this is essentially what is going on here.

63
00:03:08.580 --> 00:03:13.839
Now keep in mind that, like I said in
the last part, it doesn't necessarily

64
00:03:13.839 --> 00:03:18.946
mean that you're going to go seven,
six, five, all the way down to one.

65
00:03:18.946 --> 00:03:21.803
Or one all the way back up to seven,
right?

66
00:03:21.803 --> 00:03:24.117
So, for instance,
when we start processing it,

67
00:03:24.117 --> 00:03:28.190
we have application data that is then
sent to the presentation layer, right?

Layer two information,

However, notice the direction,

115
00:06:06.100 --> 00:06:10.310
On the one side here, when

00:06:13.810 --> 00:06:17.750
In wireless technologies, right, we

00:06:17.750 --> 00:06:21.780

00:06:21.780 --> 00:06:25.690
We take multiple signals,

But essentially going,

00:08:36.220 --> 00:08:39.060
And when that happens we

And one of the ones that we wanna look at

167

All right, what frequency divisional,
or division multiplexing is,

168

is typically,
what we have are multiple channels.

169
00:09:13.490 --> 00:09:15.650
We have a bandwidth, right?

170
00:09:15.650 --> 00:09:18.140
And in that finite bandwidth,

171

it is divided up into individual

00:09:22.900 --> 00:09:27.620
And then we can send our
signals over those channels.

173

communication because look what can

I can send signal over one channel, but

also do over adjacent channels?

177
00:09:39.360 --> 00:09:43.330
If we're sending over one channel, you can
see that it looks like we're receiving on

178
00:09:43.330 --> 00:09:46.880
the other channel,
making this a full duplex communication.

179
00:09:46.880 --> 00:09:52.750
So we divide the bandwidth, multiple

410
00:21:59.150 --> 00:22:01.560
We use this in wireless networks too.

411
00:22:01.560 --> 00:22:06.320
And detect would be things like
detecting electrical collisions.

412
00:22:06.320 --> 00:22:08.350
Now what is an electrical collision?

413
00:22:08.350 --> 00:22:10.364
Well, when you have a shared medium.

414
00:22:10.364 --> 00:22:14.488
You have two networking devices that
are sharing the same physical medium and

415
00:22:14.488 --> 00:22:18.677
they both send signals at the same time,
they're essentially like two trains

416
00:22:18.677 --> 00:22:21.580
running at each other on
the same train tracks.

417
00:22:21.580 --> 00:22:23.730
Eventually there's gonna be a collision.

418
00:22:23.730 --> 00:22:30.450
Now, with the carrier detect, your network
adapters have the ability to receive.

419
00:22:30.450 --> 00:22:31.220
So, what's gonna happen?

420
00:22:31.220 --> 00:22:31.970
Electrical collision,

421
00:22:31.970 --> 00:22:37.430
they're gonna reflect fragmented
frames back to the original senders.

422
00:22:37.430 --> 00:22:39.760
Well, those network adapters
can detect that part,

423
00:22:39.760 --> 00:22:41.650
they're listening out to the fragments.

424
00:22:41.650 --> 00:22:44.680
All right, and
this is constantly going on.

425
00:22:44.680 --> 00:22:48.910
This process of carrier sense
multiple access collision detection.

426
00:22:48.910 --> 00:22:51.800
But let's dive in a little bit
more to what's going on here.

427
00:22:51.800 --> 00:22:55.860
All right, so PC 1, when PC 1, and
I've got a BUS network by the way guys.

428
00:22:55.860 --> 00:22:59.000
Same thing would happen if
you have a hub as well.

429
00:22:59.000 --> 00:23:00.770
The process is still the same.

430
00:23:00.770 --> 00:23:04.237
But the way, like we've talked about
in other episodes, collision domains

431
00:23:04.237 --> 00:23:07.293
are a little bit different today
than they were in the earlier days.

432
00:23:07.293 --> 00:23:11.862
Today, every single computer is
on its own individual collision

433
00:23:11.862 --> 00:23:15.610
domain with a switch today
in packet switch network.

434
00:23:15.610 --> 00:23:16.784
So I went ahead and

435
00:23:16.784 --> 00:23:22.210
drew this in a BUS because this is one of
the earliest ethernet implementations.

436
00:23:22.210 --> 00:23:25.830
So a PC 1 has information
that it has to send, right?

437
00:23:25.830 --> 00:23:26.568
It's got a frame.

438
00:23:26.568 --> 00:23:29.140
Hey, I've got information I've gotta send.

439
00:23:29.140 --> 00:23:31.340
It's gonna use its carrier sensibility.

440
00:23:31.340 --> 00:23:33.640
It's gonna say,
is the medium busy, all right?

441
00:23:33.640 --> 00:23:36.335
If so, right,
somebody is already sending information.

442
00:23:36.335 --> 00:23:37.710
You're just gonna have to wait.

443
00:23:37.710 --> 00:23:42.960
All right, see that's detecting is
the medium idle or not, all right?

444
00:23:42.960 --> 00:23:46.990
Now, if it isn't, go ahead and
transfer your data.

445
00:23:46.990 --> 00:23:50.290
Throw your data out there on the wire and
monitor for a collision, right?

446
00:23:50.290 --> 00:23:52.680
Carrier sense and detect.

447
00:23:52.680 --> 00:23:54.980
Now what happens if
a collision's detected?

448
00:23:54.980 --> 00:23:57.100
Here's an interesting thing.

449
00:23:57.100 --> 00:24:01.190
What happens is your computer's
gonna signal its intent

450
00:24:01.190 --> 00:24:02.740
to resend its information.

451
00:24:02.740 --> 00:24:05.150
So, it's constantly trying to
make people aware of, hey,

452
00:24:05.150 --> 00:24:07.200
I've got information to send.

453
00:24:07.200 --> 00:24:07.910
And it waits.

454
00:24:09.250 --> 00:24:10.410
Is the media available?

455
00:24:10.410 --> 00:24:11.570
Okay, I'll send it.

456
00:24:11.570 --> 00:24:14.980
Now, once a collision is detected,
it's gotta let everybody know, hey,

457
00:24:14.980 --> 00:24:17.270
I've got information I need to send.

458
00:24:17.270 --> 00:24:20.900
All right, and what it does is it
increments a retransmit counter.

459
00:24:20.900 --> 00:24:25.900
All right, now that retransmit counter
is only gonna be incremented so

460
00:24:25.900 --> 00:24:28.570
much before they're just gonna give up.

461
00:24:28.570 --> 00:24:30.960
Okay, I can't get this information over,
right?

462
00:24:30.960 --> 00:24:32.470
Abort or just keep retrying.

463
00:24:33.630 --> 00:24:35.780
And then if the collision is detected,

464
00:24:35.780 --> 00:24:38.960
it waits a backoff period,
then it starts over again.

465
00:24:38.960 --> 00:24:42.100
And it says, okay, let's go ahead and
transfer this data.

466
00:24:42.100 --> 00:24:42.600
And let's wait.

467
00:24:43.880 --> 00:24:45.080
Did I hear a collision?

468
00:24:45.080 --> 00:24:47.220
Well, if I heard a collision, guess what?

469
00:24:47.220 --> 00:24:50.770
Now I'm gonna go back to signal
my intent to retransmit.

470
00:24:50.770 --> 00:24:53.830
I'm gonna increment that transmit counter.

471
00:24:54.950 --> 00:24:58.578
Once it hits the maximum
number of retransmits reached,

472
00:24:58.578 --> 00:25:01.007
there's an option to abort or retry.

473
00:25:01.007 --> 00:25:04.140
And it's interesting that the contention
that goes on in these networks,

474
00:25:04.140 --> 00:25:06.000
this is constantly going on.

475
00:25:06.000 --> 00:25:09.080
Every time you're sending information
on a contention based media network,

476
00:25:09.080 --> 00:25:10.390
it's constantly doing this.

477
00:25:10.390 --> 00:25:15.220
Now, you might say, well, that's a real
inefficient way to send communications.

478
00:25:15.220 --> 00:25:16.623
Well, yes and no.

479
00:25:16.623 --> 00:25:21.040
One of the things is, it makes
the technologies that we use fairly cheap.

480
00:25:21.040 --> 00:25:22.360
Cuz they can figure it out themselves.

481
00:25:22.360 --> 00:25:25.750
Versus deterministic media like
the old token rings and stuff.

482
00:25:25.750 --> 00:25:27.750
That would cost a lot of money.

483
00:25:27.750 --> 00:25:29.286
All right, so
that is one of the good things.

484
00:25:29.286 --> 00:25:32.234
Yes, there are possibility for
collisions, possibility for

485
00:25:32.234 --> 00:25:34.018
fragments in these type of networks.

486
00:25:34.018 --> 00:25:37.470
But it kept the communication
equipment relatively low in its price,

487
00:25:37.470 --> 00:25:41.520
which made ethernet less expensive related
to the other technologies of the day.

488
00:25:42.600 --> 00:25:44.950
Now, that's carrier detection.

489
00:25:44.950 --> 00:25:48.154
There's one other one here and-
>> Collision detection.

490
00:25:48.154 --> 00:25:49.241
>> Or, collision detection, excuse me.

491
00:25:49.241 --> 00:25:50.932
>> [LAUGH]
>> Not carrier detection,

492
00:25:50.932 --> 00:25:51.982
collision detection.

493
00:25:51.982 --> 00:25:53.355
Thank you [LAUGH] there, Dan.

494
00:25:53.355 --> 00:25:55.576
There's another one here that
we gotta talk about, Dan.

495
00:25:55.576 --> 00:25:59.520
But I'm looking at the clock and I don't
know if we have enough time in this one.

496
00:25:59.520 --> 00:26:00.760
>> Okay, not a problem.

497
00:26:00.760 --> 00:26:04.069
We can always round things out
with one of our famous part twos.

498
00:26:04.069 --> 00:26:05.296
You know I enjoy those things.

499
00:26:05.296 --> 00:26:06.964
Well, Wes, thanks for getting us thus far.

500
00:26:06.964 --> 00:26:09.190
Looking forward to seeing
you in part two of this.

501
00:26:09.190 --> 00:26:11.440
Hopefully, our good audience
there will join us there.

502
00:26:11.440 --> 00:26:14.590
That being said, for this episode
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

503
00:26:14.590 --> 00:26:16.730
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

504
00:26:16.730 --> 00:26:17.690
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

505
00:26:17.690 --> 00:26:18.758
>> And we'll see you next time.

506
