[MUSIC]

507
00:26:26.970 --> 00:26:29.961
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes round out their conversation about basic network concepts and theories by discussing Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Avoidance(CSMA/CA), 802.11 RTS/CTS, and the TCP/IP networking model in contrast to the OSI model.
episodes.title: Basics of Network Theory and Concepts Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.005 --> 00:00:05.902
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:05.902 --> 00:00:08.381
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.381 --> 00:00:12.108
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.108 --> 00:00:12.826
>> All right.

5
00:00:12.826 --> 00:00:16.795
Greetings all and welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.795 --> 00:00:18.185
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

7
00:00:18.185 --> 00:00:20.665
And in today's episode, well,
if you're here for A Plus,

8
00:00:20.665 --> 00:00:21.565
you've come to the wrong spot.

9
00:00:21.565 --> 00:00:26.035
Because we're doing Network Plus today and
of course, joining me in the studio.

10
00:00:26.035 --> 00:00:28.060
The network master, himself.

11
00:00:28.060 --> 00:00:29.200
Our good friend, Mr. Wes Bryan.

12
00:00:29.200 --> 00:00:29.980
Wes, welcome back, man.

13
00:00:29.980 --> 00:00:31.450
How's it going?
>> Awe, man, it's going good.

14
00:00:31.450 --> 00:00:33.420
Hopefully I can live up
to those expectations.

15
00:00:33.420 --> 00:00:35.388
>> That's right [LAUGH].

16
00:00:35.388 --> 00:00:37.140
>> That's right and
we're coming back with a part two.

17
00:00:37.140 --> 00:00:40.880
We have just a few more things that we
wanted to kind of tidy up when it comes to

18
00:00:40.880 --> 00:00:42.750
the basics of network theory and concepts.

19
00:00:42.750 --> 00:00:46.580
In fact, one of the things that
we left off in the last episode,

20
00:00:46.580 --> 00:00:50.910
we were talking about carrier sends
multiple access collision detection.

21
00:00:50.910 --> 00:00:52.780
And if you remember,
as a real quick recap,

22
00:00:52.780 --> 00:00:56.200
that is pretty much on any
wired ethernet based network.

23
00:00:57.230 --> 00:01:00.110
What they're using as far as
the media access method goes,

24
00:01:00.110 --> 00:01:03.920
that being said, up until 10G and
10G uses something different.

25
00:01:03.920 --> 00:01:05.940
But for the most part,
that's what we've been using for

26
00:01:05.940 --> 00:01:08.580
the last 30 or
40 years when it comes to ethernet.

27
00:01:08.580 --> 00:01:11.550
Remember that a device signals its intent.

28
00:01:11.550 --> 00:01:15.530
Basically saying hey, I've gotta frame,
fully formatted and it's ready to send.

29
00:01:15.530 --> 00:01:19.700
And it listens to see if that,
if the media is available, if it's idle.

30
00:01:19.700 --> 00:01:23.640
And if it does, it sends,
it transmits its data and listens out for

31
00:01:23.640 --> 00:01:24.880
an electrical collision.

32
00:01:24.880 --> 00:01:26.350
And if it detects collisions,

33
00:01:26.350 --> 00:01:33.100
it goes through a back up period if you
will, a little bit of a wait period.

34
00:01:33.100 --> 00:01:35.270
And then it calculates and
it tries to reset.

35
00:01:35.270 --> 00:01:39.530
And it keeps doing that until
finally either a counter,

36
00:01:39.530 --> 00:01:44.920
retransmit counter hits its max and
it just aborts the whole thing.

37
00:01:44.920 --> 00:01:47.850
Or it just constantly keeps
retrying until it finally

38
00:01:47.850 --> 00:01:50.450
sends the information over the wire.

39
00:01:50.450 --> 00:01:53.950
Well, that's not the only thing that
we have inside of our networks as far

40
00:01:53.950 --> 00:01:55.750
carriers since multiple access goes.

41
00:01:55.750 --> 00:01:58.540
We also have what's known
as collision avoidance.

42
00:01:58.540 --> 00:02:03.416
Now, this one's a little bit different,
because this is what we use on 802.11

43
00:02:03.416 --> 00:02:07.087
networks, the IEEE 802.11 based networks,
all right?

44
00:02:07.087 --> 00:02:11.911
It's really kind of hard to detect
an electrical collision when you're

45
00:02:11.911 --> 00:02:13.605
using radiated energy.

46
00:02:13.605 --> 00:02:16.680
[LAUGH] There's nothing
really to bounce back at you.

47
00:02:16.680 --> 00:02:19.840
So we use a different method and
it's called collision avoidance.

48
00:02:19.840 --> 00:02:21.440
Let's go ahead and take a look at it.

49
00:02:21.440 --> 00:02:25.880
So this is CSMA CA as it were.

50
00:02:25.880 --> 00:02:29.920
All right, and
this is what we use on wireless networks.

51
00:02:29.920 --> 00:02:34.530
So if our laptop here wants to send
information, it's gonna have again,

52
00:02:34.530 --> 00:02:37.520
that frame that's fully formatted,
that's ready to go.

53
00:02:37.520 --> 00:02:40.230
And it's gonna detect, is the media free?

54
00:02:40.230 --> 00:02:44.360
And now if the media's free, it's gonna
send out what is known as a jam signal.

55
00:02:44.360 --> 00:02:47.890
And that jam signal is gonna say hey,
I've got data that I've gotta send and

56
00:02:47.890 --> 00:02:51.600
it waits for
everybody to hear it, all right?

57
00:02:51.600 --> 00:02:54.027
Now, what it will also do,

58
00:02:54.027 --> 00:02:58.100
all right, is it will send what's
known as a request to send see.

59
00:02:58.100 --> 00:03:02.380
In the earlier days,
we had something that would come up,

60
00:03:02.380 --> 00:03:03.920
it was called a hidden nodes syndrome.

61
00:03:03.920 --> 00:03:08.460
In fact, I wanna kinda touch base on this
a little bi,t because in the earlier days,

62
00:03:08.460 --> 00:03:11.770
we would use carrier sense
collision avoidance.

63
00:03:11.770 --> 00:03:15.480
Basically we would throw a jam signal
out on the wireless network and

64
00:03:15.480 --> 00:03:19.710
we'd wait a period of time for that to
basically propagate the entire network.

65
00:03:19.710 --> 00:03:23.810
And then we would send our information,
so it's a wait in line method.

66
00:03:23.810 --> 00:03:25.930
Well, it still is a wait in line method,

67
00:03:25.930 --> 00:03:29.880
but today we use what's
known as an RTS/CTS signal.

68
00:03:29.880 --> 00:03:35.200
Now that just sounds like a big bunch of
technical jargon and it really isn't.

69
00:03:35.200 --> 00:03:39.010
It's a request to send signal, right.

70
00:03:39.010 --> 00:03:44.210
We don't use the earlier jam signal
per se if you will, because well,

71
00:03:44.210 --> 00:03:51.150
what happens in a scenario where let's say
you've got 100 yard football field, right?

72
00:03:51.150 --> 00:03:53.600
And your access point
theoretically is in the middle,

73
00:03:53.600 --> 00:03:56.550
you've got two nodes at
the end of the football field.

74
00:03:56.550 --> 00:04:00.655
Well, if I yell out carrier
with that jam signal and

75
00:04:00.655 --> 00:04:05.254
I say hey Dan,
I'm gonna send information, all right.

76
00:04:05.254 --> 00:04:09.580
Well, Dan's all the way on the other
side of the football field.

77
00:04:09.580 --> 00:04:12.230
Dan's computer's listening out,
says I didn't hear nothing.

78
00:04:12.230 --> 00:04:14.460
So he sends a signal, right,
he doesn't hear anything.

79
00:04:14.460 --> 00:04:17.190
So his computer automatically
thinks the media's idle.

80
00:04:18.260 --> 00:04:19.870
But then we get electrical collisions,
right.

81
00:04:19.870 --> 00:04:23.090
And there's no way to detect that
inside of a wireless based signal.

82
00:04:23.090 --> 00:04:26.520
So this would generate what's known
as a hidden node syndrome, right?

83
00:04:26.520 --> 00:04:29.580
In this case,
because I signaled my intent to send but

84
00:04:29.580 --> 00:04:33.220
Dan couldn't hear me,
I just think he's not there.

85
00:04:33.220 --> 00:04:36.620
So what they did is the IEEE
came up with this process,

86
00:04:36.620 --> 00:04:41.508
this IEEE 802.11 RTS/CTS.

87
00:04:41.508 --> 00:04:44.760
And wouldn't it be nice if that access
point in the middle of the football field

88
00:04:44.760 --> 00:04:49.130
had a way of making Dan's computer
aware that I had information to send?

89
00:04:49.130 --> 00:04:50.860
So now that's kind of what's going on.

90
00:04:50.860 --> 00:04:55.670
Now what we have is instead of sending
that to everybody and saying hey,

91
00:04:55.670 --> 00:04:59.970
I'm gonna send my information
across this radiated energy.

92
00:04:59.970 --> 00:05:02.330
Now what I'm gonna do is
I'm going to send an RTS,

93
00:05:02.330 --> 00:05:06.340
request to send signal
straight to the access point.

94
00:05:06.340 --> 00:05:09.850
Now, how does this help
the hidden node syndrome?

95
00:05:09.850 --> 00:05:10.910
Well, I want you to think about this.

96
00:05:10.910 --> 00:05:15.110
If I can yell all the way to the other
side of the field to talk to Dan and

97
00:05:15.110 --> 00:05:18.030
tell him I have information to send,
guess what?

98
00:05:18.030 --> 00:05:19.530
How about the half way point?

99
00:05:19.530 --> 00:05:22.680
Right there in the half way in the middle
of the field, I can talk to the access

100
00:05:22.680 --> 00:05:27.340
point because the access point is
aware of Dan's being on the network.

101
00:05:27.340 --> 00:05:31.090
And guess what the access point says,
it says clear to sender, it says no,

102
00:05:31.090 --> 00:05:33.345
you're not clear to send, all right.

103
00:05:33.345 --> 00:05:36.185
I sent a request to transmit
signal to the access point,

104
00:05:36.185 --> 00:05:38.305
the access point said hold on a second.

105
00:05:38.305 --> 00:05:39.805
I know you've got something to send, but

106
00:05:39.805 --> 00:05:41.885
what you can't hear is
something that I can.

107
00:05:41.885 --> 00:05:44.245
I can hear Dan on the other
side of the football field and

108
00:05:44.245 --> 00:05:46.990
he is already sending information,
so you need to wait.

109
00:05:46.990 --> 00:05:49.650
>> So the access point ends up
acting like a traffic cop saying

110
00:05:49.650 --> 00:05:51.360
I can see vantage points you can't.

111
00:05:51.360 --> 00:05:53.210
So I'll direct the flow of traffic.

112
00:05:53.210 --> 00:05:53.970
>> Absolutely.

113
00:05:53.970 --> 00:05:54.870
Great way to put it.

114
00:05:54.870 --> 00:05:56.700
So I just sent it to the access point.

115
00:05:56.700 --> 00:05:59.160
I don't have to worry about
whether I can hear it or not.

116
00:05:59.160 --> 00:06:01.940
We know the access point can hear
it whether someone else is sending

117
00:06:01.940 --> 00:06:02.730
information.

118
00:06:02.730 --> 00:06:05.937
So that's really all
the RTS/CTS signal is, guys.

119
00:06:05.937 --> 00:06:10.330
Again, it doesn't have to be
technical jargon, all right.

120
00:06:10.330 --> 00:06:13.170
If I wanna know whether I
can send information or

121
00:06:13.170 --> 00:06:15.510
not, why don't I send
the request to signal.

122
00:06:15.510 --> 00:06:19.320
Or request to transmit signal to
the managing device on the network that's

123
00:06:19.320 --> 00:06:21.550
managing the communications, all right.

124
00:06:21.550 --> 00:06:23.560
And if it tells me,
nah you're good, go ahead,

125
00:06:23.560 --> 00:06:26.760
send your information,
then I know I must be okay.

126
00:06:26.760 --> 00:06:32.400
So that's the process, now, all right,
so it's collision avoidance.

127
00:06:32.400 --> 00:06:35.800
Think of it as a wait in line method,
all right.

128
00:06:38.060 --> 00:06:41.120
If I'm sending information
Dan's computer has to send.

129
00:06:41.120 --> 00:06:43.800
It's not like collision
detection where we're just

130
00:06:43.800 --> 00:06:46.630
constantly striving to send
information if it collides.

131
00:06:46.630 --> 00:06:49.946
We'll wait for a second,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore the myriad of wired connectivity standards that you'll need to know for the CompTIA Network+ exam. These standards include the major copper wire standards of past and present such as 10Base2, 10Base5, 10BaseT, 100BaseT, and 1000BaseT.
